PARA.TAB: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Stephen Martin) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.
Message from the Administrator reported informing the House of assent to the following bill:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Witness Protection Bill 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Mr Lavarch:
That the bill be now read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: upon which Mr Ruddock moved by way of amendment:

PARA.TAB: That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House calls on the Federal Government to reform the treaty making process so that the Commonwealth Parliament, the State and Territory governments, and the community are properly consulted on the content and implications of treaties".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the interruption of my remarks I was making the point that many members opposite had suggested that in some strange way or other this debate on the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill had been brought on completely out of the blue to try to embarrass the Tasmanian government and Tasmania. I was pointing out that nothing could be further from the truth. On two occasions, in 1979 and more recently in the time of the Field government, Labor members of parliament in Tasmania had attempted to repeal the Tasmanian laws which proscribe homosexual conduct. They had been unsuccessful because the bills to remove these provisions from the statute books had been defeated in the Tasmanian Legislative Council.

PARA.TAB: Members opposite then had the gall to stand in this House and say that the proceedings of this parliament were overriding the democratic procedures of Tasmania. Everybody here knows that the Legislative Council in Tasmania consists of rotten pocket boroughs, that it needs to be properly reformed and that reform is long overdue. One would hope that the proceedings which have been commenced in the High Court to seek to do just that will have some effect on that matter.

The most important point I want to draw from this is that efforts have been made in Tasmania. They have been thwarted by Liberals and conservatives in the upper house in Tasmania by people who have not a broad picture of the world, who do not understand the implications of their acts. This has led to the tragic situation where Tasmania and good and decent Tasmanians are held up to be a laughing stock in many parts of the world. I know many Tasmanians. They are appalled at the legislation that still exists on their statute books, and their statute books only.

In a sense, all Tasmanians are victims of the social fascists who seek to impose their morality through the application of the criminal law. The use of the criminal law in this way brings into contempt the criminal law itself. Extraordinarily, probably in breach of the criminal law itself, the Tasmanian Attorney has said that he has no intention of enforcing this law. If he is not going to do that, it clearly brings the whole of the law into contempt.

We can see the extent of the problem from the point of view of the Tasmanian government if we think about the fact that, even using the most conservative assessment of the percentage of homosexuals in the community of four per cent and assuming that there is a reasonably active homosexual community amongst that four per cent, it is likely that there are a million and more transgressions of the Tasmanian law every year, not one of them being brought before the courts because of the Attorney-General in Tasmania saying clearly that he has no intention of enforcing this law. As I said, a law which is not enforced, a law which cannot be enforced, is a bad law.

In any event, it is certainly not clear exactly what the people of Tasmania really think about this. It is unclear what the majority of Tasmanians think on this issue. Certainly, the community is heavily divided. I believe that the level of protection of basic human rights in Australia should not depend on where a person happens to live. That ought not be the criteria by which people's rights are determined. It is an absolutely intolerable situation for our nation that a person can undertake certain sexual conduct in private without any direct interest from the law in five of the states while in Tasmania that person can be brought before the courts, prosecuted and, if found guilty, subjected to heavy punishment by imprisonment.

We have heard all the arguments from those opposite, with their hands on their hearts, about their not wanting to see the law enforced. That is not the point. The practical effect of the position those opposite have taken is that the law in Tasmania would remain as it is and 400,000-odd Australian citizens would have very different human rights from those of the rest of the people of this nation. That is not a situation which should be allowed to continue.

Another aspect of the Tasmanian law which I find quite interesting is that this provision was put into the Tasmanian law as section 122 in 1924 and in fact applies to women as well as men. When it was put in, it was probably seen as somewhat enlightened in that it applied to women as well. There is a very cute piece of history about this type of legislation in common law countries. It was originally put into the British criminal law at the time Palmerston was Prime Minister. He was a very cautious fellow and it was put to him, by his advisers as I understand it, that bringing these matters before Queen Victoria would be almost too much for her, the sort of thing that would send her reeling and looking for the smelling salts. So they worked out a compromise.

The legislation in Britain, which was the root of this legislation, applied only to males because it was thought that it would be possible to raise with the good Queen Victoria that these types of activities might occur with males. The idea of suggesting that females should do this sort of thing was quite beyond the sorts of things one could converse with the Queen about in the 1860s.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very exciting anecdote. I don't know what it has to do with the bill.

—It has a lot to do with the bill because it was an attempt at that time to impose what was then seen as Christian morality. I might say that this was at a time when a lot of Christians were still trying to justify slavery as part of Christian doctrine. Tasmania subsequently took this up in its legislation. It had enough guts to actually apply it to everybody by then, but the point is that this sort of legislation should never have been on the books of any of the states of Australia. That the Tasmanian government has not had the guts to be sensible enough to stand up to the Christian fascists who are pushing this sort of doctrine I think is to its eternal condemnation.

PARA.TAB: It is a great pity that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer)—as well as other opposition members—who on other occasions has made very clear his views on the criminal law governing homosexuality, has not had the guts, decency and strength to stand up on this occasion in this parliament and make his views clear. He has wimped it. There is no other word for it. It is, I think, an indication of his weakness and lack of leadership that he did not go straight to Tasmania and put his leadership on the line by saying to the Tasmanian government, `You people have got to do the right thing by Australia, otherwise we will be back in the national parliament voting with the Labor government to make sure that these pernicious laws are removed from the statute books.'

I have been impressed by the contributions some members opposite have made. I have previously referred to the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth). In supporting this legislation, I can do no more than quote her because I think she summed the argument up perfectly when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . by allowing this bill to pass through the House, I am not promoting homosexuality; I am merely sanctioning the right of each of us to make and live by our own decisions. I wish to stress that I respect the opinion of those who have concluded that homosexuality is immoral, but I would simply ask that, in turn, these people respect the right of others to form their own moral judgments.

As I said, you could not put it better than that. I commend the speech by the honourable member for Adelaide. I wish to refer to other matters which have been raised, particularly by some members opposite who have shown not much more than rabid humbug in the way they have approached this matter.

PARA.TAB: The first matter concerns AIDS being drawn into the debate. It is true that Tasmania has the lowest rate of HIV infection in Australia. I do not want to go into the detail of this, but there are many reasons why that may well be the case, such as the fact that Tasmania is an island, is relatively isolated and has a relatively low homosexual community compared with some other states.

The complete contra of that is that the second lowest rate of HIV infection is in my own state of South Australia, which more than 20 years ago passed legislation to remove the proscription on homosexual behaviour from the criminal law. At that time, in the state parliament we had tories, conservatives and Liberals standing up saying, `Hellfire and damnation. This will be the homosexual paradise of Australia. We will have homosexual tourism. We will have all sorts of hellfire and damnation coming down upon us.' What is the judgment of history? The judgment of history is that no such thing occurred. No such thing took place. In spite of the fact that South Australia has had 20 years without a law against private homosexual behaviour, we have the second lowest HIV rate in the nation. It is, therefore, pretty clear that the argument that the HIV infection is in some way related to this law bears no weight at all.

In conclusion, I want to say something about the use of treaties. We have heard a great deal about how supposedly heinous it is to import decent, high quality international standards into this country by use of international treaties. The opposition likes to give the impression that treaties and their implementation in Australia are some new phenomenon undermining our constitution and allowing Australia to be governed from the outside and not by the institutions of this nation. Of course, nothing is further from the truth and the opposition knows that very well.

The opposition, when it was last in government, was no slouch when it came to treaty action. I am informed that the volumes of the Australian Treaty Series from 1976 to 1982 are not, on average, any slimmer than those before or after them. It is ironic that the opposition should now criticise the recent decision of the international Human Rights Committee on the Toonen case, as it was the Fraser government that ratified the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It was that convention which gave rise to the international obligation which was the subject of the comment from the committee. So opposition members cannot run and hide and suggest that this is in some way a conspiracy by this government.

The fundamental platform which gave rise to this piece of legislation being before this parliament was an international treaty that was ratified, brought into effect, by the Fraser government. That might irritate the opposition terribly, or the tail that wags the dog of the opposition, but it is a fact and those opposite cannot get away from it. The current government does not criticise the treaty action taken by the Fraser government; we support it. The real issue here is the essential need, in my view, for uniform human rights for all Australians. That is the fundamental position and that is the reason why the government supports this legislation and will see it through the parliament. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a brief contribution to this debate, although I was not originally intending to speak. The Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill has had a very long list of speakers and most of what can be said has been said. One of my responsibilities in the opposition is to be the spokesperson on HIV-AIDS matters. I thought I should, for the record, put the coalition's view in this debate.

PARA.TAB: It has not been easy for the coalition to come to a decision, because this bill balances two competing principles—the principle of an individual's right to privacy and the right of a sovereign state to manage its own affairs. It is disingenuous in the extreme to pretend that these are not principles that should be of concern to a national parliament. In the end, though, the coalition came to the view that privacy in itself is a principle of enormous importance.

I came into this parliament in 1987 during the time of the debates on the Australia Card Bill. When I made my maiden speech I talked, amongst other things, about the issue of privacy. I was a medical practitioner before I entered parliament. I was very concerned about the implications of the Australia Card Bill and what it might do to private aspects of a person's health—what might happen if it were known what medications people were on, what tests had been ordered. That concerned me greatly.

Many coalition people spoke in that debate, and in the end the bill was not implemented. In this instance our long-held position on privacy came up as the more important of those two competing principles. But I fully accept that some of my colleagues have come to a different view. They have done that after a great deal of soul-searching; and it has not been an easy decision for them.

There have been a number of comments on HIV-AIDS. While this is not a debate on HIV-AIDS as such, I do want to reply to previous speakers. We are now 13 years into the AIDS pandemic. Around the world Australia's response is generally regarded as one of the better responses in the Western world. It is a response that has had cross-party support. It has been pretty good, except in regard to the threat posed to Aboriginal people. There our response has been pathetic, and we will be condemned by future generations for it.

Our response to HIV-AIDS has been predicated on a harm reduction approach. We have taken a commonsense approach and asked: how can we stop people doing harm to themselves? As a result, needle exchange programs have been introduced right around the country, something our colleagues in the United States and other countries simply marvel at. This has meant that the case load of new infections in Australia has plateaued and may be starting to fall whereas in other Western countries it is still increasing. The basis of that has been encouraging people to come forward for voluntary testing and encouraging them to manage the responsibility of their own decisions.

In the first parliament of which I was a member we had an AIDS liaison committee, which comprised people from all parties. Sadly, this is something which does not appear to still exist. In 1988 I was one of the people who was on a working group—the treatment and care subcommittee—set up to formulate the government's white paper on HIV-AIDS. That subcommittee travelled to Tasmania on two occasions. We talked to doctors, people in the community, including people in the gay community, about the issues surrounding the treatment and care of people with HIV-AIDS. Tasmania is quite different from every other state in Australia. I was quite shocked at the feelings of oppression and fear that the Tasmanian people had. Many Tasmanians were moving interstate to get treatment or to be tested for HIV because of the climate that existed in Tasmania then. I cannot say whether that climate still exists but it certainly did exist in 1988.

Tasmania's low level of HIV infection is a factor which partly contributes to this. It is an island and there is a slower progression of the epidemic. But that just reflects the different time scale in the course of the epidemic. Tasmania also has the lowest level of testing of any state. I believe that reflects the fact that many people are going interstate for testing. The test does not tell us what state the person came from; it tells us what state the test was done in.

From my own personal experience, and from talking to some of my former colleagues in the medical profession who treat people with HIV in Hobart, Melbourne and Sydney, there is not a professional working in the field who does not believe that a significant number of Tasmanians are moving interstate for treatment and care. I think that is unfortunate and it goes against the whole thrust of our response to the HIV-AIDS epidemic—a response that has had cross-party support and has been one of the most successful responses, if not the most successful response, in the Western world to date.

I do not, in any way, doubt the sincerity of my colleagues who have raised these issues. It is not something that we often talk about in this place or in the party room. I do not for a moment doubt their motives in raising it because it is a dreadful illness. If we want to see how bad it can be we just have to look at our northern neighbour, Thailand. I was reading a document yesterday put out by the United States government. It predicts that, within 15 years, one in five children between zero and four years of age will die every year in Thailand from HIV-AIDS. It is a matter that generates emotion and is something that we will have to continue to confront here and with our regional neighbours.

I would like to make a few comments about the speech of the honourable member for Makin (Mr Duncan). He highlighted the essentially political nature of this debate. I was disappointed by the disingenuousness of the speech. This place would be a lot better if there were a little more goodwill from time to time. If you are the Leader of the Opposition you have got to cop it all the time. I have had quite a lot to do with the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) on this issue. He has shown guts, decency and strength. We could have endless debates about the structure of the Liberal Party but it is not an easy thing for a Liberal opposition leader in the federal parliament to take a position contrary to five Liberal state premiers. That is what the Leader of the Opposition has done and he has my admiration for doing it.

Many debates in this House are framed in terms of black and white, of one side being right and one side being wrong. An identical situation is faced by a counsellor, particularly in marriage breakdowns. One side is 100 per cent right and sees the other side as 100 per cent wrong. I must say that I have always found difficulty in apportioning blame of any more than 51-49.

The member for Makin portrayed how the Labor Party has approached this matter over the years. I would remind him that it was actually John Gorton who put in a private member's bill to decriminalise homosexual acts in the ACT. Amongst the people who opposed that legislation was the member for Blaxland (Mr Keating), who sits in the Prime Minister's chair opposite. People's views can change over time. I accept that. But perhaps we should have a little bit more honesty in this debate and accept that this can be a difficult issue on both sides of the House from time to time.

The member for Makin talked quite a bit about treaties and treaty making processes. The basis of this legislation is the UN Convention on Civil and Political Rights, which is the cornerstone of human rights around the world. It is true that the Fraser government signed that, and that is something that the Fraser government can be proud of. What the Fraser government did not sign was the optional protocol that allows matters relating to Australia to be taken before a foreign body. It was the Labor Party that signed that. It signed it in the dying days of the last government, with very limited discussion. That is the basis of our concern. It is not the existence of the UN Convention on Civil and Political Rights but the manner in which the optional protocol was signed and the manner in which it is being used.

One's view might change over time. The optional protocol might be something that one can accept down the road as one sees how it works. But when its first application is to effectively override the criminal law of a state, no matter how inappropriate that criminal law may be, it is a cause for legitimate debate. I look forward to finishing this debate and then putting it behind us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham Mr D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill. When one reads Hansard, one can see that this has been an interesting debate. Many contributions have been made from both sides of the parliament. But it is obvious that, even on a cursory reading of Hansard, coalition members appear to have more positions on this bill than the Kama Sutra.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that there are a number of members of the coalition who are petrified of this matter coming to a vote. That is tragic in many ways. I happen to be one of those people who believe that we need to be tolerant and understanding of people with a different opinion. Legislators, in their views on these matters—I will quote the views of some members from the opposite side shortly—really need to be consistent.

Whilst I do not agree with some members of the opposition who have spoken stridently in this debate, I respect them and I respect their consistency. One of those is the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). I think he has been consistent—consistently bad, but he has stuck to his views. When similar matters were voted on in the Queensland parliament, he registered his vote against the legislation. I will give that history when I come to it.
I think it is worth recording the positions of opposition members in this debate. The debate was started for the opposition by the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), who said at page 1778:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . our extreme reluctance to support the use of the Commonwealth's external affairs power to encroach on areas that are otherwise the responsibility of states.

PARA.TAB: After careful consideration of the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill, the coalition has decided that the balance must come down on the side of protection of individual privacy in this instance. Therefore, we will not be opposing this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on in his contribution to quote a legal opinion which the opposition received on the matter that shows, frankly, that the government is well within its rights in bringing this legislation before the parliament. That legal opinion basically says that, in the opinion of that person, it is clear the bill would give rise to a valid act.

PARA.TAB: We then have the contribution of the member for Tangney (Mr Williams), who said on page 1787:

SPEECH.PARA: I have said that I believe the Tasmanian laws should be repealed, but I believe that the Tasmanian government should be the one to repeal them. The federal government should not intervene legislatively to render the laws ineffective.
But he says on balance that he will not oppose the bill. It was a very thoughtful contribution by the honourable member for Tangney, as most of his contributions are.

PARA.TAB: We then have what I regard as probably the best contribution by an opposition member in this debate, and that came from the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), who stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The philosophy of liberalism grew out of the need to find a way to limit government, to protect people's freedom, and this is the philosophy that guides me. In consequence, I cannot oppose the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill.

We then heard the contribution by the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who has really led the charge as far as the opposition is concerned in this matter—that is, as far as his constituency is concerned and as far as Tasmania is concerned. He led the charge to the extent that material he circulated to his colleagues led to the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson) being dismissed by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) from the shadow ministry. The member for Braddon said:

PARA.TAB: I do not oppose this legislation, but I certainly cannot support it because of the reasons which I have outlined to you—that is, based on false information to an overseas, unelected and unaccountable body. It is totally un-Australian.

SPEECH.PARA: That is an interesting position. We will see how the honourable member for Braddon votes on this matter.

PARA.TAB: At page 1844, the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) said, `I state that I am opposed to this bill.' I repeat, I have no problems in that. If he is opposed to the bill, I suggest that the natural consequence of that opposition should be that, if a vote is called for by one of his colleagues, he should support it. Some members are trying to have two bob each way. That is why I suggest that they are diminishing themselves. There needs to be some consistency. I suggest that someone who is on the record as saying `I oppose the bill' should have no hesitation in voting against the matter.

As far as the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) is concerned, frankly, I cannot pick up from his contribution which way he is going. Obviously, he is reserving his position to see whether a vote will be taken.
At page 1938, the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) declared his position, and it is a position of consultation. He goes on to talk about consultation but says:

In conclusion, the Tasmanian law is wrong. The issue of individual liberty is greater than states responsibilities on any issue. But I strongly believe the Labor Party's method of overturning this law is heavy-handed, paternalistic, politically motivated and wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: Yet we have heard from other members of the opposition how at a previous time Mr Gorton introduced a private member's bill in this house and that members of the coalition at that time, some of whom are still in this House—the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) being one—supported that. So it is as if it is a Labor Party inspired thing that we are doing. That is not true. I will go through the history of the decriminalisation that has taken place in every state and territory of Australia other than Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: At page 1941, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) is recorded as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: While I will not be opposing the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994, I most certainly will not be supporting it.

At least he has nailed his colours to the mast. But I would have thought that, given his opposition, given the words that he has used, it really is a logical extension that he should exercise his vote one way or the other. That is what amazes me—that there are people on the other side attempting to sit on the fence. I suggest to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in the context of the history of this debate it is a bit rich. That is the problem with the opposition. On many critical issues, it is attempting to have two bob each way.

PARA.TAB: I have always believed in caucus solidarity, and I do not resile from that. But we have been criticised in this place and around the countryside. We have had held up to us the virtues of the conservative party with the conscience vote. Indeed, the honourable member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan) in her contribution, from which I will quote a bit later, said, `As far as the Liberal Party is concerned, we always have a conscience vote—and it is the same on this issue.'

But the reality is that the kneecappers have been to work on members of the Liberal and National parties imploring those people who hold a genuine view to not even call for a vote. I think it is a bit rich, frankly, for that to be taking place and for the Liberal Party to be attempting to continue to tell us how it is a small `l' Liberal Party, how its members do not like caucusing in the way the Labor Party brings in its people and binds them by a caucus decision.

I would have more respect for the honourable member for Braddon, who is merely a shadow minister, if he would be prepared to take his opposition to its natural conclusion and oppose the legislation. If that is what he believes in and he is in a party that, he believes, gives him in many respects a conscience vote, he should exercise it. But he should not come in here and try to have two bob each way. It is not as if he is a minister or that he will lose anything. What is he going to lose if he is dumped? A shadow ministry. This is the fellow who pedalled material around that led to another person being dumped from the shadow ministry.

Sadly, we are not going to hear a contribution by the honourable member for Wentworth; he is not speaking in the debate. Where is the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard)? Where is the Leader of the Opposition? Sorry, too hard. As far as leadership is concerned, they are still candidates—well, the honourable member for Bennelong certainly is. So you will not find him contributing in this debate.

As I have said, the honourable member for Groom (Mr Taylor) will not be opposing the legislation, but not supporting it. At page 1953, the honourable member for Aston (Mr Nugent) is recorded as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I would have preferred to have supported the legislation.
He is following the coalition line. He gave a thoughtful contribution, a contribution which I respect.

PARA.TAB: What about the honourable member for McPherson (Mr Bradford)? At least there is a rationale behind what he says. Here we have the Secretary of the Australian Parliamentary Christian Fellowship obviously struggling with the situation. I do not happen to agree with his views. But we have someone who is deeply committed to a particular view, who deeply believes in it. What is happening? In his contribution he was unable to oppose the legislation. What a joke. I do not want any lectures from him in future about morality or views that we as individuals should hold, because if he were fair dinkum he would be the one that would be calling for a division on the bill and voting against it. If he took that particular view I would have more respect for him, given his history. I criticise him not because he holds a particular view; it is for the lack of consistency, the hypocrisy that emanates from him.

Those who have been consistent are those like the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter). He made a scatty contribution—that is my summary of it. But at least he made it. At least he nailed his colours to the mast. I have more respect for him in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Bronwyn?

—The suggestion was made as to where the contribution of the honourable member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) is. The opposition has given up flying her flag, so there is no need for her to contribute in this debate. As far as leadership contenders are concerned, she is dead and buried. It came from her own hand. That is the irony of the situation, and that is the irony of the Leader of the Opposition's position at the moment. Some of us have held a view about the Leader of the Opposition for some time. It has been painfully and patently obvious. But his popularity in the polls is not as a result of anything we have done; it is as a result of his own actions. He managed to turn the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) into a statesman, which he is, which he is acting like. It is no mean feat in relation to the rapid movement of the opinion polls, because the position is that there is no alternative. The opposition's performance is appalling.

PARA.TAB: At page 1960 of Hansard the honourable member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss) is recorded as saying that he is voting against the legislation. He further states:

SPEECH.PARA: At its federal conference only last month, the National Party without dissent declared its opposition to the bill.

I am disappointed that many of my colleagues are not choosing to give expression to that principle by voting against this bill. I share many of the concerns raised by my constituents and oppose the bill. When the opportunity arises, I will be voting against it.

I say to the honourable member: if you are fair dinkum, you will be one of the ones that will be calling for a vote. So that is not good enough. Carry that to its natural conclusion. At page 1965 the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) says:

PARA.TAB: I would, however, support the view taken by the previous speaker that fundamentally states do not have rights; people have rights. States have responsibilities and duties, and those responsibilities and duties are primarily to protect the rights of individual citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: At page 1966 he says:
The legislation, therefore, is of fundamental importance.
A federal government which has a vision and a concept of nationhood must be prepared to go beyond state borders on occasions, and certainly in the context of human rights.

The honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur) gave a tirade against the bill, but we really do not know which way he is going, because he does not really declare himself. As I said, I regard the speech by the honourable member for Kennedy as a scatty one, but I respect it. It is consistent with everything we have come to know about the honourable member for Kennedy. He says that he will be voting against the bill, and I respect him for that. And I respect the fact that he opposed similar legislation in the Queensland parliament. Consistent? Yes—consistently bad, as well.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) on page 1975 says:
This bill strikes at the root of the real freedoms that we accept . . .
I am bound by my party—and I put myself willingly under that obligation—to follow what we have decided in the party room. I will not vote against this legislation, but I will not endorse it.

SPEECH.PARA: At least he believes in party solidarity. I respect him for that because I believe in binding caucus decisions as well. I am not going to cop any more criticism from him when he attacks the Labor Party about binding votes, caucus decisions or whatever. So let us nail that one.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), on page 1976, supports the position of the coalition on this legislation. The honourable member for Warringah (Mr Abbott), on page 1980, regards it as `creeping centralism'. That is his contribution to the debate. He is to the right of Genghis Khan. I do not know what he is doing in the national parliament. He should have run for the state seat out that way and tried to make a contribution to the failing conservative government that is going to get punted at the next election.
The honourable member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) made a very thoughtful contribution. He concluded—and I respect him for this—by saying :

SPEECH.PARA: On that basis, with a somewhat heavy heart in having to disagree with my colleagues, I will take fierce pride in crossing the floor and voting against this bill.

I commend him for it—not that I agree with him. He is taking a principled position, which is more than can be said for some of his colleagues who in the lead-up to this debate have led the charge in misrepresentation, have gone out there and played to the rednecks. When the crunch comes can they summon up the courage to even call for a vote? Not on your life.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not allowed to.

—That says something for you. Do not come in here unless you are going to be consistent in relation to the matter. The member for Parkes has been and I respect his position in the debate. He has been consistent; he nailed his colours to the mast. The honourable member for Moore (Mr Filing), on page 1988, said:

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation I cannot support.

What is he going to do? Is he going to vote against it? The honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), on page 1990, said he will not oppose it. Then on page 2024 we have the honourable member for Moncrieff saying that she supports the content and then talks about not opposing the bill. But she said:
There is no question about whether or not members of the Liberal Party have a conscience vote on this or any other issue. We always have a conscience vote.
Let us see some of them exercise it in this debate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to participate today in the debate on the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994. Like the member for Banks (Mr Melham), I have listened to many and read all of the contributions made in this place on this bill. I make the point at the outset that this has been one of the rare opportunities, the rare circumstances, where we have had a very real debate on a range of issues concerning a particular piece of legislation in this House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I would point out, however, to the member for Banks, whose contribution was largely an attempt at mischief making, that he only confirms my view that the bill itself, the legislation itself, is designed to try to cause disarray on the opposition's side of politics. The reason for that is relatively simple. The Labor Party, the ALP, in government has very firm views. Those views are that one has a vote on issues in caucus and one is then bound by the caucus decision. So the member for Banks's contribution, regardless of what he thinks about this legislation, regardless of whether he supports it or opposes it or falls somewhere in the middle on conflicting ideals, philosophy and practice, makes no difference because at the end of the day he will vote with his party en bloc, en masse, or else he leaves his party and his seat in disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —He has no choice.

—He has no choice, no freedom of opportunity, and no ability to come into this place and truly debate ideas, philosophies and opinion. This bill raises a number of issues which are important and a number of matters of principle which I wish to deal with. Firstly, the external affairs power of the constitution was assigned to the Commonwealth. In quite a number of contributions to this debate in this place, members have stated that individual states in our federation have responsibilities but no rights. Section 107 of the constitution states:

PARA.TAB: Every power of the Parliament of a Colony which has become or becomes a State, shall, unless it is by this Constitution exclusively vested in the Parliament of the Commonwealth or withdrawn from the Parliament of the State, continue as at the establishment of the Commonwealth, or as at the admission or establishment of the State, as the case may be.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 108 states:

PARA.TAB: Every law in force in a Colony which has become or becomes a State, and relating to any matter within the powers of the Parliament of the Commonwealth, shall, subject to this Constitution, continue in force in the State; and, until provision is made in that behalf by the Parliament of the Commonwealth, the Parliament of the State shall have such powers of alteration and of repeal in respect of any such law as the Parliament of the Colony had until the Colony became a State.

SPEECH.PARA: States do have the right to legislate with respect to those issues which are not specifically vested as powers in the Commonwealth in our constitution. Let us lay that to rest.

PARA.TAB: The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) could not directly legislate in this instance in order to invalidate sections 122 and 123 of the Tasmanian criminal code. The advice from his advisers and from all the legal fraternity was that he had to find some indirect mechanism. He used the Labor Party option of the external affairs power of the constitution through the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in order to validate legislation to override a state law.

I think that is wrong in principle. I do not believe that the Commonwealth should override state laws in areas where the states have responsibilities. But I do believe that we need a cooperative federalism. It is an issue that increasingly Australians will debate and discuss as we come closer to entering the 21st century. We must come to grips with the sharing of power, the sharing of responsibilities and how we work together to achieve consensus on truly national issues, yet allow diversity at the state and local government level, which is so important to making our constitution work and to allowing individuals real freedom. In his contribution, the member for Banks demonstrated conclusively that he is of the collective—he will speak as a member of a collective and vote as a member of a collective.

On this side of politics we believe in the rights of the individual. We believe that the community has responsibilities and that all of us come together to form communities that are important. We need those communities to deliver services to the individual, not to the state itself. We in this place, on this side of politics, make a very real effort to represent our constituencies, to represent those people who ask us to represent them and their views in this place. That is not always easy because, as I have said, there are many conflicting issues and principles involved in this particular piece of legislation.

We need mechanisms devised for the review of treaties and conventions. As many other members have said, there are close to 2,000 treaties or conventions currently in operation which, one way or another, could affect the legal system of both the Commonwealth and the states.

Generally, the approach under the Fraser government was to reach consensus with the states before signing conventions and treaties, and if consensus could not be reached on any issue, then to put reservations into our ratification of that treaty or convention in favour of a state having the opportunity to make its own decision with regard to that matter. This Labor government has thrown that out the window. With the device that it is using to qualify this piece of legislation under the external affairs power, it took away, as soon as it came to government, the covenants we had placed on that device.

I refer to the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child. There is an issue which raises some of my concerns about how we deal with international treaties and conventions. In 1993, I gave in this place a speech about the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child and, amongst many other things, I said:

SPEECH.PARA: My concerns are not for the generality of the convention, which I absolutely and heartily support. The convention is a document which was long years in the making and long years later than it should have had birth. Unfortunately, in a great rush at the end, I believe that those fine gentlemen, the bureaucrats who put together the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child, made a few mistakes in English. Those mistakes in English have created great concern in my electorate.

I then went on to describe problems inherent in some articles of that convention, specifically articles 12 through to 16, which, if read separately from the preamble or article 5 of that convention, could give rise to the occasion where children may be presumed to have rights despite the rights of their parents to give direction, succour and comfort to their own children. I note that recently my concerns appear to be bearing fruit.

PARA.TAB: I received this week information from an organisation called the Oz Child Legal Service. The Oz Child Legal Service has been set up to provide legal advice, representation for court hearings and other legal matters, information referrals to other appropriate services and community legal education services for children. It provides a toll free telephone number for children and young people throughout Victoria to give them greater access to legal services. Its aims are to make the law relevant, accessible and responsive to children and their needs and to promote the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child by providing legal advice to children and legal representation for children, and on it goes.

In addition, I also received this week a communication from the National Children's and Youth Law Centre. It proposes a national children's and young people's legal advocacy program, a review by the Australian Law Reform Commission of the barriers to justice for children, a commissioner for children to monitor and report on the implementation of children's rights, not their responsibilities, and also a charter of children's and young people's rights enacted in Commonwealth legislation. Not once does it mention children's responsibilities and not once does it mention parents, parents' responsibilities or families.

While at this juncture I will make no adverse comment about either one of these organisations, I flag the fact that I have serious concerns about them because constituents and friends have come to me and told me about problems they are having with their children. Siblings are sometimes trying to divorce their parents and drag the whole family into a situation only to find out that the dollars of support through the welfare system are insufficient for them to live independent lives and they then wish to rejoin their families. I simply make the point that families have responsibilities, parents have responsibilities and, until children reach the legal age, parents should be allowed and encouraged to nurture their children, support them and give them direction in their own places.

So my concerns with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child are that we ratified the convention without debate in this place, without discussion in the community. We made it then all-empowering in the Australian legal system without taking into account the deficiencies in language in four of the articles of that convention which worry many parents. I now see that those worries may come to fruition.

The second major issue of principle that we deal with in this bill is selective use of conventions by this government. I will give you two examples of that. The first is the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, article 20, which deals with freedom of association. I have on two occasions, in 1990-91 and again in 1993, introduced into the House of Representatives an industrial relations bill to guarantee voluntary membership of associations. On one occasion we were allowed to debate the bill. On neither occasion has this parliament ever taken the issue to a vote. This government is not interested in voluntary membership of associations. There is a clear convention, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, article 20, guaranteeing freedom of association, but this government does not believe that is important enough to ensconce in federal legislation. Do honourable members know why? Because it outlaws compulsory union membership.

The second selective use of conventions concerns the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1994, which we debated in this place earlier this year. The Minister for Industrial Relations attempted to use ILO convention 137, signed and ratified in 1974—20 years ago—which deals with containerisation on the waterfront, to allow the waterfront union movement through the finance committee to reintroduce employer levies and pooling of employees, to create once again a register which the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority had attempted to do away with. What happened? The Senate agreed with the opposition that it was an absolutely unconscionable use of the external affairs power of the constitution and a highly selective use of an international convention to try to introduce domestic law in Australia and it overturned it and amended the bill. So the Senate got it right but the minister got it wrong.

The third major issue surrounding this bill is that it gives rise to a de facto bill of rights. I note my extreme concern over a long period of time about codification of rights. The reason for my concern is that, once we write in this place in the English language a right or a responsibility, at some future time future courts which judge the legality or otherwise, the implementation, the application and the practicality of our legislation may make some interpretation of those words that we write today other than we intended. In that regard I refer members to the United States constitution and the first 10 amendments known as the Bill of Rights. In Roe v. Wade, 1973, the Supreme Court of the United States guaranteed abortion rights under the constitution and required that all the states conform. Less than 20 years later, in 1992, the Supreme Court of the United States in the Planned Parenthood v. Casey case, allowed the states to impose restrictions on a woman's right to an abortion.

So in the one case, the earlier case, the Supreme Court decided that the Bill of Rights gave rise to a legal right to an abortion and 19 years later it decided it could put restrictions back on that right to a legal abortion. So codification of rights gives us no guarantee of our real rights to privacy, to free speech and to freedom of religion and all those things which we value dearly. The operation of this country has given us the greatest freedoms on earth without codifying rights.

A fourth issue dealt with by this legislation is sexual conduct. The bill is about sexual conduct. I am no apologist for the homosexual industry, but I recognise and I support their right to do what they will in privacy as long as it does not interfere with someone else's rights or someone else's responsibilities. As a fifth issue, this legislation ensconces a right to privacy. I have explained my reservations about legislating for rights and in this case taking a little portion of a very wide implied document from the United Nations and interpreting it to mean only sexual privacy and using it in this place in order to create a law to override a law in Tasmania.

I make the point about right to privacy and rights in general that laws do not create freedoms; men create freedoms. We create freedoms by our general nature. All laws do is limit freedoms. They apply restrictions to the freedoms that you and I enjoy. I also note in this legislation that the word `arbitrary' is used, and with respect to the right to privacy. I have some concern that at some future time the High Court of this country may judge that word differently from the way this parliament today intends it. I record for posterity my concern that some future justices, well-meaning, may find some different interpretation through the use of the word `arbitrary'.

The mob on the other side that is bringing this legislation before us today cannot decide what they believe in. The honourable member for Banks accuses us of voicing a wide range of opinions about a wide range of issues, yet I note that the Attorney-General, in the Political Advertising Bill debate in 1991, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If we are serious about this problem—
and that is the problem of political advertising—

we must ensure that political decisions and governments are formed on the basis of rational debate and not on the basis of the best film clip, as if to say that Madonna is a better artist than Beethoven because her film clips are a bit more interesting and we like the look of them. Those opposite say, `The great rationale behind upholding this important principle of freedom of speech is that you must be able to buy these 30-second grabs because the world is going to fall down if that is not possible'. What absolute lunacy. The political process will be enhanced by this bill, and I ask the House to support it.

I repeat: the bill is a bit of mischief, attempting to divide the opposition because we have strongly held beliefs and we make every effort to represent the interests and views of our constituency. On balance I do not oppose the bill. I support absolutely the opposition's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr The Hon D.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate on the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 has demonstrated the failure of leadership in the opposition. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) has tried hard but has failed catastrophically to impose his views on the coalition. The Leader of the Opposition said that a conscience vote on this issue would be an abrogation of responsibility and leadership, and he was quite correct. But speaker after speaker in this debate from the opposition has declared that he will vote in defiance of the wishes of the opposition's leadership group. The debate on this bill has left in tatters the moral and leadership authority of the Leader of the Opposition.

PARA.TAB: In this debate the opposition has split in a number of ways. There are those like the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) who best represent the true traditions of liberalism in Australia and support strongly this legislation. There are those like the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb), sitting at the table, who represent the authentic voice of conservative libertarianism in this country and who also support the legislation. But there are those like the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) who have openly expressed their opposition to this bill and those who, perhaps most shamefully of all those members, do not want to vote at all.

The coalition has failed the basic test of good government. If it cannot determine a common position on the simple proposition that the state governments have no place in legislating to prohibit sexual activity between consenting adults, how on earth can it be expected to confront the challenges of government? The Leader of the Opposition, in his press conference of 22 September 1994, said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think a conscience vote is an abrogation of leadership. I mean it is a non-decision. We're not going to vote against the legislation . . . And I think that is a better outcome for us than sort of floating position where everyone can do as they like.

But there were problems inherent in the position of the Leader of the Opposition from the moment the evasive position that the opposition would not oppose this legislation was taken. In those words `not oppose', the liberty was taken by so many on the opposition side to avoid the principle of this issue and to avoid the thrust of what is sought to be done by this legislation.

PARA.TAB: I suppose we could characterise the contributions to this debate in the following way. There are speakers who have indicated plain support for the legislation, and I give them full credit for this. They include: the member for Adelaide; the member for Parkes; the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly); the member for Aston (Mr Nugent); and, in a very moving contribution this morning, the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge).

Then there were those who spoke to take the position which had been formally adopted by the opposition. They were: the member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), leading for the opposition; the member for Tangney (Mr Williams); the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans); the member for Groom (Mr Taylor); the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl); the member for Warringah (Mr Abbott); the member for Barker (Mr McLachlan); and the member for Moncrieff (Mrs Sullivan).

Then came the group of members who sought to sit on the fence and have it both ways, who came into the House and said that they were fundamentally opposed to this legislation but that because they were on the front bench they felt they would have to go along with the proposition that they not oppose the legislation. They were: the member for Braddon (Mr Miles), who said in his contribution that this legislation is `fundamentally un-Australian'; the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman), who said that he believed it is shameful; and the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), who said that he had substantial concerns. Yet, they will, notwithstanding their opposition expressed in debate, proceed to support the proposition that they not oppose the legislation, whatever that might mean. The test of that will come in due course.

Then we had those opposed to the legislation. They were: the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher); the member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott); the member for McPherson (Mr Bradford); the member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur); the member for Moore (Mr Filing); and the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles).

Then we came to the most interesting group, the three who are not only opposed to the legislation but also pledged to vote against it. They are: the member for Wide Bay (Mr Truss); the member for Kennedy; and the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville).

The point I am making is that this legislation cannot be avoided. There are issues of principle here and they are issues which were highlighted in the contribution of the member for Chisholm this morning. He said that when he visited my state of Tasmania in 1988 he was struck by the feeling of oppression and fear amongst homosexuals in Tasmania. He also said that there was not a single professional working in his field who does not believe that a significant proportion of Tasmanians have moved interstate for treatment and care because of that feeling of oppression and fear.

What place is it for the criminal law in our country to create that climate of oppression and fear amongst a group of our community for expressing their sexual preference in the privacy of their own bedrooms? Yet it is precisely the willingness to give comfort to homophobic expressions which in the end colours the views of those who cannot bring themselves to support this legislation or who are actively opposed to it.

In my own state of Tasmania, these feelings of oppression and fear have been significantly contributed to by the way in which, for example, the member for Braddon has conducted himself in the course of his parliamentary career. He has supported groups like HALO, the Homophobic Activist Liberation Organisation, and Tas Alert, which have consistently opposed law reform which would permit homosexuals in Tasmania to at least not be treated as criminals for the expression of their sexual preference.

An example of the kind of homophobic views which have been given comfort by the member for Braddon can be seen in a video of the contribution of Mr Richard Gibbs at a forum in which a number of Tasmanian speakers took part last month. In that forum, which was also addressed by a number of speakers, including Michael Kirby and Senator Abetz, Richard Gibbs, speaking for HALO, said that laws against homosexuality were essential. He said, `History has shown that such laws are essential for civilisation.' But the paranoia and the absurd way in which these views are expressed was taken further. He said that homosexuals are not the only group that wants to promote sexual degeneracy. He said that they were part of a Soviet plot to spread disease, to undermine the family and to destroy the social order. He said that it was part of a humanist agenda whose worldwide headquarters is the United Nations and whose aim is that of one world order. The fundamental neo-fascism and the reach of these views is shown by this quote. He said in defence of his views:

SPEECH.PARA: One document published in Russia at the turn of the century and reported to be the secret work of Zionists follows the Soviet strategy and actually outlines the deliberate spreading of lies and homosexuality as a means of bringing about the collapse of social order in the west. The book referred to is called The protocol of the elders of Zion. Some of you may have seen it. If you have not I suggest you try to get a copy.
Those views, which every member of this House, I believe, would reject with contempt, are being expressed by community movements in Tasmania and are being given comfort by the member for Braddon.

PARA.TAB: Tas Alert circulated a document from the office of the member for Braddon calling a public meeting. Tas Alert purports to be the more user-friendly face of the homophobic movement in Tasmania. One might expect the Homophobic Activist Liberation Organisation to have a certain colouration of an extremist kind, but Tas Alert is an organisation that the member for Braddon has continually associated himself with. A recent leaflet put out by Tas Alert made a personal attack on Elizabeth Evatt, who is Chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Committee, which made the findings that have been the subject of a lot of comment in this debate. That recently circulated leaflet attacked her on the basis that she was the daughter of H.V. Evatt. It stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Dr H.V. Evatt was a friend of notorious Communist Harold Laski and was the First Secretary of the United Nations General Assembly chief architect of which was American Communist Alger Hiss.

Daughter Elizabeth, Chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Committee has been instrumental in the Toonen Homosexual Case providing the wedge by which the Socialist Labour Party may override all State Law.
Like Father Like Daughter
Their allegiance to foreign Socialists and subversive attempts to centralise foreign policy in Canberra are a disgrace to every free thinking Australian.

What a disgraceful performance, but, more importantly, how factually incorrect. First, Elizabeth Evatt is not the daughter of H.V. Evatt. Second, Harold Laski was a friend of Evatt but he was Chairman of the British Labour Party and professor of government at the London School of Economics. He was definitely never a communist. Hiss was not the architect of the United Nations. Indeed, there is no evidence at all of Evatt having corresponded with or ever meeting Hiss. Finally, Evatt was never secretary of the United Nations. He was in fact President of the General Assembly in 1948, but he was not the first but indeed the third president. He was the first English speaking president.

PARA.TAB: The honourable member for Braddon uses his electoral allowance to send out leaflets promoting the views of Tas Alert and promoting rallies like Stand Up for Tasmania, which was organised by Tas Alert. What is the personal view of the honourable member for Braddon? His own views are as extreme as those of Tas Alert and HALO. At a public meeting in Ulverstone in 1991, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The act of homosexuality is unacceptable in any society, let alone a civilised society.
Does that not echo precisely what a Homophobic Activist Liberation Organisation speaker, Mr Gibbs, said in his comments? He said:
History has shown such laws are essential for civilisation.

The honourable member for Braddon really has a question to answer here. He says that laws criminalising homosexual behaviour are essential for civilisation. He also says that he is a person of principle. In the Sunday Tasmanian of 19 July this year, he said:

There are too many people who put their finger up to see which way the wind is blowing and move that way . . . what people want is leadership and you need to let them know your beliefs to be an effective member of Parliament.
In that article, the honourable member for Braddon said that in the end he would answer to God, not the party or the people. As The Examiner of 17 August stated:
This was all before Mr Miles became the Shadow Minister for Schools. Now he has something to lose and the decision isn't so clear cut.
Watch him wriggle. In The Advocate of 27 September this year, he said:
If the proposed Federal legislation had overridden the code, I would vote against it.
As the proposed Federal legislation stands, it does not override Tasmanian law. Sexual practices such as sodomy as covered by the Tasmanian Criminal Code will remain a criminal offence.

What an puerile attempt to avoid the logic of the situation he is facing. The fact that these laws plainly override the Tasmanian criminal code is given testimony to by Senator Abetz. In his briefing paper to opposition members earlier this month, Senator Abetz asked this question:
Does the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994 override Tasmanian law?
The answer:
Yes.
Senator Abetz continued:
Propaganda—
not referring, of course, to his colleague the honourable member for Braddon—

has been peddled that this move by the Federal Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, was clever and smart, and somehow it does not override Tasmanian law . . . The High Court will look behind the legislation and ask the intention of the legislation. The intention is quite clear. It is designed to override Tasmania's laws.

The honourable member for Braddon has no credibility in this matter. He has been the prime organiser of opposition to any reform of Tasmania's criminal laws. Through his office, he has distributed the most extreme propaganda and anti-homosexual literature. He is now confronted by a clash between two principles: will he remain true to the principles that he has espoused for many years in his electorate and oppose the bill—he said he would oppose the bill if it overrode the Tasmanian laws, which it does—or will he try to weasel out?

The truth is that he is now talking of abstaining from the vote. He is simply unable to face one of those difficult choices we face from time to time in politics: do you abandon your principles or your front bench position? The honourable member for Braddon can run but he cannot hide. There is no right to privacy in casting a vote in this place.

PARA.TAB: There is a fundamental question here. The honourable member for Parkes has made a very reasoned contribution to this debate. However, one point he raised needs a specific response. He asked why the Labor government, when in government in Tasmania, did not repeal these very laws. The honourable member for Curtin implied the same by arguing that the Tasmanian House of Assembly was more democratic in its formulation than was the House of Representatives. The truth is that the democratic House of Assembly in Tasmania did try to pass legislation which would have overridden these laws. In December 1990, the Tasmanian Labor government introduced legislation to repeal the offending provisions. It was passed by the lower house but rejected by the gerrymandered upper house—an upper house whose malapportionment of seats is such that the seat of Gordon has in the order of 6,000 electors and the seat of Pembroke has in the order of 26,000 electors.

But in the end the point is this: we have to deal with the situation where, daily, people in my state of Tasmania whose sexual preference is not that shared by the majority of Australians have their privacy invaded. The honourable member for Braddon is at least right about one thing in relation to this debate: laws do have an educative effect. They tell homosexual men in Tasmania that they are criminals. They tell the Tasmanian community that homosexuals are second-class citizens. Those laws intrude into every aspect of the private life of homosexual men. The threat of the criminal law is an invasion in itself. It affects the way people live their lives. If the criminal law is not intended to affect the way people live their lives, then why are these laws still on the statute book?

I return to where I started. I understand that in an interview this morning the Leader of the Opposition said that he expects those on the coalition side, should this issue come to a vote, to actually support this legislation. That was the principled position that should have been adopted in the first place. There should have been clear and unambiguous support of this legislation. I respect the views of those who hold a different position but I disagree with them profoundly. The honourable member for Braddon should lose his position on the front bench, not because he expressed a position of conscience but because he has an intolerance which no opposition frontbencher or government frontbencher should share. There is no room for such intolerance by those who speak on behalf of either the government or the shadow government of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Slipper Mr P.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill we are discussing today has been inappropriately named the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994. Government speakers march into the parliament and pretend that this bill is all about privacy, human rights and Australia's international obligations. At a time when the parliament and politicians in Australia are held in very low esteem, the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the government are indulging in a sordid and cynical exercise in petty politics.

PARA.TAB: While masquerading as champions of the individual, this Labor government—facilitated by the unelected and unaccountable judges of the High Court—is proceeding to tear up the Australian constitution as we have understood it since 1901. In doing so, it is seeking to overturn the criminal law in Tasmania, regardless of what the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) has said. In this nation, criminal law has traditionally been the responsibility of the states. I personally believe that that position should remain. Therefore, I am taking the stand I am on this particular piece of legislation because I am opposed to the federal government's abuse of the external affairs power, as revealed by the speeches of government members.

I cannot support the government in its cynical legislative manoeuvre. I believe that the people of Australia will reject this government's attempt to undermine the Australian constitution. At the very heart of the government's actions is a desire to try to cause division in and between the coalition parties. Our Australian constitution has served this nation well, and we have freedom, stability and a way of life that is the envy of people throughout the world.

I believe the people of Australia are fortunate that they have a system that works. Yet every time you open a newspaper in Australia you find that the government, from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) down, is seeking to destroy a fundamental institution which has given this nation so much. Political standards have sunk to an abysmal level when we find that a government is prepared to destroy the Australian constitution in such a way. The government's real motive is to expose varying views on our side of the chamber.

The coalition of Liberal and National parties prides itself on being a broad church. On some issues we celebrate our unity through diversity. One of the great strengths of conservative politics in Australia is that our members of parliament are not puppets; they are allowed to think. They are elected by their constituents to represent their electorates and to cast a considered vote on any issue. We are mostly of one mind but on difficult issues, such as that posed by the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994, the views of our members undoubtedly have varying emphases. The ALP treats its members as hacks. We have seen situation after situation where government members have objected to what the government is doing but, because of ALP discipline, they have not been allowed to express dissent in this forum.

In debate on the recent Mabo disaster—that awful piece of legislation that has now been placed on the statute books of this nation—we saw the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) express opposition to what the government was doing. He said that he was going to vote against the government, but he was threatened and voted with the government on pain of possible loss of his endorsement. We also remember that former senator George Georges was disciplined by the ALP because he disagreed with the position it took in the parliament.

On our side of politics we are fortunate that we are allowed to think. We are allowed to vote on issues in the parliament in accordance with our conscience. I hope, however, that on this bill the parliament will be permitted to cast a vote on the voices and that a division will not occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your conscience then?

—I will outline where I stand on this bill and what I will be doing should a division occur. There is no way that I am resiling or hiding from my very strong views. I am quite happy to outline to the House of Representatives where I will stand in the unfortunate event that a division is called on this bill. If a division is called, then some coalition members may vote differently or may not vote at all on this piece of legislation. Should this happen, it should be seen publicly as a strength and not as a weakness. It would be public witness that our members of parliament are not slaves to the party and a coherent example that our members are thinking individuals who are able to properly and publicly express their own views and those of their constituency. As I said, we differ very substantially from those opposite, who are required to jump to the dictates of Leaping Leo McLeay, who has now joined us in the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Hon. N.B. Reid)—Order! Members should address honourable members by their correct titles.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Watson. I thank you for the correction, Mr Deputy Speaker, although I am quite certain that the Chief Government Whip was not at all offended by my comment on his athletic prowess. The honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock), as first speaker for the opposition in this debate, pointed out that, as a coalition, we have a very high respect for the principle of privacy. He stated that, in our law and justice policy at the last election, we included the words:

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition puts a high priority on the right to privacy, especially the right to privacy against government.

Therefore, the coalition had a very difficult job when discussing this bill. On the one hand, we had to consider our very strong support for the principle of privacy and, on the other hand, we had to look at the very cynical exercise of the government in seeking to tear up the constitution by using a very broad interpretation of the external affairs power. That was the dilemma that we had.

PARA.TAB: The external affairs power was put in the constitution when Australia became a nation. Quite appropriately, it was understood that matters of an external and international nature should be handled by the federal government. Traditionally, there has not really been a problem with this. But, in recent times, an ever-widening interpretation of the external affairs power has meant that, in effect, the federal government is now able to enter into a treaty on any subject matter with any country. The Commonwealth is thus empowered to legislate, through this parliament, on the implementation of a treaty, regardless of the situation under the Australian constitution and regardless of the normal responsibilities of the states.

Upon our return to government, we will have to address this glaring problem. It is a problem which is reducing our constitution to a sham because the Commonwealth is now able to rule on any matter. When I went to law school, it was clear that at the time of Federation certain powers were given to the Commonwealth and that the remainder of the powers rested with the states. Following these ever-widening interpretations on the part of the High Court, there is clearly a problem which even the government admits. The question is, however: how is it going to be addressed?

This problem could be corrected if the High Court restricted its wide interpretation of the external affairs power. Given the current make-up of the High Court, it is unlikely that we will see that occur in the near future. This parliament could arguably pass an act which would restrict the ability of the executive to enter into treaties. It is unfortunate that, at present, most treaties are entered into simply by the executive. I understand that there is not usually even a full discussion of these matters at cabinet meetings, and the decision to sign and ratify is often made by the Executive Council, comprising the Governor-General and two ministers. It is of concern when such an important power is allocated to so few people.

This problem could also be addressed by a constitutional amendment by virtue of complementary legislation between the Commonwealth and the various state parliaments. But, given the nature of Australian politics and given the varying compositions of parliaments in Australia, that might be a difficult aim as one might find it hard to gain a unanimous point of view right across the nation.

People on all sides of politics are concerned at the impact on our constitution of the wide interpretation of the external affairs power. It is not beyond the realms of possibility that a future coalition government could sit down with state governments of both political colours and say, `Look, we've got this major hiccup in the way that our constitution is now operating and we have to solve it; is this a viable option?'

The last way that this problem could be addressed is by a constitutional amendment with a referendum put to the Australian people. But, with the current reluctance of the Australian people to pass constitutional referenda, that might be a rather difficult way to implement this important change to the constitution. From my point of view, it is unfortunate that it would be difficult to gain a majority of people in a majority of states, as well as an overall majority, on a constitutional question of this nature. However, the reluctance to pass constitutional referenda is going to thwart this government when it ultimately seeks to turn Australia into a republic.

An interesting observation is that, whenever politicians ask for constitutional changes, the people of Australia are somewhat suspicious. With the cynical exercise of the Attorney-General and the government in bringing in this particular bill, is it any wonder that the Australian people are very concerned about the attitudes of politicians? We on our side of the parliament therefore have had a fairly difficult job in deciding our party political position on this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least you can ride a bike.
—Yes, I can certainly ride a bike.
—Order! The honourable member will not respond to interjections.

—Occasionally it is very hard to resist, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I take on board what you say. As always, I will slavishly observe your ruling. The coalition was faced with a range of difficult options. We could have taken three alternative positions: the first was active support, the second was opposition and the third was a middle course, where we would not oppose the bill.

PARA.TAB: Although the options of active support and opposition were canvassed, the middle course ultimately commended itself to the coalition. Personally, I would have preferred the coalition to oppose the government's constitutional vandalism, but, reluctantly, I can live with the party room decision because it did not require us to support the legislation. I fully concur with the decision not to call a division on this issue as to do so would play into the government's hands and enable it to claim a victory but the people of Australia would certainly see it as being a hollow victory.

The reality is that the different actions of our members, should a division be called, would represent a political maturity and tolerance on our side of politics. I implore our colleagues not to call a division on this issue. However, should a division be called, I will register my disgust with the government's tawdry reactions by abstaining. This will ensure that I have made my position clear while conforming fully with the letter and spirit of the party room decision, which was not to oppose the bill in a parliamentary vote.
