I see an abstention as the most accurate interpretation of the party room decision.

Faced with a division, there will be those who elect to convert a position of no opposition to support of the bill on the floor of the House; others will register their opposition by voting against the bill. My essential liberality and moderate approach means that I must respect the individual decisions of others. I hope that a division will not be called on this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hall The Hon R.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill, I am not much interested in the politics that surround this issue. I do not find it a complex issue and I do not find it difficult to say that I support this bill. If there is a division, I will happily cross the floor. I take that position easily because I come from a state parliament—I spent a number of years there—which was renowned for its reforms and many important social issues.

PARA.TAB: I pay tribute—as did the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) in her landmark speech on 12 October—to the Hon. Murray Hill for initiating reforms on this matter in the South Australian parliament in 1972. Strangely, Murray Hill's remarks give a lead to this parliament nearly 22 years later. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I represent the interests of people. People come before all other "interests". In this issue, I am confronted with a minority of people whose cause to change the law . . . is just and right. Irrespective of the severe personal criticism that I know will come from some members of the public, I cannot justify my claim to represent "people" if I turn my back on this minority.

With that background, I must reiterate that I have no difficulty in standing up in this place, halfway through the 1990s, and openly supporting this matter. It is, after all, bringing some finality to the reforms which have occurred in the rest of Australia. I am also at ease with this legislation because it is on all-fours with my liberal philosophy.

PARA.TAB: I can think of nothing better than to extend freedom yet again in this way. I wish we could say that we could extend the freedom of access to the law as easily as we can with this simple and finite matter that is the subject of this bill. I very much regret that, in the matter of the application of the law generally, the citizens of this country are at a deep disadvantage in obtaining access to the decisions made in the courts of law because of the costs and inability to obtain economical legal advice. But that is another matter. I hope this government, the government in office, will move to that matter in due time. I am at ease with the use of the convention powers which enable this government to legislate. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch), in his introductory speech, referred to the course of events. He said:

It was the Liberal-National government of Malcolm Fraser which accepted the standards set out in the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in 1980. It did so after a long period of discussion with the Australian states.

SPEECH.PARA: He went on to indicate the discussions that he had with the representatives of the law in the various states of Australia. I am also at ease with that background and with the Fraser government of 1980—the father to this move—which I joined the following year.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to read on the weekend an article in the `Focus' section of the Weekend Australian written by Michael Detmold, Professor of Law at the Adelaide University. Every politician should read that article because it sets out in terms understandable to those who are not legal practitioners the course of events which is leading to so much change in regard to personal freedoms in Australia.

It would be impossible to incorporate all of this article, although I believe it would be of specific help and assistance in understanding the changes with which we are now dealing. However, I quote certain excerpts:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are growing up as citizens—and we now have the right to judge things for ourselves.

An important part of our growing up as a community has been the High Court's transformation of constitutional law in the past decade. If anything characterises that transformation, it is the importance attributed to citizenship. The old constitutional law was mainly a constitutional law of sovereignties (the stuff of the Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports, and paternalistic by definition); the new is one of citizenship.
He made another point:
The High Court has created a profound and far-reaching constitutional law of citizens' rights that makes the contemplation of a written Bill of Rights now pointless.

The old legal view of the matter was that judges shouldn't make any law at all, that is, they should stay put. This never was a tenable position (for the common law didn't just drop out of the sky—someone has to make it).

Constitutional law is the law of the structure of communities. When a law distinguishes two citizens on rational grounds, it does not construct a separation of community between them; in other words, it does not create an apartheid. They are still bound together in the community of rationality. But when it distinguishes them without rational justification, it cuts them off from community.
All laws discriminate but a irrational discrimination cuts people out of community.

PARA.TAB: The most obvious example of irrational and therefore unconstitutional discrimination is racial discrimination. It is now clear a repeal by the Parliament of the Racial Discrimination Act would be of no consequence; for there is in place a common law guarantee of the same thing.

SPEECH.PARA: The following part of the article touches on the issue of the bill before us. He said:

Not quite so clear but very strongly arguable under the same principle is the constitutional invalidity of the Tasmanian anti-gay law, regardless of any Commonwealth legislation. Humans are sexual creatures. Discrimination against people of a certain sexuality simply excludes them from community; that is, it denies them citizenship.
He ended his article by saying:

The human discovery of the conditions of community and citizenship are equivalent as advances in knowledge to any of the great discoveries in physics. Like the common law, physics didn't just drop out of the sky. The idea that the relations of things are governed by laws that can be known but the relations (in community) of humans are not is mere superstition.

The important point he makes which impinges on this subject is that he believes it is strongly arguable that, even without this law, the existing law in Tasmania may be struck down by the additions to the common law as a result of the recent decisions of the High Court.

PARA.TAB: It is a very simple matter for me to say on that basis that I do not want to remove gays in Tasmania from the community. I do not want to discriminate against them. Quite clearly, this parliament could not. The Fraser government signed the treaty which gives us the enabling authority to place this law before the Australian parliament, and on that basis I support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise but briefly to participate in this debate on the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill. I guess any comments at this stage in the debate from anyone on any side of the House are bound to be repetitious because all that needs to be said has been said. In a synopsis, much of what I feel about this legislation has already been said by the members for Tangney (Mr Williams), Parkes (Mr Cobb) and Fisher (Mr Slipper).

PARA.TAB: I was in the chair when the member for Gilmore (Mr Knott) participated in this debate. He was at some pains to indicate to the House that he felt that the legislation was doing nothing more than guaranteeing the privacy to which he felt he should be entitled, as a husband, to engage in any sort of permissible sexual activity with his wife. While I sat in the chair, the member for Gilmore was clearly anxious to titillate the parliament. He was hoping that some of us in the opposition would in some way be discomforted by what he had to say. The simple reality is that, in my view, he missed precisely what this debate is all about. I have heard no-one on any side of the chamber at any time in this debate indicate that he or she, in any sense, wants to intrude on the rights of individuals to engage in legal activity in private. I have not seen the matter of privacy arise in this debate as an issue that is causing any one of us any angst.

As I understand it, everyone in this House recognises the rights of individuals to engage in legal activity in private. It was in that context that I felt the member for Gilmore had failed to embrace the entire range of what this debate was all about. He was not alone. In common with every other member in the parliament, I have been lobbied by a number of single issue groups which I am sure are well intentioned but which see this legislation as in some ways giving additional rights to Tasmanians, particularly homosexuals, to which they are not entitled. I think they have misrepresented what the legislation is about because, fundamentally, the legislation in my view does nothing more than say, `If the activity that you are engaged in is legal, you are entitled to be engaged in it in private. If that activity does not occur between consenting adults and is not a legal activity, then clearly no-one in society intends to protect or give people an opportunity to engage in illegal activities in private.'

I find, frankly, that no-one in the National Party, the Liberal Party or the parliament has challenged the right of individuals to privacy. Some activities that people engage in may be viewed by others as immoral, but that is not the purpose of the parliament. The purpose of the parliament is to determine what is legal and then to appropriately enforce or amend those laws. For me, the right to privacy poses no problems at all, and in that context—in the context of the right to privacy—I could not oppose the legislation currently before the House.

However, this legislation has been designed principally to pose a problem for the opposition. In many ways, the difficulties that opposition members have referred to over and again have had nothing to do with what has been an attack on us about our attitude to privacy but a great deal to do with what we see as the principal role of the federation and of what is popularly called states rights. My own view is that, whatever is wrong with the law in Tasmania, Tasmanians can sort it out. The Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr), as a Tasmanian, and the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) may well want to remind me that the Tasmanians have failed to sort it out so they felt an obligation to act on behalf of all Australians. Frankly, I do not share that sentiment.

Even in Tasmania the Minister for Justice, as a Tasmanian, gets only one vote, but it has precisely the same impact as the vote of any other Tasmanian. If, as I suspect, the Attorney-General genuinely feels that the Tasmanian government has failed in its responsibility, as the member for Wakefield my reaction to that is inclined to be, `That may be; nonetheless, it is in the hands of the Tasmanians to do something about it.' At that point, I find myself unable to support the legislation simply because, in my view, whatever the faults, the Tasmanians have the power to sort it out.

I am not a lawyer and am not in a position to comment—the Attorney-General may want to comment on this matter—but it may well be that, as the member for Boothby (Mr Steele Hall) has said, the High Court has already set a precedent that will oblige the Tasmanian government to do something. I am not in a position to comment on that, but I recognise that every Tasmanian has the right to do something about whatever is seen to be wrong in Tasmania. That is a right I do not want to take from them or intrude on.

Much has been said about the way in which this legislation is alleged to have split the opposition. I noticed, when the member for Fisher made his remarks, that they were greeted with levity from the government back bench and also the front bench. I think that was a little unkind. I think the member for Fisher was well intentioned; he was prepared to stand up and declare to his electorate that he would be accountable for what he was doing. He was not pretending that he would be on an overseas delegation or not about, and he was entitled to recognition for standing up and declaring his position.

I do not feel, as a member of this opposition—and have never felt in 11 years in this place—dictated to by the party room. The thing that I most resent is the degree to which I am dictated to by the press gallery. Mischief will be made of whatever is done today. There will not be a genuine effort to portray the heart-searching that has gone on on the opposition benches and maybe on the government benches as well. I can speak authoritatively only about the opposition benches. I recognise, as every member of the opposition does, the right of every Australian to engage in a legal activity in private. What I cannot condone is the right of the Commonwealth government to intrude on what is a relatively—I use the word cautiously in terms of the total spectrum of government affairs—incidental exercise in Tasmania, a matter that I believe the Tasmanians have at their fingertips the power to sort out for themselves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with a number of the comments made by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), one of which was that this has been a very long and fulsome debate. I will not keep the House long in terms of recanvassing issues which have been debated fully by many members.

PARA.TAB: I want to address a few of the fundamental and constant themes expounded by many speakers in this debate. Firstly, let us understand that this bill is about human rights. It is based on the same constitutional authority as all other Commonwealth legislation in relation to human rights—that is, the external affairs power of the constitution; putting into domestic law that part of our international obligations that is necessary to fulfil our human rights obligation.

It has been a matter of great moment for many in the opposition that somehow the reliance on and use of the external affairs power are being used in such a way as to essentially destroy or attack the federal-state balance or things of that nature. I do not believe that that is the case.

We must understand some fundamental points here. The constitution itself contains this power. It was not placed in the constitution in recent times; it is part of it. Obviously, a fundamental reason for federation is that the Australian people should speak internationally with one voice. The same constitution establishes the High Court and vests in that court the responsibility of determining questions in relation to the extent of Commonwealth power, the interpretation of the constitution. The High Court again has played that role since its inception, as prescribed by the Australian constitution. So there is nothing new or novel in this power.

It is then suggested that the High Court has in recent times embarked on a new interpretation of the external affairs power. There is no doubt that the external affairs power has been developed over time. However, as early as 1936 it was quite clear, through a number of judgments handed down by the court—for example, in the case of Burgess ex parte Henry—that the Commonwealth, through the external affairs power, did very well have the scope to put into domestic law Australia's international obligations. That has then been a power which governments of both political persuasions have relied on over the years.

It is indeed ironic that the very covenant upon which a large part of our human rights legislation is based, with the use then of the external affairs power, is the covenant on civil and political rights which was ratified by the Fraser government. It was the Fraser government which used the power to establish the Human Rights Commission in this country in its earlier form. So the Fraser government and Liberal-National party governments have relied on the external affairs power. It is quite extraordinary that we now seem to think this presents us with some great difficulty.

The incorporation into domestic law of international processes is hardly something which is new, nor has it largely been controversial. Shortly this House will be debating the question of GATT legislation. This is Australia putting into domestic laws our obligations which we have agreed to under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. In fact, in reality, the impact on Australian lives, on the Australian nation, of this international embodiment into domestic law of international obligations will be far greater than this particular piece of legislation, yet I do not think we will probably get quite the same enthusiasm or conspiratorial theories expounded or one-world government undertones which we have heard in a lot of the contributions throughout this debate, including some contributions in this parliament. So that again faces the reality that Australia is part of the world and this parliament forms part of it.

This legislation also brings up very many fundamental questions about the position of human rights versus states rights. The line expounded by and a common theme coming through from a number of speakers in the opposition is that we should be more concerned about the rights of the Australian states and their legislative power than about human rights. This legislation has been described as `a grab for power by Canberra'. `Another example of creeping centralism' was the expression used by the member for Moore (Mr Filing). Yet, fortunately, we did have more balanced views expressed by members of the opposition. The member for Aston (Mr Nugent) said:

SPEECH.PARA: While we have always said the states should have primary rights in traditional state areas, we cannot overlook the fact that federally we have international obligations. We cannot opt out of living up to them because one or other of the states does not like it. We are not merely empty vessels for the states.

That is a view which has been expressed by different members of the opposition. But the fundamental point, of course, is this: it is individuals who have rights; it is individuals whose rights parliamentarians, parliaments and governments should be interested in protecting. It is not the rights and powers of governments which really we should think are placed higher than that of individuals. I do not believe that is a terribly controversial proposition. I think that would be generally supported by members across the chamber.

PARA.TAB: But we then get down to this second level of argument where people say, `Well, I accept that, but the Tasmanian people have voted for a government, for a parliament, which has decided on a particular course of action. We as individuals may not agree with that, but that's a matter for that parliament.' Tasmanians as well as Australians living in all other states have voted, of course, for a federal government and for a federal parliament as well. This federal parliament also has the right to make determinations and judgments on issues of human rights. It is this parliament which is being asked to make such a judgment on this legislation.

Just as the mandate arguments can be advanced on behalf of the Tasmanian government—that is, if the people do not like the decision made by their representatives on the particular provisions of the criminal code, then let them be voted out at the next election—I can say exactly the same thing: if people do not like the decision of the Commonwealth government on this legislation, if they do not like the decision we are asking the parliament of Australia to make, let them vote us out also on this issue at the next election. That is the difficulty with these mandate arguments—they only take you so far. That is why our constitution recognises that inevitably there will be occasions where there are differences of view, differences in laws, between the Commonwealth and the states. That is why the constitution prescribes through section 109 that, in the case of conflict between a Commonwealth and a state law, it is Commonwealth law which is to prevail. That is the constitutional decision which our founders made. That is the way conflicts between Commonwealth and state laws have always been determined. At the end of the day, even though you may try to clothe this in rhetoric of states rights, it is a completely circular argument.

This parliament has just as much right—if you are going to talk in terms of rights—to make legislation, to make a decision, to make a judgment, as does the Tasmanian parliament. If there is a conflict between the two matters, then the Commonwealth law prevails. That is not different because it is a power based on the external affairs power or putting into Australian law international obligations. If any of the GATT legislation, which this parliament will soon decide, is contradictory to the law of contract which is under the domain of state governments, if it is contradictory to the law of liability or tort which is largely under the domain of state governments, the Commonwealth legislation regarding the implementation of our GATT obligations will override the inconsistent state legislation.

But will we get members of the opposition railing against this? Will we say, `This is an attack upon our constitutional framework'? Will we see this as destruction of the federal and state balance? I do not think we will. I think we will probably get some broad support for the implementation of international GATT obligations into Australian domestic law, notwithstanding whatever impact it may have on state laws or on traditional so-called state responsibilities in the area of contract in tort. Yet suddenly we have this great hang-up about the area of criminal law. Criminal law has never been solely a responsibility of state governments. We have, and have had for many decades, the Commonwealth Crimes Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for Justice points out, we have had very strong support from the opposition—and I commend the opposition for this—for the passing recently through both houses of legislation designed to combat the activities of Australians involved in paedophilia overseas, the child sex legislation, which was a bipartisanly supported measure. This is again legislation which is based on our international obligations and putting an obligation into domestic law.

PARA.TAB: Let us strip away all this meaningless rhetoric. Let us look at the reality. What we should be interested in is the interests of individuals, the interests of human rights—not the power balance of governments. Surely we are not so het up with our own power, drunk with the responsibilities of being politicians, that we forget we are not here to talk about power battles between governments. At the end of the day, surely we are here to look after and be mindful of the rights of our citizens, the rights of the individuals that we represent. That is the fundamental point here.

We then had a range of discussions about the way in which the Commonwealth enters into treaties. That is a legitimate enough debate. Of course it is. People can have differing views about what processes should be employed in relation to the Commonwealth entering into treaties. Let us get a couple of the fundamentals at least understood and restated. Firstly, under the constitution it was a power given to the Commonwealth. The same constitution, under section 61, describes it as an executive function. So that is the starting point for it.

Secondly, there is an agreed set of principles which operate between the Commonwealth and the states in relation to the entry of treaties. These principles and arrangements were agreed upon, in their most recent form, substantially again by the Fraser government in 1977. There has been some change to them, but there has been no change to the substance of them. They were most recently reconfirmed by both the states and the Commonwealth in, I think, 1992. Those are agreed sets of principles that are in place.

Under this scheme, this set of principles, there is established at the Commonwealth and state level a treaties committee, the job of which is to meet to examine treaties which the nation is considering, which it is involved in negotiations on, or about which it is pondering whether ratification should proceed. As well as that, individual ministerial forums discuss and consider the terms of individual treaties. Matters of human rights, such as this matter, go before the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General. Those structures are already in place.

Those opposite almost then miss the point. They say, `In the United States, there has to be the approval of the Congress before the government—the executive, the President—can go off signing treaties, and we should have a similar process here.' That misses the point that, under American law, treaties are generally self-executing; that is, upon signing, they become part of American domestic law. Common law countries, Westminster countries, such as Australia, have a different system. There is no direct impact on domestic law by the signing of a treaty. Rather, it has to be through an action of a parliament that a treaty implication becomes part of domestic law.

So we have this great debate about the involvement of parliament in the treaty process and here we are, sitting here today, being part of the parliamentary involvement of the treaty process, that is, taking part in the discussion of the legislation which is putting part of a treaty into domestic law. It is an absurd argument to say that there should be greater levels of parliamentary involvement. What greater level of parliamentary involvement can you get in a process than having a bill that has to be put, debated and passed by both houses of parliament? There is not some rinky-dink little committee looking at this bill and making a determination. It has to be passed by both houses of parliament. What greater parliamentary involvement is required? Of course, that argument is an absurd argument. It is advanced by people who do not understand the process, or who do not want to understand the process, or who deliberately try to misrepresent the process.

Let us get away from these things which in a sense are almost side issues and look at the provisions of the bill. A range of somewhat bizarre arguments was advanced. I suppose the member taking the cake would have to be the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). Because the words `sexual conduct' are mentioned in the bill, his interpretation of that means that it has anything to do with sex organs. As a result, through his rather tortured reasoning, he believes it is possible that somehow this bill could give comfort or protection to those who may, for instance, be contemplating female genital mutilation. This comes within his definition of sexual conduct.

Here is my advice to the people of Australia: `Never go out on a date with the member for O'Connor.' His version of what sexual conduct is would make me run a thousand miles away. He is entitled to his view, but I would rather refer him to a more thoughtful contribution on the impact of the bill by the member for Tangney (Mr Williams) who concluded that that sort of nonsense was exactly that—nonsense. This bill will not impact on laws governing children or on laws governing incest. It does not deal with acts done in public. It does fundamentally look after the interests of private citizens. The issues have been well canvassed. I urge the House to strongly support—not just not oppose—this legislation.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Ruddock's amendment) stand part of the question.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that this bill be read a second time. All those of that opinion say aye, the contrary no. I think the ayes have it. Is a division required?
—Divide.
—Do I hear two voices? The House will divide. Ring the bell for one minute.
—Where's the second voice?
—There were two voices.
—No, there wasn't a second voice.
—Order! I ask again: are there two voices?
—Yes. This is one voice calling upon the House to divide.
—Is there a second voice?
—Yes.
—There is a second voice. Ring the bell for one minute.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 October, on motion by Mr Bilney:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of legislation implements Australia's commitment to the World Trade Organisation or, if you like, the outcome of the Uruguay Round of the GATT. Similar legislation to that which is being debated in Australia is being put before the parliaments of about 120 other countries. Of particular concern to Australia is what legislation is put before and passed by the parliaments of the European Union, the United States and Japan. Obviously, there is concern that those major powers adhere to the spirit of the Uruguay Round agreement. In my view, what is happening in the European Union at the present time is just as negative or potentially negative as what is happening in the United States. If all parties pass this legislation, it will be a most significant achievement for world trade, and this will include Australia.

PARA.TAB: In the past, I have been critical of the way the Australian government has unilaterally reduced tariffs ahead of all other countries and therefore reduced or removed any leverage we would have in the hard bargaining process of the Uruguay Round. The reason it did this was, first of all, that, as initial chairman of the Cairns Group, it wanted to be seen to be purer than any other country. More realistically, without the government's ability to bring about a more competitive and efficient industry in Australia by labour market reform, the only way it could do it was indirectly through tariff reductions. I also believe the government relied too much on the multilateral agreement and was too slow negotiating bilateral agreements, particularly with our Asian neighbour countries, for better access to those very closed markets. Having said that, I commend this government and those other governments who were members of the Cairns Group for what they have achieved.

I was a member of two bipartisan delegations—one to the European Union and one to the United States—that looked at the progress of the Uruguay Round. I fully support the continuation of the Cairns Group and Australia remaining chair. After two tours of a number of Latin American countries over the last two years, it is obvious that the better relationship that we have with those countries stems to a great degree from the better understanding and feelings that were created by so many of those countries in that part of world being part of the Cairns Group.

There have been projections about who will be the winners and who will be the losers. As a result of the Uruguay Round, it is generally conceded that in Australia the big winners in agriculture are beef, dairy and grain producers, particularly wheat producers. All the projections indicated increased prices, increased production and increased exports. Amongst the losers are some horticultural industries. The citrus industry has been rightly mentioned in this debate because less than adequate attention has been given to the problems of that industry by the government in changes to legislation.

I want to remind members that the citrus industry is not the only horticultural industry that has been a loser as a result of this process. I refer to the deciduous canned fruit industry which has also been a loser. If one goes back a few years, the tariff advantage Australia traditionally had with Canada under the Canada-US Free Trade Agreement, stemming back to the days of empire preference, was removed or phased out over a period of years and preference, if you like, for Californian canned fruit was advanced.

A commitment was made by the then Prime Minister of Australia, Mr Hawke, that Australia's canned fruit industry would not be disadvantaged and the situation would be corrected. Nothing happened as a result of negotiations with Canada, but the commitment was made that it would be sorted out in the Uruguay Round. It has not been. It means that Australia's largest export market for canned fruit is at grave risk as the advantage moves in favour of California and away from Australia.

When one talks about the winners, much will depend on what finally happens with policies in the United States, the European Union and Japan and the access provided to the growing markets in Asia. Generally, it will be the year 2000 before there is any significant improvement for those particular industries. In the meantime, drought and increasing domestic costs could further reduce the ability of those industries to be winners.

We already have higher domestic costs than many of our competitors. With the drought now in its fourth year in some parts of Australia, it is particularly tragic that the grain industry—whether it is wheat, or barley for the growing production of beer around the Pacific Rim—will fail to maintain and develop markets, and that the beef industry, with the rapid expansion of the feedlot industry and value adding, will be unable to continue its advances into a number of Asian countries. If the drought moves further south, the dairy industry could be the next of that winning group to suffer as a result of the drought.

I want now to refer specifically to two sections of the legislation. Firstly, I refer to the dairy industry and the role it plays in Australia. I declare an interest in the dairy industry as I, together with my bank manager, own a dairy farm. Secondly, I will refer to the anti-dumping section of the legislation.

Dairy is quoted as being one of the major winners. The dairy industry is winning now, but it is not a miraculous or easy win because the price that dairy farmers are receiving for their exported product is less than last year and less than two years ago. They are winning to a certain extent because of the European Union's policies and because rising living standards around the Pacific Rim are requiring greater consumption of dairy products.

But the major reason why the dairy industry is well placed, with increased exports and increased value adding of those exports, is that the dairy industry has had to rationalise more over the last 20 years than any other industry in Australia. It has suffered unfair international competition for a longer period and to a greater degree than any other industry in Australia. It goes back to the early 1970s, with the UK entry to the European Community. The European Union, in particular, over the 20 years since then has been a provider of production, of processing and finally of exporting subsidies. Those export subsidies have quite often amounted to over 100 per cent of the price. Compare that to, say, grain. Only since the US Farm Bill of 1985 has there been significant export subsidisation of grain. Generally it has been no more than, say, 40 to 50 per cent of the price.

As a result of this severe and harsh rationalisation, which has been gained at great pain for those who have been forced out of industry, and for that matter those who have remained in the industry—because of the reduced standard of living they have had to suffer to stay in the industry—Australia has gained a great competitive edge, along with New Zealand, the other low cost dairy exporting nation. I represent the Goulburn Valley, the largest concentration of the dairy industry for export of anywhere in Australia. Even in southern Australia the dairy industry has not had some of the advantages of New Zealand. The New Zealanders have continued to have access to the European Community's high priced domestic market and through their domestic pooling arrangements have been able to add to the prices of their producers.

We do not have the same natural advantage of New Zealand, which can grow grass for more months of the year than anywhere else in the world with a temperate climate. However, I believe that advantage is now declining because in New Zealand they are recognising that if you are only going to milk cows for eight or nine months of the year you have very expensive capital tied up both in your farm and your factory which is not being fully utilised. As the genetic potential of your herd increases, the ability to profitably feed grain to further add to that production becomes more and more obvious. New Zealanders do not have the source of cheap grain that we now have.

New Zealand also has a VAT, or GST, which reduces the cost to its domestic producers and gives them an export subsidy. Our market support arrangements are now being terminated. I believe they will be replaced, ironically by a GST type scheme because GST or VAT schemes are the only form of GATT legal export subsidies. It is disappointing to me that the New Zealand government is making threats at present to try to prevent the replacement legislation treating the Australian dairy industry in the way it should be treated, and that is providing through the system some advantage for the local industry, so that the industry in New Zealand has less of the free ride that both New Zealand and the European Union have had with regard to the way their products have been promoted freely—freely for them but at a cost to the Australian dairy industry.

New Zealand's threat about flooding the Australian domestic market because there are no anti-dumping provisions between our two countries is absurd. We could do more to harm New Zealand in international markets as New Zealand is a bigger exporter than we are. The time has come for the government to stand up to New Zealand and say: `What do you do for us with regard to access to your markets? We want to play fair and positive by the dairy industry in Australia with the new legislation.'

The expansion of the dairy industry has been particularly dramatic in Victoria. It has been expanding at seven per cent a year now for quite a few years, with the greatest consistent productivity increase of any industry in Australia. We are now up to about $1.2 billion in exports. In spite of the drought and the dry conditions, production will be well over eight billion litres this year. In Victoria, at least, production this year so far is at least 10 per cent ahead of last year. There has been well over $500 million of investment on dairy farms in the last few years and an even higher figure than that in our factories—a good percentage of that in the major dairy factories in my area. More will be needed, particularly to handle the increasing problem of effluent, as factory production increases and tighter environmental restraints come into place with regard to the discharge of effluent, particularly through the irrigation areas.

We now have the ironic situation of an actual shortage of product for export. This means that some of the lower priced markets will miss out this year. That will be unfortunate if it includes some of the new Latin American markets which have been developed in the last few years. The major exporter processor factories in my area, such as Bonlac, Murray Goulburn, Kraft and Nestle, have put a ban on any new suppliers this year partly because they have a 10 per cent internal growth or productivity increase of their own suppliers. By itself it is difficult to maintain the capital investment needed to handle that, particularly to value add.

But there is a problem. The member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) referred to it to a certain extent in the debate yesterday. Some old factories are having to stay open to handle the dramatic increase in production. They have a problem because there is no doubt that dairy production can increase dramatically in southern Australia. But they are most uncertain as to how much they should be investing partly because of uncertainty over what the United States, and particularly what the European Union, will do and partly because of the uncertainty here as to what this government will do when the challenge comes of replacing the legislation that we are terminating in this debate with what the dairy industry has been promised—equivalent legislation that is GATT legal. That legislation is absolutely essential if the stability and confidence of that industry, which is advancing at a faster rate in exports of value added products from Australia than any other industry to my knowledge, are to be maintained and if that investment is to take place so that extra dairy farms can be allowed to come into the system and extra processing facilities can be built.

The market support scheme that is being terminated has provided some stability and security to allow this investment to take place, to develop these export markets. I am disappointed on behalf of the dairy farmers whom I represent that that problem is not being addressed in this legislation. I acknowledge that there is a clause in the bill which would indicate that the current scheme will continue beyond 1 July, if necessary, until such time as the World Trade Organisation comes into being. But surely there should have been another clause put in saying that the current scheme will also continue until equivalent legislation is put in place. That would have provided the security for the industry to go out even harder to invest than is currently the situation. That is why an amendment will be moved by the opposition in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst not declining to give the bill a second reading, the House is gravely concerned that this legislation is being terminated ahead of the introduction of the GATT Legal replacement legislation, which will be needed to ensure confidence and investment is maintained in the Australian dairy industry.

I hope the government does quickly move to give that confidence to the dairy industry so that this great development can continue. Another important element of the legislation is making our anti-dumping and countervailing legislation consistent with that part of the GATT round. The advice we have been given is that it is mainly for clarification, definition, transparency and, hopefully, uniformity.

PARA.TAB: I am concerned that other countries party to the GATT will legislate similarly. I have some knowledge of the way the United States handles its anti-dumping and countervailing operations. It may be using the same GATT text that we are, but it certainly interprets it differently. I support the comments made by the member for McEwen (Mr Cleeland) that, to a certain extent, it is a question of the attitude of those authorities concerned about this to see that we do have a better balance between those who are allegedly dumping product here or who are benefiting from export subsidisation to give better equality to Australian industries that are being put at risk. Australia is the sufferer of more dumped processed food products than any other country in the world, simply because we have the most open access arrangements for those products of any country in the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bills we are dealing with all revolve around the World Trade Organisation and contain changes to different aspects of the way we do things in this country. Over the last few years there has been a fairly tense debate across Australia on what we as a nation should be doing as far as tariff protection, industry support and the direction in which we should be going are concerned. Those issues were highlighted at the last election and are certainly being addressed in these bills, which will have a profound effect on what happens in Australia, particularly with agriculture, for many years to come.

PARA.TAB: Some of the countries that have agreed to the signing of the GATT agreement have actually signed the document. The signing of the GATT agreement is a milestone in world trade. Understandably, sections of our community, the manufacturing industries and the primary industries, are still quite sceptical as to the outcome. The benefits that we are told will flow to a lot of these industries are yet to be proven.

The bill I focus on today is the Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. Since the mid-1980s the dairy industry has benefited from stabilisation plans that have been put into place. The industry has self-funded its support mechanism as far as the sale of milk on the domestic market and the support of export products are concerned. It has been a highly successful scheme.

I represent the mid-north coast of New South Wales and the dairy industry has for many years been the key primary industry in the electorate of Lyne. It is little wonder that the producers operating within that industry are a little sceptical about being left in limbo between when we do away with this legislation with the all milk levy, which has provided that mechanism for the stability of the dairy industry over the last eight or nine years since it came into being, and when a replacement mechanism or subsidy that is GATT friendly is put into place. The previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), foreshadowed the amendment which is proposed to be moved at the appropriate time. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is gravely concerned that this legislation is being terminated ahead of the introduction of the GATT legal replacement legislation which will be needed to ensure confidence and investment is maintained in the Australian dairy industry.

Confidence is the most important thing—confidence for producers to go on and invest and plan for the future of their operations. These operations are not small by any means these days. A great rationalisation has taken place in the dairy industry right across Australia and there are many hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not millions of dollars, invested in each individual operation. That is all swinging in the breeze at this stage. It might be all right for the people involved in the drafting of this legislation, the people involved in the negotiations as far as GATT or the World Trade Organisation is concerned, and the people still involved in the discussion as to what form the replacement mechanism is going to take, but it is little consolation for the dairy farming community.

PARA.TAB: In many cases at the moment, particularly throughout New South Wales and particularly in my electorate, the dairy industry is facing a very grave situation with the drought, with the lack of available stock and domestic water and the scarcity of feed. We saw in the media this morning and last night that the government is taking measures to try to ascertain the amount of feed still available in Australia. We are facing the prospect of importing feed and grain from overseas to make the bare essentials of life, such as bread, to feed the Australian population. We are confronted with a very grave situation with the drought.

On top of that, this industry is facing up to the situation outlined in this legislation. We flag to the parliament and the government that the situation being created may cause doubt about whether that confidence can continue through this process. I add that the dairying industry has placed a great deal of trust in the government so far in the process that is taking place. We have not seen lots of protests or comment in the media, so the industry seems to be trusting that the government will deliver. We certainly hope that it does and that it delivers a mechanism that sees the dairy industry trade on past the year 2000 as the dynamic industry that it has become. That has been a lesson to a lot of the other primary industries.

What does the bill do? It terminates the market support payments to the Australian dairy industry to comply with Australia's GATT requirements. As I said at the start of my comments, it is interesting to note, and it will be interesting to note in future, the countries that are fair dinkum, that follow up on these negotiations and that make domestic commitments as far as subsidies and support schemes are concerned. We are going through all sorts of pains in this country to make sure that the mechanisms we have in place for the primary and manufacturing industries in this country are GATT friendly.

The market support scheme which has existed is basically a domestic market support scheme paid for by dairy farmers—not taxpayers, not the government, but by the industry—through a levy on all milk. It provides extra payment on exports which encourages manufacturers to export rather than undercut each other on the domestic market, which was happening in the mid-1980s. With this encouragement, dairy exports are growing and are now worth more than $1 billion a year. It is a substantial primary industry and is a substantial earner for the Commonwealth of Australia.

Under 1992 legislation, the market support scheme was to be phased out by the year 2000. At that time, it was to be the equivalent of a five per cent tariff. The government and the coalition have agreed that the phase-out period should continue as planned but in GATT legal form. The bill terminates market support payments to the Australian dairy industry to comply with Australia's GATT requirements. Legislation for the new scheme will be introduced at a later date. The current legislation will be terminated on 30 June 1995. However, this legislation also provides for the termination to be delayed if the World Trade Organisation does not come into force until 1 July 1995.

Here we are here, in October 1994, and we are looking at this coming into place in 1995. There is that element of uncertainty. This industry is facing not only this uncertainty but also one of the worst droughts on living record. The government and the coalition agree that the all milk levy should be phased down by the year 2000 to an amount equivalent to a five per cent tariff. Legislation was in place to achieve this. The levy simply collects money on all milk produced and pays it out to exporters to lift the returns from exports. The system keeps the domestic prices up. If exporters were not helped, they would simply sell their products on the domestic market instead of exporting them. This would cause the domestic price to fall because there would be an abundance of milk on the market.

As honourable members would recall, either earlier this year or at the end of last year there was an amending piece of legislation to the existing act. It plugged a couple of holes with processing operations in Australia, where manufacturers had increased their productivity and their export markets and were bringing milk in from overseas to process and then re-export. The coalition supported the government plugging the gap where some manufacturers were getting export market support for milk that was produced overseas. Over time, the industry has quite maturely addressed that issue. The industry is going along with the measures that the government is taking. It is placing a great deal of trust in the government, and we hope that that trust is returned to the industry.

What about the GATT Uruguay Round? Today we are cognately debating a number of bills, as we did yesterday. These bills are a result of Australia's commitment after the finalisation of the GATT round negotiations, which has now moved on to the World Trade Organisation. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade is a treaty between 118 governments. It seeks to provide a secure and predictable international trading environment for the business community and a continuing process of trade liberalisation in which investment, job creation and trade can thrive. The GATT operates in three ways: as a set of rules for international trade; as a forum for trade organisations to make trade more liberal and predictable; and as a forum for GATT members to resolve their trade concerns.

It is important that we focus on some of those elements. I do not think that the day will ever come when everybody in this nation will be completely satisfied and not a touch cynical about what some trading nations participating in the GATT negotiations are likely to do. We talk about 118 governments participating in the negotiations. Are we going to see 118 signatories? Are we going to see everybody becoming whiter than white as far as their trading practices are concerned? It remains to be seen. We should urge this government to move cautiously and slowly. Unless we see those sorts of reciprocal arrangements existing in other countries, in some aspects Australia may get burnt in its rush to be part of this world trading community.

We have heard many speakers in this debate issue that caution as well. We should consider whether this rush with the reductions in tariffs is being balanced by the commensurate amount of benefits on the other side. Are we seeing the reforms within our own country that are going to offset the protection and the support that Australia has given to a lot of our industries, or are we barrelling down this road at 100 miles an hour just to pacify the advocates of a certain train of economic thought—the free marketeers? Some discussion papers put out on the GATT round mention what world free trade is all about and what is going to be implemented as we go through the GATT process with the World Trade Organisation. We are being told that countries are to reduce by such and such a date their tariff barriers or their equivalents—whether they be subsidies or tariffs—by a certain percentage. Joe Average on the street immediately asks the question: are we all starting off at the same base? The answer is no, we are not starting off at the same base.

Australia has probably led the way in reducing tariffs. This has been done under the current government, although I know that the coalition offered a similar sort of prospect at the last election. But at the last election we spoke a lot more of the balancing benefits that were going to be provided to industry in Australia to offset the reduction in those tariffs. I go back to the question: will people in the world trading community be reducing their tariffs in—for want of a better term—the same real terms? I do not believe they are. I do not have the percentages here but let us say that, over the next couple of years, tariffs have to be reduced by 20 per cent. If Australia is starting off at a 15 per cent base and America is starting off at a 40 per cent base, we are not going to end up on a level playing field and we are not going to end up trading on level terms.

I come back to the question of caution as far as the government is concerned. I suppose that only history will record whether this has been a sound move for Australian industries, Australian primary industries and the employment security of the people working in those industries. It is all well and good to look in those terms at what is going to happen in the future and say `Let's all be a part of that agreement and let's all head towards the trading Utopia'—which is what it is supposed to produce in the world in the future—but history will record whether we achieve that and whether Australia's leading the way with the reduction in tariffs and subsidies in industry support has been a wise move or not.

I come back to where I started: the dairy industry in Australia. Back in the mid-1980s, the dairy industry faced a crisis because there was a lot of internal friction between the New South Wales and the Victorian industries. I note that the shadow minister for resources and energy, the honourable member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran), who is sitting at the table, represents one of the largest dairy electorates in Victoria. The Victorian industry gave the New South Wales dairy industry a fair bit of stick at the time and there was need for a great deal of commonsense to be injected into the industry. We should commend the government and all the people involved at the time—we give credit where credit is due—who worked their way through a very difficult situation.

What do we have today? We have an industry that is exporting in excess of $1 billion worth of product. It is a stable industry, an agricultural industry that is growing—not declining. The processing plants in my electorate are encouraging people to go into the dairy industry because they cannot get enough products to process for export around the world. So the industry is growing.

TALK.START.PARA: —John Kerin did a good job.

—I have already said that at the time the government did a good job. I agree and the industry agrees. But, at the moment, we are going to be leaving the industry a little in limbo. We are wiping this out. We do not have a legislative replacement mechanism in place so the industry—because of the interest the government has shown and through the process of developing the all milk levy back in those days—is trusting the government. We urge the government to reciprocate in that area because this is one of our leading rural industries and is of great benefit to Australia. But it is suffering at the moment because of the drought. Because of the lack of confidence in the World Trade Organisation, we are going to complicate that a little by doing away with the all milk levy before we have a replacement mechanism in place.

PARA.TAB: I will close with some figures from ABARE. They are estimates of increases in annual value of Australian production and exports as a result of the moves that we are making towards this `free world trade'. We are told that there will be an increase in the volume of beef of three per cent, which equates to $340 million; in dairy products of one per cent, which equates to $320 million; and in wheat of five per cent, which equates to $340 million. As far as exports are concerned, they show an increase in exports for beef of seven per cent, which is $330 million; an increase in dairy products of 10 per cent, which is $210 million; and an increase in wheat exports of seven per cent, which is $320 million. That is if it rains again!

I am going to hang on to those projected figures and I will look on with interest to see if they are actually achieved as we move down this path supposedly to a free trading world in the future. I am not a zealot in my cynicism of the abolition of the tariffs and the subsidies and our rush to be a party to this new free trading world. I think we are probably moving a bit too quickly. I would like to see the colour of the money of a few of the other nations around the world which we know are absolutely corrupt in the way they deal with their trading partners. It remains to be seen if we have moved too soon and it remains to be seen if we actually achieve this production. Let us hope for the benefit of the Commonwealth of Australia we do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cleary Mr P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding some rumblings from the National Party and mild concern from a couple of ALP members, the World Trade Organisation amendment bills do not appear to trouble too many people in this House. Finding someone to fiercely question the government and the opposition's obsession with so-called free trade is about as difficult as coaxing Bob and Paul to kiss and make up in Tasmania.

PARA.TAB: It is ironic that the responsibility for taking up the cudgels against the myth of free trade should have fallen on the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) during the adjournment debate on Monday night. It is all very confusing really. On the one hand, the member for Kennedy puts himself in the hillbilly league, vociferously declaring his opposition to the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill and calling for a division, much to the chagrin of his fearless leader. Then, on the other hand, he bounds into the House on Monday, takes off the gloves and gives that sacred cow, free trade, a real pounding on the basis of its effects on local industry.

I would have preferred it if he were protecting healthy products such as potatoes and oranges. As the member for Mackellar (Mrs Bishop) only too well knows, tobacco, like uranium and unemployment, might kill you but it certainly is not illegal. The irony is that, despite the fact that members are supposedly elected to represent their communities, rarely do they defend their communities if doing so puts them in conflict with the party line. Think of the member from Tasmania who walked out of the House today. Instead they offer some mealy-mouthed defence or try to convince the locals by way of religious analogy that a bit of bad medicine will be good for them in the long run.

It is never the same when the question involves sex or sexual morality. On this issue, members of the Lyons Forum have no problems proclaiming their position. When it comes to a bill on sex, it is standing room only on the speakers list. If only they were as forthright on the crucial economic questions, the ones that determine the nature of a person's existence and a country's identity.

Free trade, it seems, is beguiling. Travel on a parliamentary delegation and you will run into more disciples of free trade and market liberalisation than you can poke a stick at. Ask a minister for trade what he or she sees as crucial to the future of the respective country and you will be told it is all about acquiring markets and rectifying trade imbalances. In other words, it is about selling more than you buy.

What I can never work out, however, is: if everyone sells more than they buy, which mythical body is going to do all the buying? The idea that the market is infinite is quite silly. The reality is that it is finite. As everyone knows, GATT, free trade and the World Trade Organisation are about winners and losers. They are about how much of the pie the big fellows can take. They are about a redistribution of wealth which favours developed countries and leaves environmental degradation in the exploited developing world. They are also very much about exploitation of cheap labour. Globalisation is definitely not about an equitable distribution of wealth.

It is true, as the member for Herbert (Mr Lindsay) said yesterday, that trade and internationalisation have the capacity to free us from the parochialism of the old world. Nevertheless, one has to be careful about arguing that globalisation means liberation, whether intellectual or economic. The opinionated Paddy McGuinness would no doubt describe colonialism in Ireland, India or anywhere else as having been a liberating force—and what he knows you could write on a postage stamp.

That globalisation has brought with it the casualisation of work is rarely talked about. That globalisation, GATT and the World Trade Organisation are really about the superpowers pounding their way into other countries' markets with scant regard for the economic and social consequences for the host country is never talked about. Then again, in one sense, that is not completely true.

Some members of the National Party, not least the member for Kennedy, do at least raise the issue of the US government's subsidisation of agriculture. The problem is that, although others such as the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) or the member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) might attack US policy and argue for government support for agriculture, when it comes to the manufacturing sector they are all for competition.

Yesterday the Leader of the National Party introduced his speech by giving his in-principle support to the World Trade Organisation bills. He then proceeded to tell us ad nauseam that there was no such thing as a level playing field. A couple of minor amendments aside, the Leader of the National Party turned out to be yet another unreconstructed devotee of free trade. In a speech on 23 March this year, I cited a claim by Colin Teese, a former deputy secretary to the Department of Trade, that the US trade deficit would only come into balance if 2.5 million offshore workers lost their jobs.

That just about sums up what free trade means to the USA and its mates. It is about self-interest—nothing more. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) might like to think about his statements recently about the Gulf War as well in that context. According to the ALP, free trade and reductions in tariffs have not resulted in jobs being lost in Australia. In fact, so the fable runs, participation rates are going through the ceiling in this reconstructed Australia. The fact that anyone in casual or part-time work or someone doing one-hour stints in the office or the child-care centre is classified as participating in work is conveniently overlooked by the defenders of our economic restructuring.

The Prime Minister tells us having a job in a textile factory is equivalent to having a dead-end job or being in sweated labour. By contrast, we are told having a two-day job collecting the bed linen at a foreign-owned hotel on the Gold Coast qualifies you as an essential component of a new high-tech Australia. The minister relevant to that particular issue is in the House right now.

Enlightened critics such as Ken Davidson and Humphrey McQueen have consistently made the point that our subservience to free trade has eroded our economic sovereignty. The textile sector, which the Prime Minister would probably describe as going gang busters, is now turning out 40 to 70 per cent fewer clothes than it did a decade ago. An exciting niche industry gives a minister plenty to talk about, but it is no substitute for the loss of employment in the industry at large.

There is little chance that we will get an agreement on the implementation of social clauses in the World Trade Organisation, this despite the fact that social clauses would go a long way towards instituting fair and appropriate production cost equalisation. When I moved my motion on 19 September calling on the government to ban imports made with child labour, there was in-principle support in this House. It was not surprising, however, that only one coalition member spoke and she, the member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), opposed the introduction of legislation designed to outlaw child labour. Tax concessions for business are one thing, tariffs are another. In June 1994 an ASEAN official said:

SPEECH.PARA: We will speak with one voice to denounce moves by developed countries to improve workers' wages and welfare benefits in developing countries in the name of free trade.
Such sentiments would please the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles). The Prime Minister of Singapore told the world:

Attempts to check imports from low wage countries like the recent efforts to introduce social clauses on workers' rights and minimum wages into the GATT agenda—betray the West's fear of competition from Asia and its growing sense of economic insecurity.
ACTU President, Martin Ferguson, saw it another way. He described the social clause as being:
. . . about freedom of association, the right to organise and bargain collectively, opposition to forced labour and child labour and discrimination in the work force.
He went on to argue that:
The chief beneficiaries of increased trade in those countries were the elite minorities.

The well-heeled Kuwaiti monarchy, much cherished by our own Prime Minister if recent revelations about his gung-ho approach to the Gulf War are true, is probably one of the elite minorities the ACTU President was referring to.

PARA.TAB: If free trade is designed to make trade free and equal and to remove subsidies and the like which tilt the balance in favour of one party or another, why are negotiators loath to establish equilibrium on the issue of labour costs? Is it because the real agenda is about driving down wages in the developed world rather than raising them in the developing world?

The US government's subsidisation of its agricultural sector is not lost on the crusty Nationals in this House. In a blatant attempt to counter the World Trade Organisation regulations, the USA is considering replacing inconsistent subsidies with other forms of subsidies which would be GATT-WTO consistent. If this is the way of the future, GATT is a joke. China is not even a signatory. In its 1994 report, the Economist's intelligence unit argues that origin labelling should be redundant under the GATT system because it is about discriminating between exports. If that is the case, what does free trade mean for the concept of the nation?

Members of this House generally delight in parading their Australianness. For the coalition, it is Australia with a monarchy, the Union Jack and good old style Menzies morality. For the ALP, it is a new republican Australia, freed of the yoke of colonialism. If the cultural statement is any indication, it is also a whiz-bang Australia of elite artistry.

The irony is that free trade and the GATT in their extremity are the very antithesis of a self-determining nation. I am not talking about the jingoistic, flag waving Australia that is paraded in this House from time to time. What I am talking about is economic nationalism and self-determination. We need to ask republicans and monarchists what kind of rights their nation-state should have in a global economy.

If coalition members are serious in objecting to the so-called influence of United Nations treaties in the fashioning of Australian law, why are they not objecting to the loss of economic sovereignty that accompanies their leaders' subservience to GATT? The Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer) claims that criticism of the World Trade Organisation bills amounts to a return to a Fortress Australia mentality. He should talk! If ever anyone was obsessed with Fortress Australia, I would have thought it was the honourable member. As member after member of the National Party has argued, that is a furphy.

It is all very well for the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer) to declare his in-principle opposition to the anti-dumping measures and the abolition of dairy subsidies and claim that Australia will be the big winner. Where is the evidence? Why are members of the National Party so concerned about the GATT and the World Trade Organisation bills? The problem with the approach of the Nationals is that it stems from a sectional interest, not an overall concern about Australian industry.

The honourable member for Scullin (Mr Jenkins) raised the spectre that any attack on the GATT was a form of populist politics and, by definition, simplistic. This proposition was put despite the passionate defence by the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) of the Australian citrus industry, which he described as internationally competitive and efficient. He went on to tell us that, irrespective of its efficiency, it could not compete with the Brazilian giants.

So here we have the case of an industry which, despite its efficiency, cannot compete in a global economy. It leaves one wondering. Is this what comparative advantage is supposed to mean? It is instructive that the member for Scullin was the only member to refer to the issue of a social clause in the GATT. Not one coalition member saw fit to address this question.

Whether John Quiggan and the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) have it right in their book Work for All remains to be seen. What they did say—and what the member for Scullin chose to ignore—was that Australia's unilateral reduction in tariffs weakened our bargaining position. Certainly, the book argues that globalisation will bring increased employment. The question is what will be the nature of this employment. Will it be the kind of casual and insecure employment which Will Hutton talked about in the Guardian Weekly of 20 March? Hutton argued that we would see:

SPEECH.PARA: an explosive growth not merely of unemployment but of jobs which neither pay a living wage nor survive very long.
In an interview with Monica Attard on PM on 30 September 1994, Jim Gale from the ACT Council of Social Service said:

Of course Australia isn't alone in all of this. Income inequality has got worse in most OECD countries. In particular unskilled workers in the West have seen their wages and their jobs under pressure from two fronts. Freer global trade means they're in direct competition from low paid 3rd world workers, and technological change has cut a swathe through low skilled labour.

For that read the electorates of Wills, Blaxland, Scullin, Calwell, Batman, et al. What really intrigues me is that the coalition has no problems with signing an external treaty which dictates trade matters and reduces the federal government's power, but it is totally opposed to an external treaty which, as is the case with the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill, limits the state government's power.

PARA.TAB: What this House ought to be more concerned about is the loss of cultural identity which comes with globalisation in its present form. Global technology and Hollywood on the harbour are not, by necessity, symbols or conduits of culture. What is cultural about giving Rupert Murdoch and a handful of media monopolies the power to control the production of ideas? I would ask the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Mr Lee) to think about this question. It is all very well to parade and tell us that we are going to have this great rebirth of culture in Australia. But Rupert Murdoch is not culture. The French value their culture. The French would not want Hollywood by the harbour. The French protect their film industry because they believe that their culture actually means something.

People in the opposition ranks talk about culture as if it were something we ought to protect but, when it comes to trade or Rupert Murdoch or media monopolies, the silence is deafening. I find it, quite truthfully, intellectually embarrassing that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Minister for Communications and the Arts can parade about the place and accuse others of cultural jingoism when their dissertations on this brave new multimedia world are so lacking in substance. Ken Davidson is right when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: At this stage of multi-media development what is required is some research into the social, economic and cultural implications of the new technologies associated with multi-media.
Who cares about CD-ROM? It is a process. It is not culture in itself; it is a process.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the content, not the CD-ROMs.

—Is it really content? Is that what we are talking about? Who controls the content—Rupert Murdoch or some other media monopoly? The problem is that it is not the ordinary person who will control the cultural content, just as it is not the ordinary person who controls the opera.

PARA.TAB: Globalisation, the World Trade Organisation amendment bills and free trade are not all they are wrapped up to be. I think it is time members in this House had a serious argument about these kinds of matters. To take us down the track of globalisation in the economic form also has implications for culture and political sovereignty for Australia. It is about time we had a think about it. The revelations yesterday about culture surely would give members something to think about.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say I listened to the points put forward on tariffs by the member for Wills (Mr Cleary) with a certain fascination but I ended up really rather confused. He seemed to be selecting arguments to suit a point of view that changed depending on whether he wanted to attack the opposition or whether he wanted to attack the government, and that did not seem to be consistent either.

PARA.TAB: It does seem to me that he has chosen to overlook the damage that has already been done by protection to many industries, particularly to some of the industries in my area, for example, in agriculture. It has been a constant source of frustration to see the sorts of barriers that have been put up over the years, to see the effect that those barriers have had and to see the distortions that has brought to our economy, where we have seen far too many resources pushed into industries that have relied more on protection than on performance and far too few going into those industries that have had to face some very difficult trading times but nonetheless have still managed to compete on the world markets. Those distortions, of course, are not just those that are imposed by other countries. Many distortions have been built up within the Australian economy in those industries that have been highly protected, many of which, of course, are in the electorate of Wills and we often hear the member for Wills talking about them. Those sorts of distortions have in fact led to an increasing cost burden on many industries that have had to compete on the world markets. Obviously, agriculture is a good example.

One of the best ways to illustrate this is that particularly during the 1970s and the 1980s the ACTU used to lead an almost mindless wage push, and protected industries, particularly in manufacturing, were able to give wage increases in return for maintaining, or in many cases increasing, the protection. But for those industries that were trying to compete on the world market there was no such opportunity to pass on the costs. As a result, we saw growing in the economy a distortion which I think worked very much against some of our most important export industries.

I suggest to the member for Wills that he have a long hard look at that too because right now the trading position of Australia as seen in the monthly balance of payments figures is going further and further into the red. Much of that is because those industries that should be able to export more have been starved of capital, of resources and, in many cases, of the talented people to go into those areas so that when they should have been able to increase the level of exports they have been unable to do so. So on that first point I would have to take some exception to what was said.

The second point that I am rather concerned about is criticism of the idea of reducing protection through the GATT process—something that Australia has fought very long and hard for over many years—and that this somehow is not in the interests of other less developed countries. Again, that overlooks the fact that wherever a country is able to trade and is not being pushed against barriers in seeking to trade with other countries it can raise its standard of living. There is no question that, if a country can raise its standard of living, those who are working in the industries in that country will be able to pay higher wages and get rid of some of the less desirable practices, such as the exploitation of child labour, which the member for Wills rightly highlights. But the way to get rid of that is to allow those countries to trade into a better economic situation. Trade barriers cut both ways and, if we do not allow those countries the opportunity to trade, how can we be so critical of them if they are not able to raise their standard of living?

In the light of the government's past record in handling the dairy industry, I would like to speak about the Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. I was rather surprised to see the way the government has handled this.
