I have a very keen interest in the dairy industry, with the southern part of my electorate being in one of the best dairying areas in the whole of Australia.

I am very proud of the way that the dairy industry has performed in my electorate in recent years. It has gone through a very difficult restructuring, as part of what has happened right across Australia. In case honourable members have forgotten, we can see just how much the dairy industry has had to change by considering a simple statistic: in 1969 there were 47,000 dairy farmers in Australia; today there are probably about 15,000. In other words, there has been a huge reduction. There are only about a third of the number that there were in 1969, only 25 years ago. So the industry has gone through a quite painful process of readjustment, but it has done it very successfully.

In Victoria—and I refer particularly to my region in the south-west—we have seen an industry move away from supplying the fresh milk market, with manufacturing concentrated mainly on butter and cheese, to supplying many different products, many of which are of very high value. So there has been a huge investment in processing. When we are talking about changes, if we look at the investment in value adding—to use another buzz word—in the food industry, of which the dairy industry is a part, the fact that $50 million has been invested just in the south-west of Victoria in the last three or four years is an indication of the confidence that is there.

Interestingly, despite the success of that investment and the fact that it has led to a significantly improved range and quality of products, it has also been recognised that that sort of investment is going to have to occur again very shortly in order to handle the sort of demand that has been built up throughout the Asian region. In south-west Victoria dairy industry production is worth about $1 1/2 billion to the Victorian economy, half of which is in exports. So it is a very significant contributor to the economy of Victoria and of Australia.

We are talking about a very important industry. I wanted to emphasise this point so that I could highlight my concerns about the way the government is handling this change to the program. The dairy industry has been changing from a domestic oriented industry to an export oriented one.

The government's most recent dairy plan of two years ago is accepted, given our commitment to GATT, or the World Trade Organisation as it is now, that we would have to make changes. I do not think anyone argues against that point. But the concern is that the government has brought in this change to get rid of the existing arrangements whereby there is a levy of around 45c per kilogram of butterfat on all milk to encourage the manufacturing sector. The government is scrapping this arrangement, but putting nothing in its place. We accept that the government has said, `Yes, we are going to do this,' but where is the colour of its money? We do not see what it is going to do.

I happen to have been around here long enough to know how this government deals. I recall very clearly events back in 1985 when in Victoria the Cain government was just about to go to an election. Those who can remember that will also remember that the Cain government had run into a lot of trouble with the dairy farmers. In fact, there were mass rallies going on and the senior ministers in the Cain government were looking extremely worried.

What happened was that Mr Kerin, then a minister in the federal Labor government, decided that he would throw them a life raft. Mr Kerin had tried to build up a reputation as a man of integrity and decency. He said, `A new dairy scheme is being considered and I think it looks pretty interesting.' He knew in his own heart, and I think most people in Canberra knew, that he had no commitment to that and no intention of ever following it through. But he was prepared to put his name to a press release which he put out just prior to that 1985 state election to say that he was going to give serious consideration to this dairy plan. He did that in order to help his Victorian Labor colleagues in that election.

If he had been prepared to give serious consideration to it, then maybe we would not have the same objections now. But the point is that within a matter of days of that election being held and the Labor Party being returned in Victoria he said, `No, I was never serious about that.' He just whipped the rug out from under the industry and said, `Go back to the drawing board. We are not prepared to go along with what I said last week, because the Victorian government has been re-elected.'

It is on that basis that I raise these very real concerns. This is the same government that did that. Now it is saying to the dairy industry, `Trust us. We are going to remove the marketing scheme that we put in place to take you through to the end of the decade, and instead we will give you something else. We are not quite sure what it is going to be yet but trust us. We are going to let you go on.'

I have very real concerns about that, and that is why I raise it in this debate today. I believe that we, as a parliament, should be scrutinising properly what the government is doing, and I believe that it should be held accountable for what it is doing. I am very concerned that, whatever the intentions, when the government comes back with its alternative, which it says has to be GATT acceptable—in other words, some system to allow the dairy industry to continue this successful restructure—it will not honour the spirit of what it has said in trying to convince the industry at the moment.

I notice that United Dairyfarmers of Victoria has said that it is working towards redefining the industry support plan, a support plan which, of course, involves the transfer of $85 million. We are not talking about a small arrangement; this is quite an important thing, because 60 per cent of Australia's current support package is paid for by the Victorian producers. There is a 45c per kilogram butterfat levy, and this support is worth just over $10,000 for a property running 130 milking cows. So we are talking big bickies, from the point of view of the industry and from the point of view of individual farmers.

In the build-up to this discussion, which I think the United Dairyfarmers of Victoria is handling in a very responsible manner, it is setting about having meetings amongst members to discuss some of the options. That is perfectly normal, in order and timely. Why does the government have to actually press ahead with this bit of legislation when it knows that it is not essential to do so before the end of the financial year?

The United Dairyfarmers of Victoria has put forward what it calls a reinstrumentation proposal, which has been drafted by the Australian Dairy Industry Council. This features a product levy, pitched at around 4c a litre on domestic sales and also collected on imports. Given that the dairy farmers are prepared to follow this path, the question has to be raised as to why the government is rushing ahead to scrap the existing situation when it has not got an alternative in place.

It may well be that what the Dairy Industry Council is now discussing amongst members will be put forward by the industry as an alternative, but there is still the question of whether the government would agree to it. While the government may have said, `Don't worry, we will look after you,' I go back to the example of 1985, when this government demonstrated very clearly to the dairy industry that there are times when it cannot be trusted. So I raise this concern—and I see it as a very genuine concern. I ask why the government is prepared to go down this path when, clearly, there is a lot of uncertainty.

In the short time that is left to me, I would like to point out another occasion on which the dairy industry found itself caught short because of the government. That was when the move was made towards closer economic relationships with New Zealand. The industry had believed that it would have a certain amount of time in which to operate as we moved down the path towards closer economic relationships. When the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, went across to New Zealand to discuss changes to the CER, he showed very little concern about the dairy industry and he accelerated the move towards closer economic relationships, which again put enormous pressure on dairy farmers.

There is no doubt that that cost them a lot of money, because the costs to dairy farmers in New Zealand were then considerably less than the costs to dairy farmers in Australia. That is still the case today. I give that as a second example of where the Labor government has sold out on the dairy industry and certainly left it high and dry.

I would like to contrast this with the treatment that the government seems to give some of its mates. Who could look further than what has happened with the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) and what he has done for his mates in the Seamen's Union, or the Maritime Union as it is now called, and ANL—the Australian National Line? It is remarkable that the pressure was on with a short nationwide strike at all the ports for just a couple of days, and the minister caved in and said, `Okay, fellas: we will do a deal here. You do not have to pay income tax anymore.' Talk about favouritism, about a privileged position, about doing deals to get oneself out of trouble! The deals seem to be only one-sided—they are only for the mates of the Labor Party—and this shows clearly that it is not a government that is going to work for all, nor a government that cares about the future of all industries in Australia.

Too often in the past we have seen that the government has clearly had very little interest in supporting people working in farming industries. Today, while agriculture has continued to face the pressures of dealing on an international market, it has also had to work with one hand tied behind its back because of the costs that are imposed by the government. These costs arise both directly, through some of the charges that are being placed on agriculture, and indirectly, through the failure of the government to come to proper micro-economic reform decisions in areas such as the labour market, the taxation system and other areas that have directly disadvantaged our exporters but have not at the same time led to proper efficiencies.

I come back to my basic point. I am very concerned about this legislation. We are seeing dairy farmers being asked to take on trust the changes that are going to have to occur because of our agreement with GATT; yet, at the same time, the government is not prepared to give the details of what those changes are going to be before it gets rid of the existing program or plan that is in place for the restructuring of the dairy industry. I am very concerned about it. I believe that everyone in this chamber should be very concerned about it and that the dairy farmers of Australia should be, too.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems a little ironic and perhaps timely that I am able to have the opportunity to speak on the eight cognate bills being debated at this particular time. The bills of course implement Australia's obligations to amend legislation so that it conforms to the agreements that Australia has entered into to implement the post-Uruguay trade agreements. Those negotiations have been going on for some seven years and have finally led to 120 countries agreeing to implement reforms and policies in the trade area. These reforms and policies will have a dramatic effect on many countries and, in particular, on Australia.

PARA.TAB: I say it is ironic and timely because I have just returned from being a member of a delegation—of which I was deputy leader—which for the last 3 1/2 weeks has been in France and Europe, meeting with a wide range of people from Europe in government, civil service and industry, and discussing the very things that we are now discussing in this legislation. The visit to Europe was part of an annual visit by the Australian parliament, and I would like to say at the outset that what I learnt over there convinces me that it is vital that the Australian people are represented constantly in the European forums and that we maintain close contact with what is going on over there.

We are very well served by our representatives there, particularly by our ambassadors and their staff, but it is important that the parliamentary level maintain and increase its involvement as the European institutions develop. We met with the OECD, the Council of Europe, the European Union and the European Parliament. I am proud to say that I am wearing the new European Parliament tie that was issued last Thursday in Brussels and given to members of the delegation to wear.

I want to refer to some of the broader issues because I think they need to be seen in the context of this important legislation. The first thing is that I believe that the continuation of a union between major countries in Europe will be a permanent factor in the world. Whilst the countries that are members of the European Union will experience difficulties from time to time, they will remain a solid cohesive force. It is remarkable to observe how pragmatic the European nations are in that regard and also how other nations are making moves to join and enlarge the European Union. I think in a referendum held last weekend in Denmark the people voted in favour of joining the union.

From Australia's perspective, the fact is that in Europe there is already a powerful union which will become larger. That union, whilst it has other objectives and other responsibilities, is very much involved in developing and enhancing the economies of its members. I met with, and observed, people of all political beliefs—from the most extreme left socialists and communists to members of the extreme right—who had remarkably different views on many issues but who had a common pragmatic view about the need to become efficient and to build economies within their nations and the European Community that would enable them to maximise their opportunities for trade. The aim, of course, is to improve the standard of living of the people in the various countries and to expand the range of influence and the activities of those countries.

If we are students of history, as I am sure most members of parliament are, to observe Germany actively supporting the need to enlarge the European Parliament and the European Union by including more countries reveals a dramatic change from what the world was 50 years ago. I am quite convinced that the formation of the European Union is a good thing, because it will help deal with problems and, hopefully, avoid conflicts and wars.

On the subject of conflict, whilst it is not entirely relevant to this debate, it was chilling to hear of the number of people who may have lost their lives in the Bosnian conflict. It is now estimated to be more than one million people, a quite frightening figure. Is it not worth while supporting every effort by countries throughout the world to try to bring about partnerships and understanding?

I left Australia knowing that we had an unemployment figure of about 10 per cent as well as a current account deficit which is frightening and which, in my view, is almost out of control. I believe it requires federal government intervention and a mini-budget, but that has not been picked up yet by the government. I did notice one of the government's senior ministers, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), saying the other day that he thought certain steps could be taken to accelerate the reduction in the deficit and the debt by using certain projected revenues towards shortening the government's public position regarding the deficit.

In Europe the unemployment rates are often higher than ours. In France, for instance, the unemployment rate is 14 per cent, whilst in some other European countries the rate is 30 per cent and in parts of some countries 50 per cent. We also notice that the members of the European Union can become and remain members of the union only if they subscribe to targets to bring about, and maintain, certain economic performance levels. In order to achieve those targets, industry, investment and trade are required to expand. So deficits have to be reduced to certain levels by certain times.

It is in that context that I make those remarks. I have heard some members in the House yesterday and today express doubt as to whether the post-Uruguay agreements are going to be picked up by member nations such as the USA, Japan and, of course, our country. What I would like to say to them is that there is certainly going to be difficulty and delay and procrastination, as we are seeing in America at the moment because of the congressional elections.

It is my view that there is no doubt in the world that the post-Uruguay legislation will be adopted by those countries. For Australia to delay and not go through with what it needs to do to put in place the agreements in a legislative form is a nonsense. It is burying its head in the sand. It is almost prehistoric talk. It is not recognising the real world.

We have to go ahead and do the things that are necessary, such as the things that are contained in this legislation, in order to maintain the momentum. For Australia to do otherwise would only encourage those people in the American Congress who have been making political capital for their own selfish purposes in their own electorates without taking account of the national interest and the world interest.

I prefer to be pragmatic. The rounds of negotiations over the seven years have led to the Uruguay agreements. They will be implemented by countries and Australia should remain in the forefront, in the first ruck, and not fall back and be diverted from its course. Do not forget that the benefits from these negotiations over seven long, arduous years are due to the efforts of the negotiators on behalf of Australia and to the several ministers who represented Australia over that long period.

We will gain a very substantial benefit. For example, in agriculture, hundreds of millions of dollars of extra trade will be available to our farmers because of the agreements that have been made. Previously countries have said, `We won't let Australia export to us its clean food, even though it is the best in the world. When it lands on our wharves we are going to load the price with artificial costs in the form of tariffs so that their product will not be competitive with what is produced in our region.'

That has been going on for 50 years. In that time huge inefficiencies have developed. The deficits of countries have grown because governments have had to spend more than they have earned and they have borrowed to pay for the services that people have expected. There is this artificial environment of paying people to produce goods that cannot be sold and of allowing consumers to spend more to buy their everyday food products, thinking that that is the price they have to pay.

In fact, in an efficient environment where goods can be traded reasonably freely, everyone benefits because the consumer can buy at a better price. They have a wider choice. Those countries and economies that are involved in the post-Uruguay environments can see expansion within their own economies as their successful farmers, manufacturers and value added manufactures gain more share of the market overseas. Such an environment can give Australia enough income to start to pay off its horrendous foreign debt and to start to develop a trade surplus. That will stop the dangerous situation of Australia every month spending more than we are earning and our current account always being in deficit instead of being at least level or, preferably, in surplus.

From my perspective as a member of parliament representing a regional part of Australia in the Murray-Darling Basin, my area of Australia is the food bowl of Australia. It occupies one-seventh of the continent of Australia but it produces 40 per cent of Australia's total food production, all of it clean, all of it the best quality you can get, and all of it produced by farmers that are the best in the world. Manufacturers are adding value to the food that we produce and are winning exports, gaining valuable export dollars to help us tackle our current account deficit and trade deficit. In my electorate companies like Uncle Toby's, Uncle Ben's, Murray Goulburn, Haberfields, and wineries like Brown Brothers, Campbells and Gehrigs are now exporting every year in excess of $1,000 million worth of value added food products to competitive overseas markets. They are doing that in the face of huge barriers against them imposed by countries that have had a protective wall around them.

This legislation is part of the campaign that we have all worked hard for to break down barriers. They have not been completely broken down, as we would all prefer, but there has been a dramatic turnaround. Can honourable members imagine what farmers and manufacturers and small businesses in my electorate and others in Australia will be able to do in this improved environment? We will knock them dead, quite frankly, we will gain more market share for our products and we will improve the economy and standard of living for all Australians. In the process we will get jobs for Australians, particularly our young Australians, which is something we all want desperately. At the same time, this will enable countries which are part of this great process to reform and improve their own economies. By lowering their barriers they will become competitive and more efficient and build up the quality of life for their own people as well. So there is a great benefit for all of us in this process.

Having said all that and being optimistic, I have got my feet on the ground and I know damn well that the real test of Uruguay is going to be how the dispute clauses work in the agreements that I have seen. I am a lawyer and I had a look at some of them in the European Council and the European Parliament that deal with the implementation of these treaties that we have entered into. I can see how some countries and some lobby groups and vested interests in those countries will try to manipulate them and find ways around them. If it gets too hot, watch them lobby all the members in the European Parliament and in the Council of Europe to see if they can get a soft loan—which is a new way of describing a subsidy, although it is not called a subsidy—and circumvent the arrangements and agreements that have been fought for and negotiated.

So do not for one moment think that we have solved all the problems. We are just entering another stage now. But we have to be equipped. This legislation has to go through to enable us to tackle that next stage. That is why I said at the beginning of my speech that it is vital that members of the Australian parliament regularly be involved in visits to the European parliaments. The perspective which we gain from being there can be maximised and enable us to be watchful and alert and to take action when necessary to ensure that Australia's interests are protected and maintained.

Getting back to the local area, I have been disappointed that whilst we have made great progress in these negotiations over seven years the government, frankly, has not put in place the necessary adjustment programs to help those who experience the pain of change to cope. In my electorate and in the Queensland electorate of my friend the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) there are farmers who grow tobacco. The tragedy is that they are now seeking from the Commonwealth government the adjustment assistance that they have been desperately wanting and needing in order to make the change imposed on them by government, but it is all almost too late; in some cases it is too late. Last Wednesday and Thursday in Brussels members of the European Parliament told me that some of their own countries have been damn slow in giving assistance to their farmers who are experiencing pain in exiting the common agricultural markets that have existed there for years.

I support the amendment that the coalition is putting to this parliament, because it puts pressure back on the government. For example, this legislation deals with removing the provisions for the dairy industry, which is fine, but where are the government's proposals? It has known about it for years; it has known the agreements were entered into a few months ago. So where is the government's announcement about the adjustment schemes and assistance that are necessary so that the painful transitions for our farmers can be put into effect quickly? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard constantly and continuously, not only in this debate but over probably the last decade, about the joys and wonders of free trade. As a person who has had long experience of overseas trade, at least in the beef industry, I would like to know which country has this free trade arrangement. We are told it is a wonderful thing. If it is such a wonderful thing, how come no other countries in the world have anything remotely like it?

PARA.TAB: Until very recently, the Japanese would not allow any rice into their country. The chances of getting any great amounts of beef into the United States have been severely restricted. Canada and the United States threw some huge ex gratia tariffs upon the beef industry. We woke up one morning and found out that these had been imposed on a completely ex gratia basis. Our sugar is effectively not allowed into Europe. Our beef exports to Japan, Korea and the United States are restricted.

Those restrictions are progressively being lifted, particularly in Japan and Korea, but that was the situation that prevailed two years ago when I reviewed the international scene. Our sugar industry cannot get into Europe and cannot get into Thailand, two of our biggest trade competitors. Beef has restricted entry to almost every one of our trading partners. I am not familiar with the situation with wheat. No-one else appears to me to be free trading.

Under the GATT arrangements they will have to reduce their subsidies by about a third, which is a pretty fair generalisation. If we reduce ours to a third, they will vanish completely. It is the policy of both parties that tariffs be reduced to virtually nothing—except, I might add, in the fairly non-competitive TFC area. I do not want to condemn the retention of the 25 per cent tariff there, but the only area that remains protected is the area that is non-competitive. I do not think that is a very clever way to go about making a country competitive.

The previous speaker, the honourable member for Indi (Mr Lieberman), referred to his area as one of the great food bowls of Australia, which it most certainly is. However, we are constantly told by our Prime Minister (Mr Keating) that he is very proud that Australia is no longer what he describes as a sort of extended sheep run and quarry. His words drip with vituperative venom against the people who work in the mining industry and in agriculture in Australia. For a person who refers to his country as the backside of the world, it is unreasonable not to expect him to use that sort of language and to have that sort of hatred for the areas that are carrying this country on their backs.

Regrettably, we constantly hear of the huge volume of manufactured goods that are exported, and yet the only manufactured items that are exported are some very slightly upgraded agricultural and mining products. That is all that is exported in the field of manufacture, apart from the products which benefit from the round robin subsidy which exists in the motor car industry. I am not knocking Senator Button for his arrangements in that industry. They were very good. I applaud him for his $1,000 million dollar gift to BHP to restructure the steel industry. A lot of people think that was a bad thing. I think it was a good thing. It has been effective.

If we want our country to go ahead, we should concentrate on the only areas in which it is competitive: agriculture and mining. Only seven per cent of our exports are manufactured items. If anyone doubts that, I have a list from the ABS which itemises the exports. Aluminium is one of the items listed. That may be construed to be a manufactured item, but all I know is that if we are not mining it in Australia we most certainly will not be processing it in Australia. So some downstream processing of our minerals and agricultural products does occur.

People who do not know very much make some very stupid statements. They say that we should be processing our wool. They may go ahead, but all that will happen will be that the people who currently buy our wool will switch their mills to producing something else, because they will not compete against us as a manufacturer. The beauty of Australia is that we do not compete against them as a manufacturer. That is one of the reasons why it has paid for them to stay in wool, even though their countries do not produce wool but produce only woollen garments.

The subsidies are listed in the IPA Bulletin. I think that is a fairly reliable document. I am not telling honourable members anything that they do not already know. Agricultural subsidies are as follows: Switzerland, 80 per cent; Norway, close to 80 per cent; Finland, over 70 per cent; Sweden, 60 per cent. The European Community as a whole has average agricultural tariffs of 50 per cent. The OECD countries have average tariff levels of about 45 per cent.

Our tariff levels in Australia, with the exception of the car industry and the TFC industry, will very shortly be five per cent. Almost all our industries are already at that level. Whilst we are operating at that level, the people who have given us GATT say that this is a wonderful thing for us because, for example, in sugar we will not have to compete against a 180 per cent subsidy anymore. All we will have to compete against now will be a 120 per cent subsidy. Excuse us for not breaking out the champagne bottles.

Thailand has almost a 100 per cent subsidy for sugar. So now we will have to compete against only a 70 per cent subsidy. To compete against a 10 per cent subsidy in world trade is an enormous achievement. I am immensely proud of the fact that the honourable member for Dawson (Mr Braithwaite) and I represent the biggest sugar producing electorates. Very few human beings work in that industry. Huge behemoths process the sugar. One night I walked almost a kilometre through a sugarcane mill and saw no human beings. The mill was completely automated. Similarly, on the wharves these days there are very few human beings.

This industry is about as efficient as you will ever see any industry in the world operating because it is highly mechanised and the cost inputs are extremely low. So even though we have to go out there and compete against a 120 per cent subsidy thanks to the stupidity and the deplorable bargaining powers of this government—we are asked to do that—amazingly we seem to be able to at least tread water. Maybe we cannot move ahead, but at least we can tread water.

Unfortunately, when the drought ends in Thailand, that will not be a happy event for Australia's sugar industry. I will be getting up in this place and pleading for some sort of assistance for the sugar industry because we cannot compete against a 70 per cent subsidy. We simply cannot do that. But Thailand is in the wonderful position of being able to dramatically increase its production.

We are talking here about one of Australia's six or seven biggest export earning items. We are in a position in that industry to be able to expand. It is one of the areas we can expand in. They say, `GATT is a wonderful thing because now our beef will be able to go all over the world.' But people do not seem to understand the beef industry because, even though we have had expanding markets, our cattle numbers have not expanded. Quite frankly, as a generalisation, it is pretty hard to make a quid out of the beef industry and in the marginal areas there are simply no cattle at all.

We had a station north of Richmond and four of the neighbouring properties were owned by Americans who decided they would not have any cattle there at all. One of them said, `I am going to leave it there for my grandchildren.' But, in any event, if he had tried to make money out of running cattle there he probably could not have done so because it is a very marginal operation.

In Australia we had 32 million head of cattle back in the late 1970s. We now have about 22 or 23 million cattle. Our numbers are down 50 per cent and the reason why they are down is because you cannot make a quid out of growing cattle except in some amenable areas of Australia, and they are very limited areas.

If I turn to wool, there is no advantage there because there are hardly any barriers to our wool production. In any event our wool production has fallen 40 per cent thanks to the people in this place who abolished the minimum price scheme in the wool industry. I do not want to go sideways into that area. So it is not going to help beef and it is not going to help wool. I cannot speak with authority on wheat. To quote Harry Bonnano, the head of the sugarcane growers for Australia, there is going to be some mild improvement and there will be some mild advantages in the area of sugar. There is going to be some very small improvement in that area. As far as I am concerned, the advantages for beef are negligible because we simply will not be able to increase production to meet the expanding overseas markets. We are not doing that now. The same applies to wool.

So what sector is going to profit? It certainly makes no difference to the metals people. They have access to wherever they want now. So which export industry in Australia is this going to help? Why are we sacrificing the Australian citrus industry, the Australian tobacco industry and large sections of our dairying industry? Where is the advantage for Australia?

They said, `We have some reduction.' Yes, I must say that a 30 per cent reduction in the European subsidies is helpful, and with the subsidies in the United States there is a 30 per cent reduction. But when we consider sugar, one of our biggest export earning items, it simply brings sugar down to 120 per cent. So one can hardly break out the champagne bottles in celebration.

One of the most experienced people in the field of trade since the Second World War, outside of John McEwen, was Doug Anthony. I had the very great privilege of listening to him recently on the subject of GATT. He said that the advantage to Australia, if he was to quantify it, would be as a pea in a 44-gallon drum. He is a person who should know. Mr Malcolm Fraser spoke the same day addressing this large conference and he made much the same sort of statement.

The people in government on the other side of the House have been there for 10 years and have now achieved in the last two months the worst balance of payment figures in our history, bar 1990. So they would hardly be leading authorities on how Australia can move forward. In fact, they would be absolute proof of the monumental diasters that have taken place in the recent period of time. I do not think any intelligent person would be listening to them for advice. It is with deep regret that I say that nobody on our side of the House has any experience, so the sort of people that we should be listening to may be the likes of Fraser and Anthony—particularly Anthony, who was very active in the field of agriculture in the days of John McEwen when we had an aggressive trading policy.

I think every intelligent person is a free trader. I have never been against free trade—I have been an anti-tariff man all my life—but I certainly have never been one to advocate the sort of supine, pathetic and grovelling trade policies that have been the hallmark of this nation for the last decade. We are really talking about whether an aggressive trade policy or a pathetic grovelling trade policy is required.

Whilst I am not inclined to agree with John Maitland of the United Mineworkers Federation, there is a lot of logic in the fact that we are selling our coal for the prices we are selling it at because the Japanese and various other buyers play one seller off against another. That is the difference with an aggressive trading policy such as Japan has had. In coal we met a single buyer, as we did with sugar and beef for many years. So these countries have an enormously powerful trading arm, which I think most of the House is aware is called MITI, exactly the same nomenclature that McEwen used in his heyday.

I constantly hear McEwen maligned in this place, which rather fascinates me. Unfortunately for his detractors, history books are going to record that when John McEwen left this place we had a current account surplus. It is interesting, is it not, that we say `current account deficit' as one word because never in our period of public activity have we heard of anything but the current account deficit? However, when he left this place there was a current account surplus, unemployment was under two per cent, interest rates were under six per cent and inflation was around four per cent. We were the third wealthiest nation on earth when he left this place.

The figures of these great economic geniuses who have run Australia for the last decade have produced over the last two months the worst trading and balance of payment figures in Australian history, with the exception of those of 1990. It would be hard to beat the world records this government set in 1990, but I regret to say that over the next 12 months we will do just that. The real unemployment rate—and I am simply quoting from the book of the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore)—is around 16 per cent. One of the government's own colleagues has had the courage and integrity to stand up and say honestly that there is a 16 per cent unemployment rate in Australia. We have real interest rates of around 10 or 11 per cent, whilst the United States has six per cent. The last time I looked, Japan had 3.8 per cent and Germany had about four per cent.

So when I ask myself who is going to benefit from this—and I think that all of us should be asking who is going to benefit and who is going to lose—I fail to see what part of the Australian economy is going to gain. It is not possible to expand wheat production. We are an extremely dry country, and we cannot even keep up the wheat production we have had in past years. It is not possible to expand the sugar industry because we need water for irrigation and there are no dams being built in Australia. Because of the policies of this government there will not be any dams built in Australia. So agriculture cannot grow because there is no water. We live in an extremely dry land.

If the government decided to build a Bradfield scheme, a Clarence River diversion, there would be an ability to meet these overseas markets and some benefit for us in the GATT agreements that we have entered into. But that is not the policy of this government. Last month the $2.7 billion that went out of this country in excess of what came in must be a world record. But what is being done to address this problem of the manufacturing industries collapsing? In the tobacco industry, for example, 6000 jobs will go as a result of what is happening in this place today. Can somebody tell me where we are going to get the income replacement that is going to occur with these exports flowing into Australia since we have lowered the barriers of protection?

Finally, we are trying to compete in the field of mining and agriculture. The miners traditionally have to get people to go out to the areas where we mine: in Western Australia and North Queensland, in my own electorate. Those are the great mining areas of Australia, and they have extremely harsh environments. To get people to go out there, we have always given them very sizeable taxation benefits. To get companies to go out there, we have had to give them an enormous amount of fringe benefits. Those fringe benefits are now being taxed, so mining companies are simply not opening up new mines. The old mines have closed, and the cost structures which have been imposed by the centralised government of Canberra have not enabled the companies to expand.

We also have a situation where Aboriginal land rights legislation in this place and the push by the environmentalists for more and more national parks have made this a shrinking resource. Put that against the fact that we have got to compete in the international marketplace. Let us just look at the members of the European Community, because they are the biggest agricultural producers. They have agricultural tariff protection—to put it another and more accurate way, subsidy protection—of 50 per cent. They can reduce that by one-third, and they will still be coming in at subsidy levels in excess of 30 per cent. We have got pretty adequate prices at the present moment, and one would have thought there would have been a great expansion in our cattle numbers, but that is simply not occurring. When we add the subsidy and the cost structures which are imposed upon Australian agriculture, we can see why our cattle numbers are not increasing in Australia. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This cognate debate covers quite a substantial area but all associated with the World Trade Organisation amendments. I wish to address most of my comments to items 3 and 4 on the daily program, the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994 and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill 1994, which deal in particular with customs legislation in its various forms.

PARA.TAB: In so doing, I wish to make a couple of general remarks in association with that which could be called an extension of the tariff debate. The member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) has made some very penetrating comments in his remarks. He has my wholehearted support in questioning the productive capacity of Australia over the years, in terms of how we might address the massive debt that this country continues to accumulate overseas through its trade deficit, when our productive capacity is being put under pressure in so many areas. It is most successful in our export production—and I refer here to both agriculture and mining.

Agriculture is not only threatened by the seasons. It is being threatened—in the view of many, including, I believe, the Prime Minister—as to which areas of Australia might be farmed. I feel that it is going to be substantially further threatened by people in UN committees who will not be using but abusing the desertification treaty which this country is apparently committed to signing. They will be using it as a process of restricting our agricultural production. In other words, having won minor concessions at the GATT, we may find ourselves losing them through the United Nations conventions.

The coalition gives its support to this particular legislation—notwithstanding the fact that I propose two circulated amendments relating particularly to anti-dumping legislation associated with these measures—because, of course, notwithstanding our commitment to free trade, we are not prepared to support shonky trade. We see huge damage being done to our industries as we open the gates of our nation to imports from other countries—countries which might choose, through subsidy or other dumping actions, to destroy our local industry that might otherwise be competitive. I will refer to them after the second reading vote.

More importantly, in assuring the House of the coalition's support in these measures, I must remind honourable members that, over the last decade, many important economic reforms in Australia have been achieved by this government for one simple reason: the fact that this coalition put responsibility ahead of politics and supported the government in areas that were necessary. That is something that we do not see reciprocated when we, as a political party, stand before the Australian people and promote other measures which we believe are of similar benefit.

How easy it would have been, for instance—had we chosen to just put the pure art of politics as our sole reason for doing anything—for us to have prevented this government from selling the percentage it has sold of the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, a national icon. We could have gone out and opposed that move—something that philosophically we supported—and guaranteed that the government did not get the money it needed in the bank to assist it with its budgetary problems.

We have not on this occasion taken that opportunity, because we believe these measures are in the national interest. Compare that with the last election where, of course, political power was put before government responsibility when the coalition put the concept of Fightback before the Australian people. It was a concept which everybody, whatever their political or economic background, would say was the solution to many of the problems that will face Australian industry under this deregulated tariff regime.

It is an interesting fact that there has been significant debate about the citrus juice industry. At the time of the election, while visiting the citrus area, I reminded people that this country allows Brazil, its principal competitor in orange juice, to deliver to the doorstep of the two principal markets—the cities of Melbourne and Sydney—its product by the cheapest form of transport available anywhere in the world: international sea travel. I am reminded that grain growers in my electorate will have to pay $40 a tonne to send their product around the Australian coast to provide it to drought affected farmers on the east coast, whereas producers in the United States and Canada can do that for $27. That is how silly the situation is! We proposed to fix that, but of course we were hounded down with scaremongering.

More importantly, what are we doing to citrus growers this very day? We ask them to compete with their foreign competition while taxing them $2,000 a truckload per week—through fuel, sales and payroll taxes—to deliver into the same markets. It is pretty silly, but that is what is happening today. That is the side of this debate that is being ignored and in fact aggravated, as we well know, by the government increasing fuel taxes immediately after the election in which they promised an overall reduction of taxes.

This legislation is the result of international agreements under the GATT, and it is the first time in history that agriculture itself has been included in the general international trade agreement, now known as the World Trade Organisation. That is a significant advance. I am the first to recognise that the achievement is constrained in many ways and that as a consequence, as the member for Kennedy (Mr Katter) reminded us a minute ago, we have not yet achieved a lot. It has got to be said that it is a gigantic step that, for the first time ever, there are a few rules about agricultural trade—minimalist as they might be at this point in time. We can only hope for better.

Might I say as further comment that there are more difficulties in trade, of course, than simple tariff barriers. There are the non-tariff barriers that affect a lot of our potential exporters, and they include the local marketing and distribution regimes in various foreign countries and buyer loyalty. I visited Japan a couple of years ago in high dudgeon as a beef producer wanting to know why they would prevent me from starting a butcher shop in Japan. And they said, `Well, we won't. You're welcome. You can do it.' That raises a very interesting point. Why then is our beef product in Japan at a retail price 10 times higher than a consumer here in Australia would pay for it? It is clearly not the freight. It is the distribution system. It is the fact that too many people get a 10 per cent or whatever rake-off and the consumer loses. No-one can tell me that buyer loyalty will not be affected by price. I do not care what language people speak; when it comes to the language of money they know what cheap means.

Wool doonas are something which I have promoted in this parliament time and time again. They are double the Australian retail price if they are sold in Japan. You could carry them over one at a time in your luggage for cheaper than that. It is the system, and it is time this government looked very closely at whether we need some specialist wholesale resale facilities in Japan that might handle product from Australian producers, retail it at the right price and, when the retailer up the road complains about it, say, `Well, how much do you want? We don't want to put you out of business. We just want your consumers to know what the real price of this product should be.' Clearly we have the right to do it, and I think there needs to be some government involvement at least in setting these things up and maybe meeting the original rent or something.

I have got to watch the time, but I just wanted to make a point about what the federal Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) referred to in this debate when he said that there was absolutely nothing wrong with these sorts of agreements and highlighted how there is no opposition from the coalition on this issue of trade and the responsibility of the Commonwealth. That is for a very simple reason. Nobody has ever disputed since the constitution came into being that trade and defence were proper constitutional powers of the Commonwealth. The difference is that social engineering was not necessarily so. Of course, there are disproportionate influences emanating from various states in their voting power in this place. As a Western Australian I am not enamoured of the fact that New South Wales, with its particular views on certain subjects, gets 50-plus votes while the people of my state get 14 in this place. But, on the issue of trade and the issue of defence, we recognise the role and the right of the Commonwealth to enter, and that is exactly what the founding fathers believed and that was the limit of the power they granted.

I now want to refer specifically to the issues relating to the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. The customs legislation I have just referred to proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 to bring Australia into line with the Uruguay Round anti-dumping agreement and the subsidies and countervailing measures agreement. I repeat that we have two amendments that have been circulated in my name relating to the two bills. They both say the same thing. It is our intention to divide on them because we think it is very important in this anti-dumping area. The amendment says:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House urges the Government to:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)significantly reduce the inquiry period for anti-dumping and countervailing cases;

I stress that, particularly considering the size of many Australian producers, time is of the essence. You cannot have subsidised or otherwise dumped product floating around the supermarkets of Australia for any period of time and expect our smaller retailers and producers to survive. They cannot do it. That should be well known by this government, because it is the basic rule of the trade union movement: close a little guy down for a week with a strike and you have got him because he cannot afford to stay out of business. He will give in on the wages issue. The simple fact is that, unless genuine dumping cases are expedited and there are no delays, damage will be done and that damage is irretrievable. The amendment continues:

(2)ensure that the administration of the anti-dumping system and particularly the material injury provisions in the Act, is no more stringent than the comparable policies adopted by the other members of the World Trade Organization.

That `stringency' refers to the responsibility for those plaintiffs who complain about dumping to prove material injury. It is no good to make our people prove more than other countries around the world demand in their own states. We see dumping as the great danger for the tariff relaxation policy.

PARA.TAB: Whilst we support that policy, we see a danger in dumping. It could cruel many small enterprises within Australia and endanger the jobs associated with them. The government should take our plea very seriously. In fact, considering our actions earlier today, it is the government's turn to join us on this issue. It is a very simple issue. It is right. It should not be the subject of political posturing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Demonstrate a commitment.

—Demonstrate a commitment to protect people under this new regime. It is one of the most important things we need to do. A substantial number of matters relate to this. In particular, I draw to the attention of the House clause 15 of the bill, which proposes to amend section 269TB of the Customs Act to require that an anti-dumping application must be supported by producers who represent more than 50 per cent of the total production or output of that proportion of the industry that indicates its support or opposition to the application, and producers who represent not less than 25 per cent of the total production of goods in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Under the present law, the anti-dumping applications must be supported by producers who represent a major proportion of the total domestic output, but `major proportion' has never been precisely defined. This bill gives a very precise definition. Again, it includes pretty substantial figures. Perhaps one of the problems that industry will have in the short term will be raking up the level of support to get the appropriate applications before the appropriate authority. We warn the government that, if there are any other roadblocks, time extension may be the reason that certain industries collapse. So it is an important point.

There are other provisions such as, for instance, the determination of dumping margins. The most important amendments proposed in this bill would alter the methodology for determining whether or not dumping has occurred. Conceptually, dumping takes place when the export price of the goods concerned is less than the normal value of the goods, and material injury to an Australian industry producing like goods has been or is being caused or threatened, or the establishment of an Australian industry producing like goods has been or may be materially hindered.

Clause 10 of the bill clarifies the procedures for determining the normal value of a good. In some cases, the price of a good in its domestic market is not an appropriate measure for its normal value. For instance, the product might not even be sold on that domestic market. If such a situation exists, the value of the good is determined on the basis of its price in a third country—that is under this proposed legislation—or by assigning it a notional value. The bill sets out criteria for selecting an appropriate third country and details the factors that have to be taken into account in constructing a normal value. That is very positive.

The existence of dumping is currently determined by comparing the export price of a product with its normal value on a transaction by transaction basis. Clause 11 of the bill adds two new methods for determining the existence of dumping, namely, the comparison of the weighted average normal value of the goods with the weighted average of the prices of comparable export transactions, and the comparison of the normal value of specific goods to the weighted average of their export prices.

The introduction of weighted averages should impart a degree of flexibility that is not currently available and may simplify investigations in some cases. The existence of dumping and the size of the dumping margin would normally be calculated for individual exporters, but the bill would give the relevant minister the option of adopting sampling techniques if the number of exporters was very large. That, again, is positive.

Clause 12 proposes to amend the system for assessing the material injury to industry due to dumping or to subsidisation. Section 269TAE of the Customs Act lists a number of indicators that can be used to assess the injury. Clause 12 adds the size of the dumping margin, if relevant, or the particulars of the subsidy concerned, to the list. The bill also adds to the section a list of factors, such as contractions in demand, that may be considered as possible alternative causes for injury. Finally, the bill tightens the definition of a threatened injury by limiting it to foreseeable imminent threats.

As far as countervailing subsidies are concerned, the existing act does not precisely define a subsidy. Of course, quite clearly, it should. That is a deficiency that has led to litigation in the past. The bill proposes to enact a comprehensive framework for identifying the subsidies that can be countervailed. Proposed section 269TAAC defines a countervailing subsidy as a subsidy that is specific—that is, limited to the particular enterprise or geographic regions, or is contingent on export performance or the use of domestic goods over foreign goods—or as a subsidy that is not an excluded subsidy, that is, it is a subsidy provided for research, assistance to disadvantaged regions, or assistance for environmental regulation, or is a domestic agricultural support measure.

Unfortunately, we have to accept the phrase `or is a domestic agricultural support measure' because, as the honourable member for Kennedy pointed out, at this point in time we are not seeing those wiped out by any standard in other parts of the world. I might add that I do not totally share his concern that a 20 per cent or 10 per cent drop is not significant in some of those countries. Quite obviously, the level of subsidy at, say, 180 per cent is given because that is the margin that their governments believe is necessary to protect that industry. That is just inefficient. If the level of subsidy is whittled away, their ability to compete is immediately damaged, and so it should be. That is a matter of some concern to me, but I understand why it is there. In addition, the bill sets out guidelines for calculating the value of a subsidy, an issue that was not addressed in the 1979 code.

There are some other miscellaneous amendments which I will not deal with specifically. This government does a lot of boasting about its achievements, but practically none could have been achieved if the government had an opposition that had the one and only tactic of preventing good legislation. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr FREE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training)

TALK.START.PARA: —In closing the debate on these World Trade Organisation amendment bills, I would like to thank those honourable members who have taken part in the debate. The government, in particular, is pleased that the opposition recognises the substantial benefits of the outcome of the Uruguay Round negotiations for all sectors of the Australian economy and we are pleased with the expression of support for this which emerged during the debate. I should take this opportunity to respond briefly to a number of points that were raised during the debate on the legislation and also make some comment on the amendments that have been proposed.

PARA.TAB: A number of speakers raised the critical situation facing the citrus industry. I should emphasise, and the House should understand, that the bill before the House addresses only the action necessary for the Australian government to accept the World Trade Organisation agreement—that is, the elimination of discriminatory treatment of imports vis-a-vis local production. Nevertheless, the government recognises that the citrus industry is facing severe adjustment pressures as a result of very strong competition from Brazilian fruit juicers and the government has been consulting widely with the citrus industry on possible adjustment assistant measures.

I must emphasise, however, that the government has already implemented a number of measures to assist citrus industry adjustment, including a grant to promote sales of fresh orange juice. Government contributions to citrus industry research amounted to $770,000 in 1993-94. There has been a contribution to a fruit fly eradication strategy and continued support for the Australian Horticultural Corporation. With regard to concerns expressed about the manner in which anti-dumping and countervailing legislation is administered, officials are required to carry out the law. The arrangements under the World Trade Organisation agreements involving greater prescription in the conduct of anti-dumping and countervailing investigations should reduce concerns over administrative discretion.

A further point raised during the debate concerns the thrust of the Eminent Persons Group to report to APEC. In this regard, I can stress that this report is one of a number of inputs into the forthcoming second APEC leaders meeting at Bogor in November. While Australia's objective is to secure a commitment to the long-term goal of free trade in the region, APEC will continue to strengthen the multilateral trade regime and will be fully consistent with GATT and the new World Trade Organisation.

I now turn to the amendments foreshadowed by the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to the Customs Legislation (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill and the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. I indicate that the government will not be accepting the amendments. Similar issues regarding the time frame and administration of Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing regime have been raised on previous occasions.

This debate is not about general policy amendments. The proposed amendments are focused solely on implementing the minimum requirements to conform with the provisions of the World Trade Organisation agreements. The first paragraph of the amendment of the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping)(World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill calls for a significant reduction in the inquiry period for anti-dumping and countervailing cases. In recent years the government has imposed time limits on the administrative conduct of anti-dumping investigations and has significantly reduced these to levels which are considered to be the minimum possible to ensure that a fair and transparent system is maintained. Australia's anti-dumping time frames remain among the shortest in the world. Any further reductions in time limits could adversely impact on Australia's ability to meet the transparency and reporting obligations to the World Trade Organisation agreements.

The second paragraph of the amendment urges the government to ensure that the administration of the anti-dumping system is no more stringent than the comparable policies adopted by other members of the World Trade Organisation. I point out to the House that Australia's administration of anti-dumping provisions will be consistent with the requirements of the bill under consideration. Those countries signing onto the World Trade Organisation which have, or are introducing, anti-dumping regimes, must, like Australia, conform with the requirements of the World Trade Organisation agreements.

Each implementing country will interpret the anti-dumping provisions of the World Trade Organisation in the context of its own domestic policy framework. Australia does not have any control over this except to the extent that the government would seek to ensure that the anti-dumping legislation of other countries conforms to the obligations spelled out in the World Trade Organisation agreements. These comments apply equally to the administration of material injury provisions and other aspects of the Australian organisation.

Finally, I turn to the amendment proposed by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott) to the Dairy Produce (World Trade Organization Amendments) Bill. This amendment really demonstrates just how out of touch those opposite are with a constituency which they claim as their own. The honourable member for Maranoa ought to know better. While he claims to be gravely concerned about this issue in his amendment, we on the government side are working through the issue with the dairy industry. The re-instrumentation of this supported arrangement is a complex issue and it has involved extensive consultation between the industry and the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

It gives me great pleasure to present to the House the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill, which establishes a new labelling scheme for goods that make a claim to being Australian. The bill gives Australian consumers a reliable labelling scheme that will help them to identify Australian products and help Australian industry to promote Australian products and to create Australian jobs.

PARA.TAB: To date, the situation with Australian labelling has caused difficulty and confusion for industry and consumers alike. Consumers, at a time when they are being encouraged to buy Australian goods, are not confident that labels stating or implying Australian origin can be relied on.

The bill takes two terms, `Product/Produce of Australia' and `Made in Australia' and defines them. These are the only authorised terms that will be used in the future to identify Australian goods. Alternative terms with uncertain meanings, such as `processed in Australia' or `manufactured in Australia' will not be permitted. If a good does not meet the requirements to be labelled with either of these two authorised terms, but some processing took place in Australia, a label can be used which identifies the particular production step which occurred here, but it must also state the source of the ingredients or components.

Australian industry will benefit from having informed consumers making purchasing choices based on reliable information. It will also benefit from having standard origin terms which will enable it to promote the Australianness of its products.

As honourable members will be aware, this bill was referred by me to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. I agreed to that referral because the opposition expressed concern about some aspects of the bill's implementation, and it has been my policy during the two years that we have been developing this scheme to consult, to talk, to explain and, increasingly, to correct misleading information that has been widely put about.

The committee reported on 6 June. It focused almost exclusively on the provision in the bill which defines the two major terms. It accepted that the terms `Product/Produce of Australia' and `Made in Australia', with the meanings ascribed to them in the bill, are the most practical and appropriate labels for this purpose. However, the committee was concerned about the implementation of this provision and has recommended that I make a statement to the House on a number of matters. I will deal with all of them later in this speech. The bill has also been considered by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. The majority of that committee recommended that the bill be passed with the amendments proposed by the government.

The bill covers the supply of consumer goods to Australian consumers in Australia. It does not contain a list of goods which must be labelled; rather the rules in the bill apply when a supplier, manufacturer or importer chooses to make some claim about the Australian content of his or her goods or is obliged to do so by some other legislation.

The most important aspect of the bill is that it gives consumers and industry clear terms to identify Australian goods. The terms `Product of Australia' and `Produce of Australia' mean the same thing and are interchangeable. They mean that each major component or ingredient came from Australia and that any processing which took place happened in Australia. This is the label for all-Australian goods. It meets the consumer wish to know when goods are made in Australia from Australian components or ingredients.

The label `Made in Australia' means what it says—that the goods were made here. It recognises that for many products we have to import some or all of the components but that Australian industry and Australian workers transform those components into a new product. The test for this label in the bill is that the goods must have acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia. This test reflects the current law on the meaning of `Made in Australia' as established by the Federal Court. It is the meaning understood and accepted by industry generally. By retaining this meaning, the bill reduces the impact and cost on industry.

These are the only terms authorised by the bill. The message is then clear and simple for consumers: if the label says `Product/Produce of Australia', it is all-Australian; if it says `Made in Australia', it was made here by Australian workers. It was not merely assembled but made into what it is.

Lobby groups concerned about the labelling of food have proposed amendments to the bill to make `Made in Australia' mean all-Australian. It is important to remember that this bill is not just about food; it covers all consumer goods and must be appropriate for them all. This proposal would mean that all those goods which are currently lawfully labelled `Made in Australia' would have to be relabelled to something like `Manufactured in Australia from Australian and imported components'. This would be very costly for industry and consumers. It would penalise Australian industry both in the local market and in the export market and would result in the export of jobs. The government rejects this proposal. If further information is thought necessary for food, then the argument should be put to the National Food Authority.

The bill's other three labelling requirements all remedy situations where consumers are given partial and currently potentially misleading information. For example, a label might identify a particular production step which occurred in Australia, like `Assembled in Australia' or `Finished and packed in Sydney'. In these cases the bill requires that a statement be made about the source of the ingredients or components for the goods. So labels in future will read `Assembled in Australia from imported components' or `Finished and packed in Sydney from imported and Australian materials'.

Where a supplier says that goods were `Designed in Australia', then the place of origin of the goods must also be identified by saying they were also `Made in Australia', by identifying particular production steps which happened in Australia or by saying that the goods were made outside Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 3.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted in accordance with standing order 101A. The debate may be resumed at a later hour. The minister will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

—Mr Speaker, with your indulgence, as some members of the House would be aware, an Ansett 747-300 aircraft landed at Sydney airport this morning with its front wheel not fully extended. After that crash landing, I spoke to Ansett's chief executive, Graeme McMahon, who advised me that the aircraft took off from Sydney airport this morning en route to Japan. The aircraft apparently experienced a decrease in engine power and the pilot decided to return to Sydney airport. On landing, the nose wheel of the aircraft was not fully extended resulting in the aircraft landing with its nose down.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that there are no reports of casualties or serious injuries amongst the 253 passengers on board. Passengers were transferred from the aircraft back to the international terminal. The Civil Aviation Authority and the Federal Airports Corporation are taking action to minimise the disruption to the airport's operations.

I have spoken to Mr Pike, the acting director of the air safety directorate, and can advise the House that both his staff and the staff of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation have commenced investigations into this accident. I know that all members of this House will join me in giving thanks that all of the aircraft's passengers and crew are safe.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will briefly add to the minister's remarks to say, on behalf of the coalition, that we are particularly pleased that no-one was seriously injured in this incident. I am sure that is a great tribute to the professionalism of the crew of the aircraft, the pilot in particular. We hope that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) will expedite any investigations into the background to this accident.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Is it not the point of having a judicial inquiry to inquire into all aspects of civil aviation in the recent past to ensure that actions taken or not taken and decisions made or not made are examined so that lives are not lost in the future? Given that, why is Sir Laurence Street not examining the actions of the chief decision maker, the main person responsible, the Minister for Transport? Is it not a fact that, unless there is a full inquiry with broader terms of reference, the real problems could remain covered up and more Australians could lose their lives? Is it a fact that you, Minister, have said we have nothing to fear, but Australians who fly have many genuine fears?

—The honourable member well knows, as does this House, that there are many avenues available and on foot at this very moment for the scrutiny of the affairs of aircraft safety, the Civil Aviation Authority and me. There is, after all, the parliamentary inquiry that I announced on 20 July this year; the parliamentary inquiry which was so warmly welcomed by my opposite number, the member for Hume. It does not begin and end with the parliamentary—
—You set up the Street inquiry yourself.

—That parliamentary inquiry just happened to be the parliamentary inquiry that the opposition called for. The opposition asked and asked and asked and received that inquiry, which is under way and there have been several hundred submissions to it.

PARA.TAB: But, of course, that is not the only avenue. In respect of allegations of improper or criminal behaviour, an Australian Federal Police investigation of the Civil Aviation Authority is under way. In addition, we now have a new Director of Aviation Safety at the CAA, Mr John Pike, and we also have the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which just happens to be the very same body that uncovered the difficulties with the Civil Aviation Authority arising from the Monarch accident which was responded to so comprehensively by me on 20 July this year.

It does not end there. In addition, the judicial inquiry into the handling by the Civil Aviation Authority of all aspects of Seaview Air's operations was announced this week. As I have said before, there is a plethora of opportunities for investigation, for scrutiny, and I think that each and every one of them should be available and is available. Anyone who has any information should come forward and use one or other or all of those opportunities.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the chairman and members of the Select Committee on Finance and General Affairs of the parliament of Ireland. On behalf of the House, I extend a very warm welcome to our visitors.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Attorney-General seen proposals that the constitution be amended to restrict the use of the external affairs power and a suggestion that the external affairs power should, in fact, never be used? Is it intended that those proposals be adopted by the government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My attention has been drawn to an article by Lenore Taylor which appears in today's Australian which refers to resolutions which are apparently up for debate at the 50th birthday federal conference of the Liberal Party to be held in Albury in two weeks. The article states:

PARA.TAB: The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Downer, is coming under strong pressure to promise that a Coalition government would never exercise powers available to the Federal Government through the constitutional external affairs powers.

ANSWER.PARA: The article goes on to state:

PARA.TAB: Three states have strongly-worded motions on the agenda at Albury urging action to limit the external affairs power, in the case of Western Australia and South Australia through a referendum to remove the power from the Constitution.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not know whether the newspaper report is accurate about the actual resolutions but, if those resolutions are accurate and if such matters were put in place, they would have far-reaching implications on a whole range of very essential legislation which is currently in place.

PARA.TAB: The parliament should understand that one of the reasons for federation was that the Australian colonies as one nation would speak internationally with one voice and that one government should be responsible for external affairs and Australia's international obligations. That is obviously why that power was given to the Commonwealth. If that power, as apparently suggested by the state branches of the Liberal Party, were to be revoked, a whole range of legislation which is based on the external affairs power would, of course, no longer be relevant.

This would include legislation put forward by previous Liberal governments, such as the Antarctic Marine Living Resources Conservation Act 1991 or the Wildlife Protection (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act 1982. Essentially, all the Commonwealth's human rights legislation, such as the Sex Discrimination Act and the Disability Discrimination Act, would be without constitutional foundation. Recently we have had a debate in this place about another piece of legislation which is based on the external affairs power—that is, the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill, which was recently passed by this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order No. 145, a hypothetical question obviously would be ruled out of order by you.
