—There is no point of order because the question asked the Attorney-General about a specific matter. I call the Attorney-General.

—In the recent debate before this chamber, I think the opposition was unfairly accused of being homophobic in some of its responses. That is unfair criticism in my view. But what I think is not unfair is the claim that the opposition is xenophobic—that is, that they have absolutely no comprehension, no idea whatsoever of Australia's place in the world, and run away from Australia's place in the world.

PARA.TAB: What we need is some strong leadership from the Leader of the Opposition on this point, not like the leadership that we have seen displayed in relation to that most recent example of legislation based on the external affairs power, where the Leader of the Opposition, when explaining the opposition's position—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Attorney-General, I believe, is now reviving debate in this place on a matter which has been concluded. Might I suggest that in the conclusion to his answer he come to the substance of it.

—The point I will conclude on is that what we need is to get a clearer understanding of the importance of the external affairs power. What we do not need are inane resolutions coming from the Liberal Party about revoking the power. What we also need is some proper leadership on the issue from the Leader of the Opposition. I will conclude on this point—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney is concluding.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, no, he is. Believe me, he is.

ANSWER.PARA: There is all sorts of speculation that we are divided, that people would cross the floor on this issue. Well, on the contrary. I managed to put together a proposition that was acceptable to the party. I did, through the established mechanisms of the party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I take a point of order. This is an outrageous—
—The member for Flinders, I think he might have—
—Well, if he has concluded, then it is not before time but it was a deliberate defiance of the chair and you should have pulled him up earlier.
—I do not need the member for Flinders to give advice of that nature. The Attorney has concluded.

—Is the Minister for Transport aware of a press report that he had conceded to a number of journalists following the Seaview Air crash that he had paid insufficient attention to reports of problems in the CAA and that there was something terribly wrong with the administration of aviation safety in Australia? Did he also say that he had been too busy with other issues to deal with the problem? Are these reports correct and, if so, given that they confirm the minister's dereliction of duty as a minister, will he now resign, having condemned himself with his own words?

—What a devastating attack from the member for Hume! This just happens to be the matter of public importance which the honourable member has given notice of for discussion later on this afternoon. The assertion that is made is one that I categorically reject. You will have your chance to debate it later on this afternoon.

—I refer the Minister for Justice to the passage through the House today of the Human Rights (Sexual Conduct) Bill 1994. Can the minister please advise what are the implications of the development for state criminal law and will the minister be seeking any further discussion with the Tasmanian Attorney-General consequent on the passage of this bill?

—I take a point of order, Mr Speaker. In accordance with both the convention laid down in Parliamentary Practice and also the standing orders, this legislation having been dealt with this day, it is not permissible for that question to be answered by the minister. The question is out of order as it is framed.
—On that point of order: the matter has been dealt with. It is no longer before the House.
—It's before the parliament.

—No, before the parliament is not relevant. The question is whether it is before the House. The matters that are before the Senate may be considered and debated and discussed in this chamber in question time or any other time. The question is whether it is a matter still to be debated by the House. It is not, Mr Speaker.

—Mr Speaker, I draw your attention to standing order 144, which lays down the criteria for the asking of questions. It forbids the request for a legal opinion, and it was clearly one because it referred to effects on state governments. As such it would be a legal opinion.

—Order! Each of the honourable members who have raised the points of order here I think would agree that the question itself, as I have already cautioned the Attorney-General, should not revive debate in this place. I would suggest to the Minister for Justice that in his response that be the case. But the question did go to another matter and therefore the question is in order but with, of course, that warning.

—I certainly thank the honourable member for her question. This bill, assuming its passage through the Senate, will render inoperative sections 122 and 123 of the Tasmanian criminal code, the offensive and discriminatory provisions which make criminals of homosexual men in Tasmania. I take this opportunity to say how enormously pleased I am and how much honour I think it did this House that, just a short time ago, 114 members of this chamber stood up for the human rights of those Tasmanians, the right to privacy, and voted in favour of the bill. The fact that 114 members supported this bill does do honour to this House and shows that the Tasmanian government is completely out of step with mainstream views on this issue. Today's vote was a rejection of the intolerance of the League of Rights and organisations born of intolerance—
—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: whilst I have no truck with the League of Rights—

PARA.TAB: Honourable members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the National Party is not being helped by those down the far end on both sides. I have cautioned members of this place this week about that.

—Whilst I have no truck with the League of Rights—I accept that there can be passing reference, clearly, to the result of the debate, the bill now having been determined on the floor of this chamber—I do suggest that you remind the minister of your admonition already issued and remind him that he is now straying beyond that.
—I think the minister knows of that and if he does, I will pull him up.
—He is wasting the time of this House.
—Let me be the judge of that.

—I believe the vote today was a rejection of homophobic groups such as the League of Rights and organisations such as Tas Alert and the Homophobic Activist Liberation Organisation. Clearly, while such groups have a right in a democratic society to exist, it is important that we reject the poison they disseminate.

PARA.TAB: As we know, as a result of today's vote one opposition frontbencher has resigned from the opposition front bench. Caught between his espousal of intolerance and the principles this House has upheld, he has been put in a difficult position. The Tasmanian government itself has to address the very issues that this House has spoken so clearly on. The Tasmanian government still stands condemned by the fact that it refuses to take its own action to repeal legislation that is so overwhelmingly rejected by members of this House.

In this House we saw the view of Australians expressed with the democratically elected House of an Australian Parliament passing the bill with a vote of 114 to four, with eight people scurrying out the door and two preferring not to turn up at all. Overwhelmingly, this House has something to be proud of. It may have left the leadership of the Leader of the Opposition in tatters, but this House has much to be proud of.

The important point is that I will now be going back to the Tasmanian Attorney-General and to the Tasmanian premier. I will be asking the Tasmanian government to reconsider its ill-judged opposition to what plainly is the dominant political view of Australia. It is the view of the Liberal Party of Australia, as expressed by its leadership, and it is the view, I believe, of the overwhelming number of tolerant members of the Australian community.

There ought be no place on the front bench of any major political party for intolerance. There ought be no place in state parliaments for laws which incriminate men because they choose to express their sexual preference in ways which are not those of the greater majority of our fellow citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question—

PARA.TAB: Mr Howard interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Bennelong. The Leader of the Opposition has the call.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Transport. I preface this question by noting that the Royal Australian Air Force has permanently grounded its Nomad aircraft. Can the minister confirm that the army has now done the same thing? Is it not a fact that, following the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation report into the Nomad crash in South Australia, another fault has been found with this aircraft? Can the minister confirm that the 17 Nomads on the civil register are still flying and carrying passengers under new speed and flap restrictions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will obtain from the authorities the detailed answers—
—You don't know.
—Order! The question has been asked. The minister will respond.

—As a matter of fact, I have not flown in a Nomad and I have not looked up one's exhaust pipe, but I will get the relevant information and answer the Leader of the Opposition. I would like to give an account of what I do know about Nomads. On 6 July this year, the Commonwealth and Defence Force Ombudsman wrote to me in respect of her findings in the investigation of the adequacy of the RAAF's response to the loss of Nomad A18401—the final report. A copy of that correspondence was sent simultaneously to the Chairman of the Board of the Civil Aviation Authority as well as to my colleague the Minister for Defence and numerous other people.

PARA.TAB: It was a serious and definitive report into inadequacies. It resulted in my not only taking the matter up personally with the Civil Aviation Authority but also writing to General Peter Gration, the Chairman of the Civil Aviation Authority, on 19 July. In that correspondence I addressed a number of issues dealing with not only Nomad but also funding for aviation safety regulation, the strengthening of the aviation safety agency, the management of the aviation safety regulations, increases in aviation passenger carriers' liability and the Commonwealth's indemnification of the CAA's safety regulation responsibilities. I also dealt with the financial viability of operators and commuter and general aviation safety. I advised General Gration of my concern and my decision to establish the parliamentary inquiry—the one called for by the member for Hume.

I am very pleased to table a copy of that detailed correspondence. It was replied to by General Peter Gration. Members opposite do not particularly like this stuff because it is an indication of the work that has been done on the very question of Nomad. Peter Gration wrote back to me on 30 August. In a detailed response to my correspondence of 19 July, he enclosed a copy of his own letter to Ms Philippa Smith, the Defence Force Ombudsman, which in part says:

ANSWER.PARA: Dear Ms Smith,
Thank you for your letter of 6 July enclosing the copy of the final report.

The authority accepted the findings of the report, with some qualifications as to the findings about the resting on the assumption of a satisfactory explanation of the plane tail cracking being available from Aerospace Technologies of Australia—
that is, ASTA—
in time to prevent the accident.
General Gration went on to say:
The authority accepts the three recommendations relevant to its operations and will proceed to implement them.

I am quite happy to table a copy of that correspondence as well. To my knowledge, that is the correspondence in respect of Nomad but I will get some detailed advice as to the individual claims mentioned in the member's question this afternoon.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is the Attorney aware of proposals that the Commonwealth could use the external affairs powers to legislate for a republic without going to the people in a referendum? Is such a course available to the government and, if so, does it intend to follow it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Lavarch The Hon M.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only is it state branches of the Liberal Party that are preoccupied at the moment with the external affairs power; apparently it is also a matter of discussion before the coalition legal and constitutional affairs committee. I have a memo for that committee prepared by the member for Warringah, which has been kindly handed to me. In that memo the member argues:

ANSWER.PARA: Strictly speaking, under the current interpretation, a bona fide treaty with Indonesia on the importance of republicanism in securing better relations would allow the federal government to legislate for a republic.
In fairness to the member, he then goes on to say:
Of course, no conceivable High Court would allow this to happen.

It is not a question of the very apparent limitations in the external affairs power not allowing something like this to occur. The only way in which Australia can become a republic is through the popular will of the Australian people expressed through a referendum pursuant to section 128 of the constitution.

PARA.TAB: It is absolutely paranoia gone mad, in terms of the republican debate and the external affairs power, to think that a head of power in the constitution can be used as a mechanism to override or change the constitution. It is a classic case of the stream rising to a higher level than the source. It simply cannot be.

I can assure the honourable member for Calare and also those other misguided members who may have to rely on the advice of the honourable member for Warringah in considering limitations to the external affairs power that the external affairs power cannot be used to bring about a republic. That could only be achieved by using section 128. I hope we get some proper and informed debate on the use of this power and some proper leadership from the Leader of the Opposition to bring his party into line a little more successfully than he has managed to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say a few things about the Tarago crash. It is a pretty serious matter. Just as I shared personal friendships with some of the people killed in the Monarch accident, the same can be said, on my part, for at least three of the young people who were killed in this accident—an accident that was the subject of a report by the New South Wales coroner, Peter Gould. Six people were killed on 19 June 1992. The findings of Mr Gould's report, handed down yesterday, fully support the findings already released to the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. The coroner found that, on the balance of probabilities, the plane crashed because a passenger moved baggage or a passenger moved during flight immediately before the final descent in an aircraft carrying excessive luggage. The coroner also stated in his findings:

ANSWER.PARA: It is difficult to envisage how the authorities can prevent such a deliberate breach of safety regulations other than by more ramp checks.

The Civil Aviation Authority has already instituted a program of increased surveillance of the industry; indeed, the most rigorous and detailed checking that the industry has ever experienced is currently under way. To bear that out, it is perhaps appropriate that I advise the House of the first of the reports I have received from Mr Pike, the new head of Air Safety. He is the gentleman whom I appointed to take Mr Macionis's place. He reported to me on 18 October in the following terms:
To implement arrangements for increased surveillance of low capacity regular public transport and charter operators—
and this aircraft was a charter operator—

the following actions have been taken: some 130 specialists in the flying operations and airworthiness areas have been assigned to the project. In addition, a dedicated team of four specialists has been selected for each of the three regions of the CAA. Their role would be to travel to locations outside their home regions to check the consistency of surveillance standards being applied across Australia. Each team will consist of two airworthiness and two flight operations inspectors. Appropriate administrative support staff are being provided to the surveillance teams. Some of the areas in which the teams will focus are ramp checks, maintenance arrangements, operating manuals and other documents. The project is expected to run for two months and will subject these sectors of the aviation industry to the most rigorous and detailed checking they have ever experienced.

I think that is absolutely appropriate. If there is any inadequacy in this approach, it is for the parliamentary committee, on which the honourable member serves, to pay some attention and to report to this parliament. I think that is a far more appropriate way of dealing with this sad tragedy than involving the Street judicial inquiry into a revisit of this Tarago accident, which has already been reported upon by BASI and the coroner. But if there is any appropriate action required arising from the review of the parliamentary investigation in this area, I will be very pleased to take all appropriate steps.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs. I refer to a report that the minister met recently with Ms Berhane Ras-Work to discuss her work in Africa to eliminate the practice of female genital mutilation. Can the minister inform the House of the outcome, if any, of that meeting?

—I thank the honourable member for his question, which I know touches on a matter of concern to many members on both sides of the House. I met Ms Berhane Ras-Work, a remarkable Ethiopian woman, last Thursday. She was on her way back to her office in Geneva from attending the very successful conference on Women, Power and Politics in Australia at which she attracted a good deal of attention for her remarks and for her work on eradicating the practice of female genital mutilation.

PARA.TAB: She is the president of the Inter-African Committee on Traditional Practices Affecting the Health of Women and Children—a non-governmental organisation which works through some 24 national committees, mainly in Africa. The objectives of the committee are to eliminate harmful traditional practices and to promote beneficial ones. Amongst those harmful practices are female genital mutilation as well as early childhood marriages and nutritional taboos. The committee encourages better nutrition, breastfeeding, child spacing, safe delivery and better child rearing practices.

Female genital mutilation and early childhood marriage leave women with lifelong disabilities and lifelong pain. They contribute to a high incidence of maternal mortality in the countries where they are practised. It was a practice which was roundly condemned at the UN Conference on Population and Development in Cairo—where I went recently—as a violation of basic human rights and as being a major lifelong risk to women's health.

During our conversation, and in specific answer to the honourable member, I was pleased to be able to offer $20,000 to Ms Ras-Work's committee to support her work, which concentrates on the education of women. That was in addition to some $24,000 which Australia recently provided through the International Women's Development Agency for a project in Tanzania, which aims to educate community members in some 40 villages about the practice of female genital mutilation.

That is in addition to some $240,000 which Australia has provided to the fistula hospital in Addis Ababa which is run by a couple of remarkable Australians, Doctor Reg and Doctor Catherine Hamlin. Doctor Reg Hamlin died some time ago and that work is now being carried on by his septuagenarian surgeon wife. She is a remarkable person, as those members of the House who have met her know. The fistulas that are treated by that hospital are often caused by difficult and protracted childbirth, and female genital mutilation is a contributor to their incidence as well.

I conclude by saying that education is the key to change in this area. One of the priorities in the aid budget next year will be the education of women and girls. Within Australia—I notice the progressive Attorney-General listening carefully to this answer—education of and consultation with the affected communities is a very important component of the government's approach to the eradication of female genital mutilation. In that regard, Ms Ras-Work was at pains to advise me that her committee was in favour of legislation in appropriate circumstances and thus is supportive of the approach which the Attorney-General is considering taking in Australia to eliminate what is to most Australians an abhorrent practice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is also addressed to the Minister for Transport. I refer the minister to his earlier reply to the question of the Leader of the Opposition relating to the Nomad aircraft in which he said that he had sought views from the CAA on 19 July. Is the minister aware that, as a result of a major inflight incident in the West Indies involving a Nomad aircraft in only the last few weeks, further operational constraints have been imposed on the operation of this aircraft type? Can the minister assure the House that these aircraft are safe for continuing military and civil operations? Will he seek further urgent advice from the CAA?
—I certainly will obtain from the experts in the authority advice relating to the matters raised by the honourable member, and will inform him and the House of the response at the earliest date.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of a proposal that Australia should adopt the social security arrangements of some Asian countries? In view of the fact that this government has already been able to maintain and improve a social security structure which is the envy of the world, could the minister advise the House, and in the process the national community, what the implications of such a proposal would be?

—On Monday I drew the attention of honourable members to the rather startling views expressed by the Leader of the National Party on social security matters. Since the honourable member has not, to the best of my knowledge, either denied having uttered those words—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. In fact I took a personal explanation. I have also written to the Wagga Daily Advertiser, so I inform you directly that I have denied that.

—It is rather interesting that several weeks have elapsed since that article appeared and it is only after the matters were raised in parliament that the Leader of the National Party sees fit to make any sort of denial. I find that rather remarkable.

—Mr Speaker, on a further point of order: I draw your attention to your admonitions to this place about behaviour of the members. If you are going to tolerate this slimy little character going on after what he has been told, this place will end up in such a row you will hear nothing.
—The member for O'Connor will resume his seat. There is no point of order. The language used by the member for O'Connor could be found to be offensive.

—I reiterate the point that not only was this statement reported but also a couple of days later it was taken up in an editorial in the same publication. Despite both of those occasions, apparently it is only now as a result of the matter being raised in the parliament that the Leader of the National Party sees fit to make that refutation.
—Last time you raised it you couldn't get it up.
—I warn the member for O'Connor!
—Since Monday, when the matter came up, I thought it quite interesting to do a bit of research on developments in social security in Thailand. It is quite interesting.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.

—Order! I think I understand the point of order that the honourable member for Bennelong is going to raise. Minister, you have been asked a question. I ask you now to come to the substance of your answer without going over the same ground.
—I was just about to do so. I was about to make some observations about the directions in social security in Thailand. The interesting thing about it—
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order.
—Order! The minister might resume his seat. I obviously wrongly anticipated the member's point of order.

—Under the standing orders of this House, reflections on the integrity of members in answers are clearly unacceptable. The minister made an accusation about the Leader of the National Party. That accusation was explicitly repudiated. The minister was reminded of that repudiation a few moments ago. It is here in Hansard. Yet in defiance of that the minister still rabbits on misrepresenting the position of the Leader of the National Party. Mr Speaker, you ought to sit him down.
—The minister has already been reminded about coming to the substance of his answer. He is doing that, and I will be the judge of the issue.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Under standing order 142, questions may be put to a minister relating to public affairs with which he is officially connected. The minister has no connection with social security in Thailand, so he should be sat down immediately.
—No. If the honourable member would care to look up the Hansard of last year when I indicated that a minister may talk about overseas countries as examples, he will find an answer.

—I was about to say, if I can get a word in edgeways in this whole thing, that Thailand is in the process of moving towards the adoption of a comprehensive system of social security. And guess what? Next year it is bringing in a retirement income system which is based on compulsory employee and employer contributions to approved funds—just like our superannuation arrangements. Is it not interesting that that country is one in which key features of the retirement income system will be quite similar to ours.

PARA.TAB: As I said on Monday, the World Bank has described our retirement income arrangements—which, as I said, consist of two main legs: a targeted pension system and incentives to encourage the spread of superannuation—and they are now held up by the World Bank as a model for a system which can be sustainable and affordable in the long-term, as well as being an effective preventative structure to avoid poverty of people in old age.

Throughout the world we are seeing a degree of convergence in the basic features of the social security system. In a number of European countries which have had so-called universal structures based overwhelmingly on contributory arrangements, there is a growing recognition that long-term fiscal sustainability of those systems—
Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, there is a squawking noise being emitted from over there somewhere. I wonder whether I could get a bit of peace and quiet.
—If the minister continues his answer, I am sure he will find that he will not be interrupted.

—As I was saying, there is a growing trend throughout the world in terms of the overall design of social security systems towards the sort of broad structure that we have and an increased emphasis on targeting. We are bringing in significant elements of a contributory arrangement. We are the ones who are in line with the broad developments of social security systems throughout the world. We have not heard anything coherent from the opposition as to what it advocates in this area, but the utterances of various people lead to a considerable degree of concern as to the long-term survival of an adequate pension system under them.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Can the minister confirm that he sacked his aviation adviser, Mr Jim Wolfe? Can the minister reveal to the House the reasons for the sacking? What does the minister have on the Prime Minister which results in everyone being sacked except the incompetent decision maker at the top, bungling Brereton?
—The last part of the question is out of order.

—The gentleman referred to in the honourable member's question is a departmental liaison officer between the ministry of transport and my office. These people are recycled and cycled and recycled. It just so happens that Mr Wolfe has finished his assignment. The honourable member should not come into this House with any slur on either Mr Wolfe or me.
—My question is addressed to the—

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for Watson will wait. Those on my left will come to order.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. Could the minister advise the House whether there are any financial implications for the Commonwealth due to the sexual privacy legislation being passed in this House today? In particular, are there likely to be savings in Commonwealth outlays due to a reduction in resources that might be necessary to service a now diminished opposition frontbench?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is: there might be. Perhaps they arise from the consequences of a press release, which I have here, from the National Party of Australia, Tasmania branch. It says:

ANSWER.PARA: The National Party today forced a division on the Sexual Privacy Bill, something the Liberal Party were not prepared to do.
Six Liberal members abstained from voting, including the Federal Member for Braddon, Mr Chris Miles MP. Fence sitting on this issue is totally unacceptable.
The National Party alone was willing to heed what Tasmania had to say and they alone have followed the voice of the National Party motions recently passed in Canberra at the Federal Conference.
We believe all states will long regret the implications of this Bill in regards to state's rights.

I can only say that as to any reduction in resources that may go to the opposition on that matter, as far as the National Party of Australia, Tasmania branch, is concerned, I would inform Mrs Mary Jackson, the Senior Vice President who released this statement, that there was one West Australian Liberal MP who joined the National Party members in it. But I think it is a pretty fair indication of the sort of nonsense that has gone on in the opposition in this place for some considerable time on this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker—

PARA.TAB: Mr Downer interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Leader of the Opposition is not helping nor setting a good example.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport. Will the minister now confirm that the pilot of the ill-fated Aero Commander which crashed en route to Lord Howe Island did not have a current pilot's medical certificate? If so, is insurance for the flight null and void? Is the government prepared to meet the claims of families of victims of the crash as a result of the failure of the CAA to enforce this regulation? What would be the ultimate cost to the government of the claims of the families?

—In response to the member for Fadden, I have sought advice from the Civil Aviation Authority and did intend to provide him with this answer at the end of question time today. He raised the point on 12 October and I promised him that I would look into it. As far as can be established by the Civil Aviation Authority's director of aviation medicine, the pilot's commercial medical certificate expired on 7 September 1994. Seaview is liable under the Civil Aviation (Carriers' Liability) Act to compensate the relatives of the victims of the accident. The investigator acting on behalf of Seaview's insurer is examining this matter, I am told, in accordance with standard and accepted insurance industry practice.

PARA.TAB: I intend to ensure that the government, for our part, pays close attention to the processing of any insurance claims which arise from the Seaview accident. I think it entirely appropriate as well that it should be the subject of scrutiny by the House of Representatives inquiry into air safety. I will be more than pleased to review this matter after we have seen the policy and after we have seen how the insurance company responds, and I will do so in the context of the measures that I announced on 20 July last which sought to ensure that there was no voiding of insurance arrangements in connection with Australian light aircraft operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Attorney-General. Can he advise the House of the government's intentions in relation to proposals to enact legislation dealing with the incitement of racial hatred?

—Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. Under standing order 144, that question clearly goes to an announcement of government policy. I would ask you to rule that question out of order before it is answered by the minister.
—No, the question actually asked for intentions and I am sure that, in his response, the minister will be aware of standing order 144.
—We all know that policies are not intentions, don't we?
—The member for Berowra should be more careful.

—Obviously the question of racial hatred or racial vilification laws is a difficult one. It is difficult inasmuch as it requires a very careful balancing between the fundamental importance of free speech and freedom of expression against the right of all people in our society to live free of taunts, attacks, or violence based or motivated on grounds of race.

PARA.TAB: Ensuring that freedom of expression is not unduly restricted while achieving that sort of security which underpins very much the basic racial harmony in Australian society has been the dominant factor in the government's consideration of this matter. I will be shortly taking a bill to cabinet seeking the introduction of legislation in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —This year?

—Yes, this year. This legislation will have criminal sanctions to deal with the most extreme instances of the incitement of racial hatred. It will, however, certainly be consistent with experiences that we have gained from the operation of legislation in other parts of Australia, most notably in New South Wales where such legislation has now been in place for some five years. We have taken great note as to the terms of that legislation, the effectiveness of it, and any implication it has on the question of free speech.

PARA.TAB: So I can assure the honourable member that the government does take this matter seriously. There are important issues to be determined here and these will shortly be discussed before the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—My question is addressed to you, Mr Speaker. Would it be possible for this House to have a health audit? I believe that, due to the airconditioning in this building, I have come down with a number of viral infections at various times in this House.

PARA.TAB: Opposition members interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Some may think it is funny.
—Order! This is a question to me, not a speech.

—My question is: could there be a health audit on the functioning of this building in terms of the airconditioning and in terms of the spread of viruses and infections which obviously cause havoc through all our offices?

—I can say to the honourable member for Gilmore that the issue of alleged health problems stemming from the airconditioning in this building has been the subject of some examination in the past. The Joint House Department, as our maintenance authority, is sensitive to those concerns and has, since occupation of the building, had in place a comprehensive plan—a preventative maintenance program—which I am advised, among other things, ensures that optimum environmental conditions are maintained in Parliament House at all times.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I am advised that our standards not only conform with but also exceed relevant statutory and industry standards and requirements such as those set down by the National Health and Medical Research Council. The Joint House Department has also commissioned independent studies and reports on the airconditioning system in Parliament House, including maintenance and cleaning standards, and on the quality of air itself. All studies have concluded that the airconditioning system and the quality of air itself exceed Australian and international standards, particularly the high percentage of fresh air which is introduced into the building through the airconditioning system.

If the honourable member has further concerns, he might like to take them up directly with the Joint House Department's chief engineer, Mr Adrian Guilfoyle, who can be reached on extension 7101. He might also like to raise directly with the Joint House Department his concerns about a health audit.

TALKER.NAME: Mr TIM FISCHER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do claim to have been misrepresented.
—Please proceed.

—I rise in respect of comments made by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Baldwin) again today and to place on the record the letter I wrote to the Wagga Daily Advertiser. Firstly, I drafted the letter yesterday. It was signed—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am honest. It was raised on Monday, I drafted the letter Tuesday, it was typed last night and I signed it this morning.

—I was misrepresented by the Minister for Social Security both today and last Monday on the floor of the House, and I made a personal explanation last Monday. The particularity of it relates to remarks in respect of Thailand. I did refer to Thailand and how it is committed to looking after the elderly in the family structure. I at no stage advocated the abolition of the aged or service pension in Australia. In fact, at the particular CWA meeting I said that my praise for Thailand was in the context of its commitment to the family and this should be something that should be pursued in Australia additional to the Australian pension system.

Those organisations have to answer for themselves; I do not. My views are not at all as extreme as those. Secondly—

SPEECH.PARA: . . . his espousal of intolerance . . .
I want to say to this House that I do not have an ounce of intolerance in my body, and I find the attempts at innuendo and smearing tactics to be deceitful and a disgrace.
