INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

PARA.TAB: The concerns resulting from the Minister for Transport's self-admitted claim that he had paid insufficient attention to the problems of air safety in Australia, leading to a loss of confidence in the Minister's ability.

INTERJECT.PARA: I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of members required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sharp Mr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A very serious incident occurred at Mascot airport today involving a Boeing 747 with 253 people on board, mercifully with no injuries involved. It just reinforces the importance of the topic we are discussing in federal parliament today and which we have been discussing over the last few days. The topic is on why our aviation safety is in a state of chaos.

PARA.TAB: I will try to give everybody in this House a very quick pictorial example of why our aviation safety is in a state of chaos. In the Sydney Morning Herald of last Saturday, there was an article all about none other than the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton). But in this article he is not called the `Minister for Transport'; he is called the `Minister for Chaos'. The reason why our aviation safety is in the state it is in is that we have a minister running and administering it who is known as the Minister for Chaos. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: A whole raft of Government MPs are happy to tell anyone who will listen (off the record, of course) they believe the blame for Laurie's plight rests squarely with himself.

PARA.TAB: Few people, even in Brereton's factional base, the NSW Right, are great admirers of the Minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Anybody who has been following the aviation industry over the last little while would share those sentiments, as I am sure all members on this side of the House would. The explanation for the chaos within our aviation safety was in yesterday's paper. As I reminded the House yesterday, an article by Geoff Kitney in the Sydney Morning Herald pointed out that the minister had informed journalists in the gallery that he felt he had not been paying sufficient attention to the problems of air safety in Australia, to the problems of the CAA, because he had been too busy with other duties. We have heard the minister here today in the House deny that he ever said that to journalists in the gallery.

PARA.TAB: It is going to be an interesting time for the minister because I was in the gallery yesterday afternoon and spoke with people who believed they had been spoken to by the Minister for Transport and told precisely what was in Geoff Kitney's article which was reported in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. It raises the question of the basic integrity of the Minister for Transport.

If we are going to look at aviation safety, and at the state of it at the present time, we need to have a look at the history of the Civil Aviation Authority. The Civil Aviation Authority was founded in 1988 and, in short history, has been the subject of a great deal of controversy: chairmen of the board have left prematurely; chief executive officers have come and gone; and it has been involved in a number of scandals such as the TAAATS inquiry, which members of this House will well remember, where Frank Baldwin, who was the then Chief Executive Officer of the CAA, was finally pressured to leave, along with his sidekick.

A whole host of other scandals have been revealed over a period of time. In the process, a number of credible journalists in the gallery have taken an interest in the CAA and reported major deficiencies within the operations of the CAA. They have been continuously reporting on these for the last couple of years.

One has to remember that the Civil Aviation Authority's headquarters in Canberra is nicknamed by all those who work there and all those who know it as `Fort Fumble'. If the minister who had responsibility for administering this authority whose headquarters was nicknamed `Fort Fumble' had read in the paper almost weekly of the major concerns about its administration and studied the history of it and discovered it was full of controversy, you would have thought that he—if he was on top of his job—would have taken a great deal of interest in its goings-on. You would have thought that he would have made it his task to know what was happening and get on top of the job at the Civil Aviation Authority.

My interest in the Civil Aviation Authority does not date back to 1988: it really started on 11 June last year when a Monarch Airlines plane crashed in Young, which is in my electorate and my home town, about a mile and a half from my farm. On board that aircraft were seven people. I knew nearly all of them. Those people got on board that aircraft because they had faith in the pilot of that aircraft, they had faith in the person who maintained that aircraft and they had faith in the system which was supposed to ensure that all the maintenance and flying operations procedures were being adhered to. Those people got on board that aircraft because they had faith in the CAA.

Do you know what? Their faith was not borne out. Because the CAA did not do its job, those people—Stephen Ward, who was my opponent at the last election; Bill Caldwell, who was born and bred in the district and a person I had known for many years; Jane Gay, Prue Papworth and Alanda Clark, three teenage girls; and the two pilots, Brindley Baker and Wayne Gorham—were killed. They were killed because the CAA did not do its job. It did not supervise the system that was supposed to give people faith to get on board an aircraft knowing that they could confidently put their lives in the hands of the pilot and the people who maintained that aircraft.

The person who is responsible for all of that is the Minister for Transport—the man who will respond in a few minutes. I am afraid to say that the administration by this government of the Civil Aviation Authority has been a sham. It has been a disgrace. As a consequence, people have lost faith in the veracity and credibility of the CAA. The system has failed them.

After this crash occurred, I started to do some investigations into why it happened. I discovered the most amazing things about Monarch. The aircraft was flying without many of the instruments operating. The owners of the aircraft were not responsible people. They had not paid a bill to the CAA since November 1991.

I also discovered that Monarch Airlines had been recommended for grounding three times, the most recent of which was six weeks before the crash. Yet, somehow or other, somebody within the CAA system, which is administered by the Minister for Transport, overrode those grounding recommendations and allowed that aircraft to continue to fly. As a consequence, those people died.

This is what it is all about. So I started to ask questions. Why on earth is the Civil Aviation Authority not doing its job? When I started to investigate it I found the most amazing deficiencies in the way it operated. I found that there was a culture which put the commercial interests of airline operators ahead of the safety interests of passengers. This is why airlines like Monarch were allowed to continue to fly.

In the process, I also discovered that there are other Monarch planes flying. When I finally got to make a speech about this in parliament on 3 May this year, I outlined all the things that I had discovered. I highlighted also that there were some other airlines that operated Monarch planes and I named them. One of them was Seaview Air. I said that these were dangerous airlines that were putting the lives of people at risk every day.

The next day in the House we had some questions on it. The minister expressed his concern and said he would take this matter up with the CAA himself. And he did. From the day he gave the CAA the information about my claims made in the parliament, he did not ask it to give him a response for five months, not until the weekend of the eighth or the ninth of October, which just happened to be after the Seaview crash, for God's sake. Why did he not do so? I had expressed these well researched, well documented concerns about Seaview Air and this guy said he was going to chase it up and he did not do anything about it for five months, until it was too late.

Over the last week or two this man has had the gall to try to say that somehow or other I bear responsibility for all of this; that somehow or other it is me who is to blame because I did not respond in the way George Macionis wanted me to in the letter that he wrote to me after I had made my speech in May. Does the minister know why George wrote that letter? He does; he knows it. It is because he wanted to get me to put things in writing so he could sue me and his colleagues and find out the sources of all these leaks from the CAA.

The minister says, `The shadow minister should put forward all of the details so that we can check these things out.' All the details were from the CAA. All the documentation I had had come directly from the CAA. He only had to go and ask the CAA. The files were there for him to find out all about Seaview, to find out all about Monarch, to find out all about Yanda, to find out all about Winrye Aviation. It was all there for you to find out, minister, and you never did, not for five months until after that crash had occurred in the early part of October this year.

So, one has to ask oneself: is this minister carrying out his responsibilities in a responsible and effective manner? I would say to the members of this House that that sort of delay, that sort of dereliction of duty, is not an indication of a minister carrying out his responsibilities with effectiveness and with diligence. It is for that reason, minister, that people have been saying in the last week or two that you should go from your job.

The minister made great play yesterday in this House of a private meeting that he and I had had in his office on 21 July this year in Sydney. He talked about that private meeting. Okay; if he wants to play it at that sort of level I can talk about another private meeting we had which he has not referred to. The private meeting we had was after I had made the speech in the House. It was after the question time, I think, after which we had run an MPI in May. We went upstairs and had a sandwich. I said to the minister, `I have all these concerns.' The minister said, `Yes, I am really worried about the CAA because any organisation that leaks as much as the CAA has a real problem.' Just for the record, as he is prepared to play this sort of game, I might say that he also said to me that he wanted to get out of the industrial relations portfolio, which confirms what Simon Crean said on the weekend. So let us have the game being played fair and square.

The dereliction of this minister's responsibilities can be seen in the fact that after the Seaview crash I informed the CAA that there were two Seaview aircraft flying in Western Australia on a 16-day charter, with 10 passengers in one aircraft and 11 in another, that were flying overloaded and with major problems in the aircraft. On the Tuesday I notified the CAA. On the Saturday they were ramp checked. On the Monday George Macionis, and Doug Roser, the Chief Executive Officer of the CAA, said that there was nothing wrong with those aircraft. Yet I knew that those aircraft had major faults. I knew that they had been flying overloaded. I knew that they were running out of engine time and could not get back to their base before their engines needed major maintenance.

How is it that I know these things, that I have the files on these things and the documentation to prove it and this man has not? I will tell honourable members why. It is because he has not been interested. The only reason we have seen action out of this man over the last few weeks is that it is starting to become an embarrassment for him. A judicial inquiry, a parliamentary inquiry, an AFP investigation—all of it is shutting the door after the horses have bolted. That is what it is all about. It is about diligence.

Minister, you have said to me, `You put some information down on the table about some of your concerns.' I am going to give you some things you can concern yourself about. I have here today a note for file.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's pretty late in the day.

—It is not late in the day. You can do something to fix this up before something else goes wrong. It is about a company called Airlink. It operates BAe 146 aircraft. It flies thousands of passengers around Australia per week. This airline is operating in a manner which is so typical of the way in which the CAA has dealt with companies like Monarch and Seaview. I will table this note for file, if you will let me do it, at the end of the debate today. It has information in it. If you want more you can go to the CAA because the files of the CAA will reveal all you want to know.

PARA.TAB: Whilst you are about talking to the CAA, ask it about the Phoenix Aero Club at Bankstown. It used to be called the New South Wales Police Aero Club. The police commissioner earlier this year withdrew patronage from the club because of the scandalous events going on there, at one of the biggest pilot trainers in New South Wales. If you cannot get the files out of the CAA, come to me. I have them in my office and I can give them to you. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brereton The Hon L.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Transport)

TALK.START.PARA: —Talk about scraping the bottom of the barrel, looking for a new angle! This lot, who spent this week calling me the minister for news clips, are now basing this matter of public importance on a single, unsourced comment piece in one newspaper, a story that appeared not today but yesterday. What an absolute waste of time.

PARA.TAB: Having failed yesterday to get any sort of a run at all, having failed to come up with any new material whatsoever and having failed to establish in any way, shape or form that I had not ordered a response to his allegations in the parliament, the member for Hume (Mr Sharp) is at it again today. He may be sharp by name, but he is not sharp by nature. He is certainly about as sharp as the member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) was yesterday—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: on the question of relevance, this is a debate about people's lives and I do not think the minister should have come in here with a pre-written speech with smart alec comments such as that.
—The minister is in order.

—The member for Bennelong yesterday gave government members all that time to come back to the House to vote in the division. What a master tactician. What a wonderful combination, the pair of you! Yesterday the honourable member for Hume was baying for my blood at the behest of the Leader of the National Party (Mr Tim Fischer), baying for my blood at the behest of `Mr Seventeen Per Cent', his friend the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer).

PARA.TAB: That is something he simply cannot refute. We and everyone in this House know that after months of congratulations after congratulations, of thanking me for every step taken and for every announcement made, this week, for the very first time, the honourable member has changed his tune. Today he comes in here with this mock performance, baying once again for blood, to condemn me after months of consistent congratulations.

What we have seen this week is the member for Hume, in the interests of securing cheap political points, giving away bipartisanship and giving away the cooperation that has been there to change this culture, to order the parliamentary review and to undertake the reform program that was announced on 20 July. Down we are in the gutter with a performance that is so typical of those members opposite. For my part, I think this for all time relegates the member for Hume, someone I have always considered to be basically a decent human being, to the ranks of the political B-graders. That is where you are as a result of your change of tune this week.

All of the correspondence I have tabled in the parliament—I have been very open in this process—has proven that I organised an immediate response to that speech made in this parliament on 4 May. If you look at that first letter from the Civil Aviation Authority, the one that the honourable member for Hume took 31 days to respond to, you find that there is a copy of that letter addressed to me.

Why is there such a copy? I will tell you why—because I had initiated the approach. I had brought it to the attention of people within the responsible statutory authority because they are the people charged by law—by an act of this parliament—with that responsibility. So, 31 days later, the honourable member for Hume says, `No, I'm not going to be in it because I'm worried about confidentiality.' But he makes very little of the fact that there was a subsequent invitation—not by the director of air safety but by the Managing Director of the Civil Aviation Authority—offering him the confidential reporting system of the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. What does he do? Again, he declines. He says, `No, I don't want to supply the information.'

That response was to BASI—the same body that discovered all of the deficiencies arising from the Monarch accident; the same body that brought forward the report that I responded to within a matter of hours in a most comprehensive way only to again be congratulated by the honourable member. The fact is that the honourable member has declined offer after offer—and now we have the parliamentary inquiry—of which he is a member. Has he put a submission to it? Has he put any of this evidence—

TALK.START.PARA: —How can I put a submission to myself?

—So he has not put forward a submission. Has he put any material before it? The answer, as I understand it, is no, he has not. He has put forward no detailed information. He declined those earlier efforts because he wanted a parliamentary inquiry—a parliamentary inquiry that I gave him. He got the avenue and he should stop complaining. I have to say this: if he had any misgivings about my approach, what was he doing in my office on 21 July so warmly congratulating me? I have tabled my file note of that conversation.
—That was in relation to the parliamentary inquiry, not in relation to the administration of the CAA.

—And in relation to the whole response to the BASI report. I challenge him to bring forward his file note, his contemporaneous explanation of what occurred back then. But instead of that, no, here he is in the House trying to launch an attack upon me based on some unsourced, alleged conversation—a version of which I totally reject and which is quite simply not the fact. Let me tell you this: in almost 25 years of politics, I have never said to anyone—not once—that I was not doing my job. I have never ever failed to do my job, whether it be in this or any other of the tasks entrusted to me throughout those 24 years and nine months.

PARA.TAB: As I have been saying in this parliament on each and every opportunity—and there have been many of them in these last two weeks—every bit of information that has come my way has been immediately referred to the relevant authorities or, alternatively, acted upon by myself. Of course, that is just what happened in the case of Seaview. That is why today we have a judicial inquiry, a parliamentary inquiry and a police investigation under way at the Civil Aviation Authority. Every time real structural problems have been identified, I have acted immediately. That was the case with the response to the Monarch accident and BASI's report upon it, and it was the case with the cabinet decision last week to split the Civil Aviation Authority and create a new and independent aviation safety agency.

Of course, it was that decision which took us away from partial cost recovery in aviation safety—cost recovery which is still the policy of those sitting opposite. Let me put down this challenge to the opposition today: do not let it go for another hour. Declare right here and now that you will give up your policy, which is full cost recovery for the Civil Aviation Authority; that is, for every aspect of search and rescue in every part of aviation safety to be funded through the industry.

We are the government that has raised our contribution from $22 million to $29 million. You still have a Fightback policy that says full cost recovery. You have not changed from it. You did not change from it in The Things That Matter. I put it to you at this belated hour today—the very same day that the honourable member is saying he has some more material that he would like to table—that you should come forward, change your policy and be decent about it. I repeat that every time we have had an issue placed before us we have acted properly and effectively.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you ever been to CAA headquarters?

—Listen, I have had numerous meetings with the officers of the Civil Aviation Authority. I have been up in their control towers and I have had them in my office. I have had numerous meetings with them. So do not come in here with any of your poise—
—Have you ever been to the CAA headquarters?
—Listen, old glass jaw, I thought you would have dropped off after your performance earlier in the week.
—You have never been to its headquarters.
—Order! The Leader of the National Party will cease interjecting.

—Try as the opposition might it does not have a scintilla of evidence to substantiate any allegation against me; it does not have a single word to substantiate anything that has been said against me. You cannot deny that you have had ample opportunities to bring forward all of your material. Let me say for my part that response has been my job—response at all times to the big structural deficiencies, including the ones that were identified by BASI, and response to ensure that your allegations are pursued through the relevant authorities. Alternatively, where you have not sought to take up that offer, I have provided alternative means, such as the parliamentary inquiry that you wanted and that you got.

PARA.TAB: If I have something to hide, why the heck would I have gone through each of those stages and provided all of those opportunities, the most important being the parliamentary inquiry of which the honourable member for Hume is a member? Everyone in this House knows that I have acted in an entirely proper fashion throughout the whole of this matter—and the honourable member knows it. Until this week, the man principally responsible for raising these matters has endorsed every single action I have taken every single step of the way. If ever I have seen an exercise displaying the most blatant and ramp hypocrisy, it has been the performance of the member for Hume this week in breaking from bipartisanship and in lowering himself into the gutter along with his opposition colleagues.

When he had to change his tune, what did he do? He put out a full-page defensive press release. There it was at long last, on 18 October, after all of those congratulations, saying that I should step aside. What reason did he give in the press release? He said:

SPEECH.PARA: To use my failure to provide the CAA with its own documents as an excuse for inertia is laughable.

He is talking about himself, of course. Yet it was not just the CAA, was it? You could have used the BASI CAIR reporting system. You were invited to use it, but you declined. You could have responded to my personal urging to bring forward material rather than waited until today when you said, `Oh, I've got some material that at the end of this MPI I would like to table.' The fact is that you have had all these opportunities and you have not used any of them.

PARA.TAB: You then go on to claim that you made me an offer to look through your documents, but you did no such thing. You said, `I want a parliamentary inquiry,' and you got that inquiry. That is the truth of the matter. On 21 July I personally urged you to come forward. My version is there on the record. I put it to the honourable member for Hume: where is yours? Do not come in here with a few unsubstantiated interpretations of what might have been said at one discussion or another. Show me what you wrote down contemporaneously on that occasion. I have my note and it shows what a blatant and absolute hypocrite you are.

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order—
—Order! The minister might withdraw that remark.

—I will withdraw `hypocrite'. It is an act of great hypocrisy. Instead of getting on with the task of reforming aviation safety, today we are wasting the time of the House on an unsourced comment and an interpretation which I absolutely refute. You will have to do a lot better than that, but in reality you cannot. You have had no new information and you have acknowledged at every point your support for the approach that I have taken.

PARA.TAB: It is only now, after this tragic accident, that we have this unwelcome intervention by your leader and the fact that you are out there changing your tune. Again, that is your choice, but do not expect me to sit back and not point out the opportunities you have had, the supportive statements you have made or the platform you have been given. I have responded at every turn. That is why we have the police inquiry, the parliamentary inquiry and the judicial inquiry. You put up or shut up!

The reality is that after damning reports—that is what the Monarch report was—I acted immediately, urgently and appropriately in every respect. You said, `Thanks very much. You've done more than I ever expected you to do.' Action has been apparent at all times. I will continue to take appropriate action at every turn. I will not be diverted by sideshows such as this. Do not accuse me in this House—as members of the opposition have done today—of being a minister for newsclips. They have based an entire MPI on a single, unsubstantiated and incorrect newsclip. Let us get back to the real issues. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the document that I referred to in my speech earlier.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Jenkins)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —No. I think you should put it before the parliamentary committee.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The speech of the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) was one of the most pathetic attempts at covering up a national scandal that I have ever seen or heard of. The minister does not like the message so he marches in here to shoot the messenger. The honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp) brought forward very serious allegations. He has been greatly concerned about the scandals in the Civil Aviation Authority for a very long time. What happens? The minister does not answer those concerns. He puts in a performance which, if put in by anyone other than a minister of the Crown, would be described as dodgy, slimy or shifty.

PARA.TAB: The minister's performance in this place is typical of the machinations of the New South Wales right wing of the ALP. He is prepared to ride roughshod over the lives of Australians that have been lost because of his maladministration of the Department of Transport. There he goes! By leaving the chamber he is creeping out of this parliament yet again. He fails to come in here for question time to answer questions on the administration—or maladministration—of his portfolio. He comes in here only occasionally. Yet during this MPI—which goes right to the heart of his fitness to hold office—he creeps away, probably to have yet another conference with members of the New South Wales right wing.

He claims that he acted on every allegation and that he has done a proper job as a minister of the Crown. He is guilty of acting too little, too late. Would you believe that he has never been—he has admitted this—to the headquarters of the CAA, situated in the heart of his electorate! Obviously, he would like the headquarters to be moved to Thredbo where he spends so much of his time. His performance has been pathetic. He has tried to turn the criticism from his own maladministration in the direction of the honourable member for Hume. That is pathetic!

Minister Brereton is totally incompetent and a danger to the travelling public of Australia. It is, therefore, entirely appropriate that we should raise the question of his maladministration in this parliament. As a House, we should also express our concern over his self-admitted claim that he paid insufficient attention to the problems of air safety in Australia, leading to a loss of confidence in his ability and loss of life in the air disaster.

A moment ago, he asked us to participate in a bipartisan conspiracy to trample on the deaths of those people who have been killed in air crashes in Australia. We on this side of the House want an open inquiry. We want the government to come clean. Obviously, we want this cleaned up because it cannot go on this way. Every day of the week people step onto aircraft, confident in the administration of the CAA. But, with the crashes that have occurred, that confidence has been misplaced.

The government is not worthy of the respect of the Australian people and, indeed, the minister is not worthy of the respect of this House. Let us look briefly at the history of Seaview Air and the disaster which ultimately occurred. As long ago as January 1994, the Civil Aviation Authority wrote to the chief pilot of that airline expressing very serious concerns about the operational safety of its aircraft. The breaches suggested related to overloading, aircraft being flown without backup navigation, and incorrect marketing of the airline. One pilot flew without a flight plan! That was January 1994. An aircraft crashed in October 1994.

The minister is the person responsible for the administration of the Department of Transport. If the government had any concept of the doctrine of ministerial responsibility, that minister would have gone. What did the minister do in January 1994? He did absolutely nothing. In May 1994 my colleague the honourable member for Hume made very serious allegations in relation to Seaview Air. Again, the question of overloading was raised, as were other matters. What did the minister do? The minister referred the matters to the CAA and then allowed them to rest on someone's desk in the CAA for a period of five months. Can you believe it! Allegations as serious as those raised by the honourable member for Hume were effectively ignored by the Minister for Transport for a period of five months.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lazy!

—Had the minister not been lazy—as my colleague reminds me—dilatory and inept, those nine people who lost their lives in the Seaview crash might well be alive today. My colleague the honourable member for Hume referred to the Monarch air crash of last year and the fact that people lost their lives in that tragedy. Yet this minister simply comes in here and mouths platitude after platitude. Like a worm twisting on a hook, he does whatever he can to avoid responsibility. Surely this minister has some concept of what is honest and decent.

PARA.TAB: He is reactive rather than pro-active. He tries to avoid the question for as long as possible. But, when we find that aircraft are falling out of the sky and Australians are losing their lives, he comes forward with some things that are too little and too late. As the member for Hume said, an international 747 aircraft crash-landed at Sydney airport today. We will all be waiting with great interest to find the reason for that. I am wondering whether that aircraft was passed when it should not have been, or whether there were problems which should have been picked up by the CAA. The minister, who is responsible for the CAA, should be answering these questions.

A stench pervades the minister's maladministration of his portfolio areas. Everyone knows that he has got too much on his plate; everyone knows that he is incompetent. He will tell that to anyone who will listen. He rings the press and says that he is far too busy to concentrate on these important matters that he should be concentrating on to save Australian lives. He comes in here—occasionally—and fails to respond to an MPI, fails properly to respond to questions, ridicules people on our side of the House who express a very great concern over what everyone in Australia agrees is the maladministration of civil aviation matters, and then he creeps out. He has slunk out of the parliament; he is not present in the parliament now. He is a coward and he continues to be cowardly.

Why did he not have time to look into these matters in relation to safety? Was he organising his capitulation to mining unions over the abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal? Was he contemplating the cost of some $4 billion to be paid by New South Wales taxpayers for the Sydney Harbour Tunnel? Was he prevaricating over the future of ANL, which is still a disaster? Australian awards for ANL still require employees to work two weeks on and two weeks off; that is, ANL must maintain 2 1/2 crews, while overseas shipping lines only have to have 1 1/2 crews per ship.

The minister obviously was not concentrating on making the waterfront competitive. In Sydney and Melbourne stevedoring costs are still far too high. They are twice as expensive as stevedoring costs in New Zealand. In that country even a Labor government was able to reform the waterfront. This minister's record in this area, as in so many others, is shabby by comparison. Was the minister trying to introduce reduced port charges to enable competition on the waterfront? No. The minister clearly was also not spending time to reform that disaster known as the National Rail Authority.

What on earth was this minister doing? Perhaps he was contemplating the disaster of his industrial relations legislation. Perhaps he was even skiing at Thredbo when Australian planes were falling out of the sky and Australians were being killed. I am appalled that this minister would creep into this parliament, that he would slink out of this parliament and that he would try to avoid the very real questions that have been raised over a period of more than 12 months by my colleague the honourable member for Hume.

When we attempt to call the minister to account, he scorns us. He refuses to answer our questions. He avoids them. He twists and turns on the hook. This minister is so grossly inept that he must go. He should be sacked. He has become a political corpse and it is necessary for the government to give him a burial very soon. The people of Australia demand efficiency, accountability, honesty and decency.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very pleasing to see the opposition returning to the present and raising an issue of substance after its little excursion into the past on major issues like who said what at meetings four years ago. A number of us on this side have been a bit worried about the opposition. There has been some debate about whether it is chronically hopeless or whether it is going through a bit of a bad patch. At least we have some potential hope that, now that it has raised an issue of substance, maybe those who take the more generous view are right. Unfortunately, though opposition members may be raising an issue of substance, their contributions have no substance. They are halfway there. We are dealing with something important for a change, but they have not managed to make a contribution that has some content.

PARA.TAB: We saw this again with the honourable member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) today. The major argument is that the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) happened to be on holiday when a plane crash occurred. He was skiing. What was he supposed to do? Throw on the flying cap and goggles, leap out into the ministerial Sopwith Camel and lead the search? Was he supposed to go into the Fuhrer bunker and get the big table out with the maps on it and move the little markers around? That is the sort of inane lunacy that comes from the opposition when the search went on for several days, when the minister was in regular, daily contact with what was going on, when there was no knowledge of what had occurred and no basis to make any assumptions about what had happened, what had caused the plane to go missing and where it had gone down.

Those are the sorts of points of substance that the opposition has managed to raise in this debate. Until that search and investigation were completed, there was no basis for knowing what had caused the plane to go missing or what had caused the crash. The minister was entirely proper to maintain contact, but the suggestion that, in some way, there is some connection between where he was at the time and the crash itself is ridiculous.

What has the minister done? In response to the accusations raised about the Monarch disaster, the minister initiated a parliamentary inquiry headed by the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). He has initiated a federal police investigation into certain matters. He has initiated the separation of the air safety section of the Civil Aviation Authority to a different authority, and he has most recently initiated an inquiry, headed by Sir Laurence Street, former New South Wales chief justice, into the Seaview disaster and all aspects of CAA administration of air safety.

Maybe the opposition would like the terms of reference broadened to include a few things like the Sydney Harbour Tunnel or some of the other red herrings that have been thrown into the debate. Contrast this with the contribution by the shadow minister for transport, the honourable member for Hume (Mr Sharp), who has managed to throw around all sorts of accusations, such as corruption—and that is a fairly strong word. But every time he is challenged to put up, he runs away. Every time he is asked to produce some evidence, he runs away. Today we heard him come forward with the most extraordinarily pathetic excuse that we could ever expect to hear; namely, that he was worried about being sued for libel. What is to stop him from raising these accusations in here? He cannot be sued for libel in here. He refuses to provide details of these accusations and says, `I am worried about being sued for libel.'

He had the opportunity to table a document this morning at a meeting of the committee headed by the member for Shortland, of which he is a member. This very day he could have submitted that document to the committee, and he did not do so. There may well be some serious problems in the administration of air safety in this country and that, as a result of some of the things that have happened with the CAA, particularly with lower level employees not passing on safety issues to senior management, there is an issue to be investigated very seriously. But we cannot make presumptions about causal connections between those problems and individual crashes until the investigation is completed.

I think we also need to look at some of the broader issues here: the question of the ever-increasing intensity to deregulate, of which the opposition is always in the vanguard. We have increasing pressure on organisations like the Civil Aviation Authority to allow greater freedom for businesses to make a profit even if passengers are at risk. The government has also been deregulating in a variety of areas, so it is not just a problem on the other side, but it is something that we ought to pay serious attention to.

The opposition, if serious, should start giving us its views on some of the substantial issues that are involved here. What do opposition members have to say about air safety regulation? What do they have to say about the regulations? Are they too strict? Are they not stringent enough? Should they be changed? They should address such questions instead of coming in here, throwing buckets over people and looking for everybody to be sacked. They want the head of the CAA and the minister to be sacked. Let us have a contribution of substance on the issues because there are serious issues to be dealt with about the nature of regulation and the extent to which we should ensure that passengers are protected and that businesses are able to continue operating the airlines.

Although we should be grateful for the opposition returning from the past and dealing with an issue of substance for a change, we may have to wait some time before we get a contribution of substance on these issues. We had a major debate about a very important part of the airline industry recently within the government—that is, the future of the Federal Airports Corporation. That substantial debate occurred openly. Safety issues, such as the maintenance of runways and lights, were involved. There were many other issues, but safety was an important factor in the debate.

During the debate, what did we hear from members of the opposition? All we heard was: sell, sell, sell. Did we hear anything about the prospective future for safety issues in a privatised airport regime? Did they give any consideration to those issues? No. What we heard was an incredible suggestion by the honourable member for Ryan (Mr Moore) that the opposition would cut the FAC in half. We would have a privatised northern FAC and a southern FAC competing against each other. In other words, in their ideal aviation industry, we would have Cairns airport competing against Adelaide airport. I can see the tourists from Asia talking to each other over in Hong Kong and Singapore saying, `Where will we go this year? Will we go to Adelaide or Cairns? I hear the Adelaide airport is very nice at this time of year.' That is an unbelievable proposition. That is an illustration of the depth and substance that we get from the opposition's aviation policy.

It is very easy to come in here when there has been a disaster of this nature and call for everyone to be sacked. That is a very simplistic and superficial response. Instead, opposition members should come in here and talk about some serious issues, such as how should the aviation industry be regulated. The opposition is floundering in debates of substance because it is full of superficial people bereft of policy ideas. We need look no further for evidence of this than the last federal election. Opposition members came forward with a substantial policy comprising 500-odd pages. But where did it come from? They had to contract it out. They had to go to Access Economics to draw up a policy for them because they did not have the capacity and the ability on their own benches to draw it up themselves. That is a perfect illustration of how bereft the opposition is of serious policy substance and the ability to come in and debate major issues of national importance like this with anything more than just vituperation and nonsense.

By contrast, the government—the Labor benches—is full of people who make substantial contributions to policy debate in this country. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) will both be remembered as people who have made leading contributions to ideas and policy debate in this country long after they have left politics.

Can the same be said of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Downer)? Can the same be said of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Mr Costello)? Have they ever written anything? Have they ever put ideas on paper? Have they ever come forward with major substantial policy initiatives? They put forward less than the average backbencher on our side. What we end up with is nothing more than pure vituperation and bile masquerading as policy substance. All we get are mindless attacks on public servants and chanting: `The minister's got to resign, the minister's got to resign.' They completely ignore the substantive issues that we all accept are of crucial importance in this area. Nobody is disputing that.

The minister has responded promptly on every occasion and he has been congratulated for doing so by the shadow minister until the shadow minister realised he might get some political capital out of the issue and changed his tune. He has responded correctly to the Seaview tragedy and to indications that there may be deficiencies in the administration of air safety regulations by the Civil Aviation Authority.

It is understandable that the opposition would seek to make as much capital as it can out of these circumstances. Let us face it, there is not much else around for it. It is understandable that we are hearing these things. But, please, at least come in here and give us some substance about what you would do with respect to air safety regulation. Let us talk about the real issues, deregulation and these sorts of things, and not throw brickbats just for the sake of it. Let us talk about the substantive issues and get some genuine policy debate into these very serious matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

(b)an amount or amounts of home child care allowance (within the meaning of the Social Security Act 1991) were paid to the spouse at any time during the year of income;
the rebate is to be reduced or further reduced, as the case requires, by the amount, or the sum of the amounts, of the home child care allowance.';
(c)by inserting `home child care allowance,' before `or a child disability allowance' in paragraph (a) of the definition of `separate net income' in subsection (6).".

The coalition and the Australian Democrats say they do not want to run a dual system, a with child DSR and HCCA; they want to give people the option to fall back onto the DSR only if they do not qualify for any HCCA during the previous year. There is no practical way to design such a system. This is because DSR is based on financial year eligibility and HCCA is based on eligibility in a fortnight. To pay DSR only after HCCA qualification for the year is tested would require that clients attest their HCCA qualifications 26 times a year, that is, each fortnight. This would be nonsensical and surely cannot be supported by the coalition, the Democrats or the Greens.

PARA.TAB: As well, it would be virtually impossible to determine HCCA qualifications retrospectively, which is what the Democrats' amendment proposes. To preclude any payment of DSR if families qualified for the maximum HCCA payment, even if they did not claim it or receive it, runs the strong risk of these families missing out altogether and losing up to $1,560 a year. This is when the coalition is complaining that the government amendment would result in a maximum loss of around $240 a year. It has to be recognised that there is no DSS payment that has a 100 per cent take-up rate, so the amendment that we are talking about would definitely involve people losing amounts of $1,560 a year, and most of those people would be on low incomes.

The government amendment is sounder in terms of policy and is workable for clients and administrators. In allowing people to get either the without child DSR or HCCA throughout the year, we ensure that no-one receives anything. At the end of the financial year, people can apply for the without child DSR and, if they receive less HCCA, they could get the difference between the two. There are also a number of technical problems with the way in which the amendments are drafted, which undermine the coalition's intentions. It is for those reasons that I move the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be opposing the government's proposal to disagree with the amendments that have been carried in the Senate. Let me first give some background to this matter. When the government introduced the new social security payment, known as the home child-care allowance, it did so in legislation, in the Social Security Bill.

PARA.TAB: I indicated at the time that many people did not understand what the government was about at the last election when it proposed this new initiative; it was quite clear that what the government was involved in was a sham. The government was intending to take away from a family household the benefit that was available before, known as the `dependent spouse rebate'—it used the term `cash it out'—to pay for this new home child-care allowance. The government was trying to create the impression that it was being extraordinarily generous by creating this new benefit that families were going to achieve. The government brought the home child-care allowance legislation in with great fanfare. It proposed, also with great fanfare, a very expensive advertising campaign to ensure that people were aware of this particular benefit. The government did not introduce at the same time as it introduced legislation for the home child-care allowance legislation to repeal the dependent spouse rebate. It left it until a later period. It is in the form of this bill that is now before the parliament and the amendments associated with it. The home child-care allowance was introduced some time ago. People are applying for it. But the dependent spouse rebate, which had to be repealed to pay for it, was not repealed at that time.

So the government is in a situation of difficulty, of its own making, because it did not see fit to introduce the legislation to repeal the dependent spouse rebate at the same time as it introduced the legislation for the home child-care allowance. It did not want these arrangements to be clear and transparent for all to see. The government's proposal was advanced on the basis that people were going to benefit significantly from this new home child-care allowance. People who were not previously eligible for the dependent spouse rebate were going to obtain a benefit for the first time, and they were going to obtain an additional benefit; I think it was about $4 a fortnight. In this context, there were significant advantages for people as a result of this new benefit.

What the government did not tell people was that, because it was going to introduce these new arrangements into the social security legislation and remove people from being able to get the old dependent spouse rebate on a with child rate, which was roughly equivalent to the home child-care allowance benefit, there were numbers of families—not large numbers—presently eligible for the dependent spouse rebate on a with child basis which were going to be no longer eligible for a benefit because the new rules for the home child-care allowance were applied on a different basis.

Some of the families that were going to miss out were the families that were overseas for longer than 13 weeks, and that could include aid workers, missionaries, academics, exchange students—a whole range of people with children. Other families that were going to miss out included: families with children who were dependent full-time students aged 18 to 25 whose income is less than $1,785 a year; families disqualified from the home child-care allowance as a result of more onerous social security income definitions; and families with children who were receiving the prescribed student payment.

All we have asked the government to do is to ensure that those classes of people who had a reasonable expectation that they would continue to receive benefits will be able to do so. Without all the resources that are available to the government, without the assistance of parliamentary counsel to advise, we have drafted amendments to give effect to that. We believe they achieve that objective. The government tells us that it does not think they quite achieve that objective, or that it may be difficult for the departmental officials to apply these matters. It had not brought these arguments forward before, but it is bringing them forward now.

If the government is serious that there are administrative difficulties, I encourage it to talk to me and to put those difficulties to me. We are not unreasonable people. There may be another way of drafting amendments to achieve this objective which will not present the government with the embarrassment that it believes it may now face in having to implement these provisions. If that is the case, let us sit down and talk about it. But the government has not sat down at this stage to do so. In that context, there is no way that we could accede to the government's view that our amendments should be defeated. We press our amendments. But, as I said, we are not unreasonable people. If the government has a proposal it wants to talk about, I am happy to sit down with its officials and go through it.

I want to make it very clear that there are classes of people who had an expectation that they would continue to receive benefits. There is no way that we are going to abdicate in relation to those people. There are not many of them. It is not a significant cost to revenue. It is not going to cause the budget to blow out. It will cost a great deal less than a cultural statement. It is not going to interrupt the government's fiscal strategy. There are people with children who ought to be able to receive the dependent spouse rebate at the with child rate.

The government is proposing an alternative. It would leave people being able to obtain the dependent spouse rebate on a basis where no children are involved. That is paid at a significantly lower rate than the with child payment. Of course, that is unacceptable to those on this side of the House. That is what the government's amendment to clause 57 would be designed to achieve: it would allow the dependent spouse rebate to remain in place at the lower rate, that is, the without child rate, even though people had children and may be in the circumstances I have described. So the government's amendment certainly does not meet our objective in any way, shape or form, whatsoever.

As I indicated, we are not unreasonable people on this side of the House. We are quite happy to sit down with the government to talk these things through if the government thinks these issues are important and need to be addressed in a positive and constructive way. But, at this point in time, no effort has been made to undertake that sort of task. I make it clear that, so far as the opposition is concerned, we are pressing on with our amendments at this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not hear many defensive points in the speech of the honourable member for Berowra (Mr Ruddock) for the amendments coming over from the Senate, and quite rightly so. Any amendment that says you get either all or none at all, when we have a fall-back position, seems to me to be an amendment that should not be supported by a sensible government or even a sensible opposition. The amendment says that, if people do not take up the $1,560 a year HCCA, they cannot then fall back on the rebate. That is a ludicrous situation. As I said before, the simple fact is there is no DSS pension that has a 100 per cent take-up rate. So obviously there will be losers.

PARA.TAB: Let me pick up a few points made by the opposition spokesman, the honourable member for Berowra. Those opposite go on all the time about how this is a big con job on the people of Australia. The policy speech made by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—I will read it again; this is about the third or fourth time I have read it—says:

SPEECH.PARA: This allowance—
he is talking about HCCA—
is more generous than the dependent spouse rebate it will replace . . .

The Prime Minister's policy speech was watched by millions of people around Australia, yet somehow this is supposed to be a big conjuring trick we have played on the Australian people. The only thing I can deduce from that is that the opposition was not good enough during the election campaign to say, `Here is a tricky thing; they are going to promise you this new allowance but what they are really on about is taking away your rebate.' But you never did it, so maybe you were just not good enough.

PARA.TAB: I noticed that the last time we were here the opposition spokesman moved an amendment that he thought gave, as a fall-back position, the DSR with-child rate. In actual fact his amendment did exactly the opposite. I suppose he has it right this time. He has had a bit of time to think about it. For all the reasons I outlined before, the government has moved an amendment which works in practice, is fair and looks after the people of Australia, and we will be pressing ahead with that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That amendments Nos 31 to 33 be disagreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the amendment before the House, there is nothing in the structure of sales tax in Australia which requires a credit on the grounds being sought; it is simply an extension of a concession that has already been given. It is the ultimate concession that is given to government and benevolent bodies in that they do not pay sales tax at all on the goods they use. Even allowing for the arguments put up by the opposition, the economic impact of providing the credit would appear to be marginal at best.

PARA.TAB: The remanufacturing of goods, such as photocopiers, is a labour intensive process; in fact, 85 per cent of the value added tax is labour and 15 per cent is sales tax on parts. So we are looking at about 15 per cent off 20 per cent—around three per cent. If the concern is that tax exempt bodies should have that sales tax remitted, we would have to look at the practicalities of doing so. When we are looking at making the tax system simpler—that is, reducing complexity—we would have to ask ourselves whether it is really worth adding this layer of complexity on top of the tax system, for what is at best a very marginal return.

If there is a problem in making the sales to the tax exempt sector, it is worth only a few dollars because in some industries remanufactured goods are already about 20 per cent cheaper than new goods yet carry the same warranty. If government departments do not buy those goods already it has to do with something other than sales tax, because the sales tax component of what we are talking about is very minimal.

If we were to give this concession, there could be no guarantee that the benefits would end up with the tax exempt bodies. If a Xerox photocopier were sold to a public library somewhere, what is to say that the exemption when it was sought would have been built into the price in the first place? We have no way of knowing for sure if that benefit will be passed on to the recipients intended in the amendment.

There are hundreds of good ideas for not charging sales tax on certain goods, and they all come at a price. It staggers me in some ways that, for an opposition that talks about government spending and cutting government spending, we are yet again facing an amendment which would require the government not only to look at the complexity of the tax system that is adding layers of complexity on top of the tax system but also to spend money. We are looking at ways to cut government spending—that is, should the opposition become the government—and this runs in the face of that.
Mr Leo McLeay interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not respond to that interjection, even though he is an old whip—and sometimes I make these allowances.
—He needs a whipping.

—Even though the whip said he needs a whipping. Maybe that is true. When we talked about giving credits on sales tax in the areas that mattered, we gave it where it mattered: to goods producers and exporters. I am talking about the amendments we put through this House last year in relation to repaired goods, such as tractors which went to people like farmers, and remanufactured goods which went to the miners.

PARA.TAB: From the many representations I received from opposition members, I know they thought it was unfair that if an agent used spare parts on a second-hand tractor which was sitting in his yard he would have to pay sales tax on those parts but when it was sold to a farmer he had no way of getting a rebate on the sales tax paid on the spare parts used to repair the second-hand tractor. We have fixed that amendment.

One thing I noticed at the time—if we are talking about the principle that underlies the amendment that is being moved at this time—was that this situation was not raised then. If this principle that tax exempt bodies should be given a credit for the sales tax on spare parts which go into remanufactured or repaired machinery is such a hot issue at this time, why was it not such a hot issue at that time? Or is this some newfound principle that the opposition has come up with? For all of those reasons, I have moved the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —These amendments affect sales tax on what are known as remanufactured goods in Australia which are sold after remanufacture or reconstitution to exempt users. The coalition's amendment in the Senate sets out to provide sales tax exemption for parts used in the remanufacture of goods sold or leased to exempt users such as government departments, schools, libraries and so on. There can be little objection in the ultimate goal in that the bodies likely to be beneficiaries are essentially non-profit organisations of one kind or another.

PARA.TAB: We are of the opinion that the amendment is desirable for a couple of reasons. Firstly, the existing treatment of remanufactured goods was not apparently intended by the new sales tax legislation and is inconsistent with the sales tax treatment of both new and imported remanufactured goods. Secondly, the current treatment is a disincentive to what is a burgeoning local remanufacturing industry. More than that, it is business of a kind which can be categorised as small. We pay lip-service to the role of small business in this place but when we have an opportunity, for little or no cost, to give some sort of sensible encouragement to those in a particular sector we fail to do so. The government is guilty on this occasion in opposing these Senate amendments.

Remanufacturing has a beneficial part to play in the Australian economy and particularly for that part which is serviced by what we have come to call small businesses. Even the Greens and the Australian Democrats in the Senate supported this measure. I call on the government to give its support to the amendment.

The amendment will encourage the remanufacturing industry, which has great potential for significant future growth. There is growth in overseas demand for remanufactured goods. Australia's remanufactured goods are also substitutes for new and remanufactured imported goods. In a small but nevertheless understandable way we are talking about import substitution opportunities. Obviously, there are also significant employment and recycling advantages.

The government, and especially the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht, made it clear some time ago that it would have discussions with industry about this very issue. That was encouraging to the coalition. I, and I am sure some of my colleagues, find the government's response to this amendment disappointing in the extreme.

In the bill, the government is extending the availability of sales tax exemptions to parts used to repair goods to be exported. The coalition amendment goes one step further and follows the logic in the same direction. It is as simple as that. We seek to restore the status quo of the sales tax position as at 1 January 1993.

It is no good for the government to say that for decades the law was unclear, because the law operated very clearly in relation to this issue. The restoration of the sales tax exemption, while generating significant benefits for the economy and encouraging the use of recycled products, will have a very minor impact on revenue. The Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) said that the government is worried about the benefits being passed on. I know the Assistant Treasurer in his own mind and heart understands that, with a burgeoning remanufacturing industry, competition will take care of a business that does not structure the price it sells—in this case, remanufactured goods—for and it will simply lose its share of the market and will not survive because it will not be price competitive. I recommend that the House accept the Senate's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the point raised by the honourable member for Curtin (Mr Rocher), I say that, if we compare remanufactured sales, overwhelmingly we find that two-thirds of the market is sold to bodies that produce goods, and therefore will be tax exempt, and where a credit will be given. Given that that is the case, local remanufacturers are advantaged in that market. In the majority of the market, local manufacturers have a natural advantage over the importers because the sales tax on imports is on the labour plus the parts. As I said before, the sales tax on parts in Australia is minimal indeed. For all of those reasons I move that the government's amendment be accepted.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Gear's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Mr Gear) agreed to:
That Mrs Silvia Smith, Mr Leo McLeay and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendments Nos 31 to 33 of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gear The Hon G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendments Nos 31 to 33 of the Senate, I present the reasons which are being circulated to honourable members.

PARA.TAB: The reasons read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the Senate's amendments nos 31, 32 and 33

SPEECH.PARA: Senate amendments nos 31.32 and 33 are not acceptable because:

A credit ground for parts used in remanufacturing goods sold to exempt users is unwarranted in terms of the basic structure of the sales tax law. The purpose of analogous credit grounds in the sales tax law for goods producers is to prevent the `cascading' of sales tax through different levels of the production chain. Exempt users are predominantly service providers and therefore not taxable on their outputs, so there is no question of needing to ensure their inputs are free of sales tax to avoid `cascading'.
The amendment would also introduce unwarranted complexity into the tax law and its administration.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Gear) agreed to:
That the committee's reasons be adopted.
Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McHugh The Hon J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bill also contains a supplementary rule that deals with the positioning of labels where there are two or more representations on a product, one saying that there is some connection with Australia and the other saying that there is some connection with a country outside Australia. These two pieces of information must be given equal prominence and be as close to each other as possible.

PARA.TAB: I cannot conclude this outline of the scheme without referring to the Australian made logo. The green and gold kangaroo in a triangle has been a successful marketing and promotional tool for government, industry and the Advance Australia Foundation, which administers the logo on behalf of the Commonwealth. It has achieved this because it has been a valuable aid to consumers who want to buy Australian goods. The bill provides that the term `Australian made' may be used in conjunction with the logo and requires that the logo must be accompanied by one or other of the authorised terms, that is, product of or produce of Australia or made in Australia. The bill thus ensures that the logo will only be used on goods which really are Australian and that it will continue to be an authentication of the claims made on the goods.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments made to the Trade Practices Act by this bill will make sure that consumers get reliable information about the Australian origin of products. Informed consumers are an important prerequisite for market efficiency. Although there may be some initial cost to industry—in many cases industry has already changed to comply with the new scheme—in the long term it will benefit from having a reliable scheme that consumers understand and have confidence in. Any relabelling costs will be minimised by the lengthy phase-in period.

PARA.TAB: The government has already budgeted for an education campaign for consumers and industry. The campaign will help industry decide on the appropriate labelling for its products. The government intends to do this through a series of guidelines developed by the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs in consultation with the Trade Practices Commission, industry and consumers.

I turn now to the matters raised by the committee in its report. The committee has recommended that I make a statement in Parliament on the procedures for formulating guidelines to assist industry to comply with the legislation, and that I give an explanation on the consultation mechanism. Some members of the committee have suggested that the guidelines be written before the legislation is passed. Let me set out what happens at the moment and how I envisage any guidelines being developed.

At the moment, officers of the federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs and the Trade Practices Commission give individual oral and written guidelines every day of the week to Australian businesses on how to comply with various provisions of the Trade Practices Act. That is their job. They administer and enforce the law and part of that job is to help industry understand and comply with the law. In addition to this individual advice, the commission issues press releases about particular problems. In December 1990 it issued one on orange juice. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The description `Made in Australia' . . . should only be applied when those operations that gave the product its essential nature took place in Australia . . . In the case of fruit juice, the country of origin was the country where the `fruity' nature originated. The addition of water would not be considered by consumers to be the `essential' quality of the product.
This is a guideline for industry. In other words, juice made from imported concentrate cannot be labelled `Made in Australia'.

PARA.TAB: The commission also issued a more general guideline in 1990 on labelling the origin of goods. It outlines the law; it gives details of relevant court cases; it gives advice on the sorts of matters a business should take into account when considering whether to label its goods `Made in Australia'; it says that, in borderline cases, if in doubt err on the side of caution by describing the processes that happened in Australia rather than claiming that the product was made in Australia.

The guidelines that are proposed for this legislation would be modelled on the commission's 1990 guideline. They would cover the same material, the law and court cases, plus information about the other provisions of the bill, based on the explanatory memorandum. However, it is envisaged that, instead of giving general advice, the particular conditions of particular industries could be dealt with.

For example, guidelines for the paper industry are likely to say quite categorically that paper which is imported in rolls and cut to size and packed in Australia cannot be labelled `Made in Australia'. This situation is a clear analogy with the case involving rolls of sticky tape which were only cut to size in Australia and could not be labelled `Made in Australia'.

Guidelines for the chemical industry would point out that where the active ingredient—for example the screening agent in sunscreen—is imported the product probably cannot be labelled `Made in Australia'. The essential characteristic which is being promoted has not been acquired in Australia. Advice for the footwear industry is likely to discuss the problem of whether shoes made from uppers which are already shaped when imported can be labelled `Made in Australia'.

In all cases, the bureau and the Trade Practices Commission would consult with industry bodies and individual manufacturers about their manufacturing processes, the nature and source of components, the particular conditions that apply and any problems that arise so that relevant and useful advice could be given.

There are a number of advantages in bringing all the disparate bits of advice together in uniform guidelines in this way. It ensures that the advice is consistent. It is not always easy to ensure that an officer in Perth and another in Brisbane are giving consistent advice to businesses asking the same questions. More importantly, it protects industry. It is a defence to a prosecution under the Trade Practices Act that the defendant reasonably relied on information supplied. The fact that any guidelines could be used as a defence should not be taken to mean that the guidelines will in any way affect the law as it will be applied by the courts.

The guidelines as currently proposed will have no legislative force. They will have no effect on the interpretation of the legislation in particular cases. No legal obligations or responsibilities can be imposed on industry through the guidelines. If the guidelines attempted to do such a thing they would be of no effect. The law as set out in the act will always prevail over anything that is said in guidelines. The only legal role the guidelines will have is as a defence for industry.

It seems to me that we have a number of options. We could attempt the unprecedented exercise of drawing up guidelines before the legislation is passed. This would mean going to industry and asking it to invest time and resources in drawing up guidelines to explain some legislation which is not yet passed and which may be amended, or not passed at all. It seems to me that if we went to industry with this proposition it would be properly outraged about the waste of time and resources.

In the case of food, it would be an even bigger waste of time and effort to make guidelines now. The National Food Authority has been considering for some time amendments to the origin labelling standards in the Australian food standards code. Guidelines for the food industry should wait until the standards in the code are finalised. The sooner this legislation is passed, the sooner that can happen.

Another option would be to stop giving advice to industry. We could issue no guidelines and I could direct the Trade Practices Commission and the federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs not to answer queries. We can say to industry, `You work it out and if you get it wrong we will see you in court.' That would be an abrogation of our responsibility. Or we can do what is normally done when new legislation is passed, and what industry wants us to do and what we are proposing to do. We can draw up guidelines in consultation with industry which will help industry understand and comply with the law.

The committee has also asked for an explanation of the interpretation and meaning of `essential character or qualities'. As honourable members will recall, this phrase is used in the definition applying to `Made in Australia'. From what I have already said about orange juice, shoes, sunscreen and paper, it should be clear that the meaning given to this phrase will depend very much on the particular circumstances of the case. In this, it is no different from other provisions in the Trade Practices Act. For example, who would care to give a definition of `misleading and deceptive conduct' which would cover every possible case likely to arise?

The bill itself gives some examples drawn from existing case law of when goods acquire their essential character or qualities. These examples generalise to a certain extent the specific circumstances considered in the cases. Any further generalisation would hinder the court's consideration of the particular circumstances of each case.

The role of the guidelines is to give guidance, based on the cases, on the factors to be considered in the particular circumstances of each industry. I add here that, in two years of consultation, industry has consistently asked that the `essential character' test remain. Industry is familiar with this test and has been applying it for at least the past eight years.

The committee also asked for a definition of `major component or ingredient'. For a product to be labelled `Product of Australia', each major component or ingredient has to come from Australia. The bill contains no definition of `major' because one definition would not be appropriate for the range of goods covered.

Honourable members may have noticed that none of my examples to date has been about food. This was done to emphasise that the bill covers more than food. But `Product of Australia' is likely to be used most often in relation to food. Australia produces a wide range of all-Australian food—cheese, fruit juices, tinned fruit and vegetables, nuts, cereals, bread, sugar, pasta, wine and a host of other items.

Food labelling is the responsibility of the National Food Authority and the Commonwealth, state and territory health ministers meeting as the National Food Standards Council. As I mentioned, the authority is now considering amendments to the origin labelling standards for food, which include a definition of `major ingredient'. Essentially, it was defined by weight. For other products, consultation with industry will give some indication of what products are likely to qualify for the `Product of Australia' label. Timber products, clothing and some plastics spring to mind.

Another matter which concerned the committee was the position of suppliers who source a major ingredient from Australia for part of the year and import it for the rest of the year. The committee seems to have accepted what I said in evidence on this question, but I am very happy to say it again. Where a product is subject to predictable seasonal variations in the source of supply of components, it is up to the manufacturer to decide whether to use one labelling run to cover all situations or to change labels as the source of supply changes.

If there is sufficient market advantage in identifying the goods which are all Australian as all-Australian, then companies will do this. If there is a perception that the return will not cover the cost, then companies can use labelling which covers all situations. An example which I showed the committee was fruit juice labelled something like `Blended from a mix of high quality Australian juices and imported juices according to seasonal variation'.

Neither the government nor Australian consumers will accept producers labelling their goods all year as being all-Australian when for part of the year they contain imported ingredients or components. There are acceptable solutions to that problem which are currently being used by suppliers.

As the committee points out, the defence in section 85 of the Trade Practices Act, which relates to causes beyond the defendant's control, will not normally apply to these predictable variations in supply. As I mentioned in evidence, it might, however, apply to such unpredictable events as crop failures.

In recent months there has been concern in some quarters, particularly Tasmania, about identifying the regional origin of goods. This arises because the bill prohibits the use of such terms as `Product of Tasmania' or `Made in Hobart'.
