However, as the committee notes, the bill provides companies with plenty of other opportunities to promote their goods on a regional basis while still meeting the requirements of the bill. One way of doing this is to add the name of the place to one of the authorised terms: for example, `Product of Australia—Tasmania' or `Made in Australia at Hobart'.

The government is planning to move an amendment to section 65VE(2) of the bill to make it quite clear that the legislation does permit identification of a particular place in this way as part of an express and unambiguous representation that the goods are Australian. This amendment says that a representation in the table may be followed by words that identify a particular place in Australia or a particular part of Australia. The words `followed by' have caused some concern.

Some people have suggested that this means that all references to place have to follow the authorised term. This is a misunderstanding of the amendment. The amendment is in the section dealing with express and unambiguous claims. It applies only to the positioning of place names when they are used as part of an express and unambiguous claim made under proposed new section 65VE. It does not apply to the positioning of such statements as `Tasmanian cheese', `traditional Tasmanian shortbread' or `proudly Tasmanian', which are covered by section 65VJ, or statements like `brewed in Hobart' which fall within section 65VG. The bill has no provision which governs the placement, size or number of these representations, provided the goods really are Australian. The supplementary explanatory memorandum clarifies this point.

The committee recommended that the phase-in period for the legislation be extended from 12 months to 18 months. I accept this recommendation and the government will be moving an amendment to the bill to effect this change. The committee also recommended that, where labelling changes are considered prohibitively expensive, producers be allowed to seek exemption for a further 12 months. The government's view is that, in a market where producers regularly change packaging and labelling for design or image reasons or because they are running a competition, 18 months seems more than enough time to make whatever changes are necessary to meet the requirements of the legislation. It is also unlikely that producers order labelling or packaging for periods of more than 18 months.

The committee has recommended that I say something about the inter-relationship between the requirements of the Codex Alimentarius and the bill. The Codex Alimentarius Commission is a United Nations body which develops food standards for adoption as national standards by member countries. Australia is a member. As a food matter, Codex comes within the responsibility of the Minister for Human Resources and Health and the National Food Authority. The committee received advice from the National Food Authority on this very question and I can add nothing to that.

According to that advice, Australia's obligation under Codex is to adopt Codex standards to the extent possible. Its standard for the origin labelling of food is that, when food undergoes processing in a second country which changes its nature, the processing country shall be considered to be the country of origin for labelling purposes. This requirement is clearly different from and possibly less rigorous than what is currently required under Australian law for `Made in Australia'.

I agree wholeheartedly with the committee's conclusion that it would not be in Australia's interest to allow imported food, which had undergone minimal processing in Australia, to be labelled `Made in Australia' if the use of that term was likely to mislead consumers and be contrary to Australian law. As the bill makes no change to the meaning of `Made in Australia', we are already out of step, to this extent, with the Codex standard. Our definitions are more rigorous.

The bill also gives a special definition to the term `Product of Australia', so that Australian industry and consumers can identify all-Australian products. The committee accepted that the terms we have chosen and the meanings ascribed to them are the most practical and appropriate labels. But some members of the committee have also expressed concern that Australia is doing something different from the rest of the world and that this will rebound on us.

As far as the bill is concerned, it has no implications for our obligations under GATT. Evidence to the committee from officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade made this quite clear. This is because the bill does not define what `Made in another country' or `Product of another country' means. Other countries may go on using those terms to mean whatever is acceptable to them on goods which will be imported into Australia. We have legislated for what claims can be made about Australia in the Australian market. This is surely our prerogative. We have been careful to do this in a way which will not impact on our trading partners, except to stop them misleading Australian consumers. The fear of retaliation is therefore quite unfounded.

I hope that I have answered all the concerns of the committee about this important piece of legislation. The bill gives consumers what they have been demanding—a means of identifying all-Australian goods and the removal of the confusion arising from the wide variety of terms currently used to claim Australian origin. It does this in a way which protects Australian jobs and supports Australian industry.
I commend the bill to the House and hope you read it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson Mr M.J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is regrettable that after the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) speaks we are no closer to resolving the concerns of the Australian consumers. Undoubtedly, that will be brought out again within the next 24 hours. We are debating today the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill 1994, which the government has at last introduced into the parliament. There has been long and sustained criticism and calls for origin labelling to be addressed. This has come from all sectors of Australian life including the Trade Practices Commission which, for over a decade, has been decrying the lack of uniformity in this area.

PARA.TAB: This legislation has undergone a long journey over the last two years. It has been through two government working parties and a House of Representatives and Senate inquiry. However, the bill as it appears today has been the subject of much criticism from the Australian public, Australian workers, producers and processors. I will be drawing to the attention of the House the comments, concerns and quite vehement criticism of a large number of people within those groups. The labelling of Australian products is an issue about which the Australian public has strong, definite and sincere opinions. Basically, the Australian public has requested that, if Australian goods make the claim to be Australian, then that is what they must be.

The way the government has presented this legislation has not met these expectations. The Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill seeks to introduce a new voluntary scheme to govern labelling on domestic consumer goods that represent they have an Australian content. It does this by inserting a new division 1B into part V—the fair trading section—of the Trade Practices Act. At the moment, no specific requirements clearly define the terms to be used on goods that claim to have Australian content. Presently, country of origin labelling is mainly covered by section 53(eb) of the Trade Practices Act, which creates a specific offence for the making of a false or misleading representation concerning the place of origin of goods. Honourable members may not be aware that penalties are set at $100,000 for corporations and $20,000 for individuals.

A wide range of terms are currently in use to describe the Australian content in goods, but members of the public have always maintained that they want to know whether the goods they are buying are Australian and they want the labels to contain the truth. This bill therefore attempts to specify and define the terms and conditions under which varying amounts of Australian content can be described. Australian producers and industry are rightly proud of their Australian product. It is known for its high quality, clean and green content, and is the result of generations of research and development into the ensuing excellent product. This is what the Australian public recognises, responds to and wishes to buy.

These same qualities have been the subject of government promotion campaigns, whether it be in the push for Australian goods into Asia or the Buy Australian campaign, which over the last year the government has spent $15 million promoting and educating the public about. When I say that the government has spent $15 million, we should remember that it is $15 million of taxpayers' and consumers' money. Therefore, it was with alarm that the government, through this bill, introduced a category `Made in Australia', which ran counter to all these moves. Under the government bill, there are two categories for Australian goods. Category A, called `Produce/Product of Australia', covers goods where Australia is the place of origin of each major ingredient or component. Under this category, all operations involved in the manufacture or production of the goods happened in Australia. Category B, called `Made in Australia', covers goods that acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia.

Further, under this legislation, goods with lesser Australian content may state this on the label. If the goods do not qualify for the above categories, the label may describe the production or pre-production step that took place in Australia, plus identify the place of origin of the components or ingredients. This would lead to a description such as `Packed/ assembled/built in Australia from imported/Australian ingredients'.

All other terms that describe the Australian content of the goods will be prohibited. The only other permitted labelling under this bill is the use of the Australian made certification mark. The green and gold triangle kangaroo logo can be used if combined with category A or category B descriptors.

For goods with Australian and foreign representations, the foreign representation must be as prominent and as close as possible to the Australian representation. The coalition supports the government's proposal of goods in category A being labelled as `Product of Australia' or `Produce of Australia' where all major ingredients or components originate in Australia and all manufacturing has taken place in Australia.
The bill does not define the word `major', and there is an element of uncertainty as to what `major' means. The explanatory memorandum states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . what will be considered major, or minor, will vary depending on the type of product. For example, in food products small amounts of imported seasonings and flavourings may be acceptable in a product labelled `Product of Australia', but in electronic goods the smallest components may be the most vital to the operation of the product.
Also the minister has reassured the House and Senate inquiries that this will be discussed with industry and dealt with when the guidelines are being drawn up in consultation with industry.

PARA.TAB: With goods described as `Product of Australia' or `Produce of Australia', the public can be assured that the label clarifies that the goods are virtually wholly Australian. However, with the next main Australian category in the government's bill, `Made in Australia', the minister on various occasions when describing the scheme has described this category as covering a situation where products have components of which some or even all—I stress `even all'—are imported but the goods are made here. With such products being labelled `Made in Australia' questions have to be asked. Do these products truthfully describe their Australian condition and content? Is this what the public understands a product labelled `Made in Australia' means? Is this the understanding of Australian consumers when they set out to deliberately buy an Australian product, as so many of them are now doing? I say to them, `Hear, hear!' On this side of the House, we encourage them to do so. Our amendments when they are passed by the Senate, as we believe they will be, will ensure that when they go shopping they will know they are buying Australian made when it says `Australian made'.

Survey after survey supports the understanding of `Made in Australia' as being, in the main, a truly Australian product. According to the Quadrant survey, 74 per cent of consumers believe products labelled `Made in Australia' should not contain imported ingredients. The recent CSIRO national nutrition survey found that 98 per cent of people agreed that food should not be labelled `Australian made' unless it was both grown and processed entirely in Australia. The Coles survey showed that 89 per cent of shoppers, up from 86 per cent the previous year, preferred to buy locally manufactured food products.

There are many problem areas with the inclusion of imported ingredients or components in the category `Made in Australia'. Objections have been raised arising from situations such as imported Canadian pork being processed into ham and bacon in Australia and sold as being made in Australia; from orange and other imported fruit concentrates in varying proportions being blended in Australia and called `Made in Australia'; with non-Australian peanuts becoming `Made in Australia' peanut butter; similarly with foreign sourced dried fruit in cereals and biscuits; with imported paper cut to size in Australia and sold as `Made in Australia'; with both imported tomatoes and navy beans made into `Made in Australia' baked beans; and with overseas fruit being made into `Made in Australia' pies. The list goes on and most of these products mentioned have been or still are the subject of anti-dumping and countervailing actions and duties.

There has to be honesty and truth in the labelling or the whole point of having country of origin labelling legislation is defeated. Accordingly, the coalition proposes to put forward amendments to proposed section 65VE(2). These amendments will reclassify `Made in Australia' into category A, and consequently goods labelled as `Made in Australia' must also meet the conditions of Australia being the place of origin of each major ingredient or component of the goods and all operations involved in the manufacture or production of the goods must have happened in Australia.

Category B will then be labelled as `Manufactured in Australia' and will have to meet the conditions of the goods acquiring their essential character or qualities in Australia. This category will not require the imported contents to be listed on the label, although it will have a larger proportion of non-Australian ingredients or components than category A.

It is proposed in the government bill that when only a production or pre-production step has taken place in Australia the imported components or ingredients must be stated when the products claim on their label to have some Australian content. Goods which qualify under the separate requirement for the Australian made logo can simultaneously display it if they also qualify under this legislation for the labels `Produce of Australia', `Product of Australia', `Made in Australia' or `Manufactured in Australia'.

The government has run a most successful campaign to promote the Australian made campaign. It has spent $15 million of taxpayers' money over the last eight years promoting the Australian product to the Australian consumer. In this year's budget the campaign received a further $1.5 million. The minister has expressed her concern that jobs would be lost if the Australian made logo could not be used on all qualifying goods. The coalition amendments will achieve the same result as the government bill in this regard, which also restricted it to goods that acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia. The minister need have no further fears of job loss or loss of effectiveness of the government's Australian made campaign.

The coalition supports the government amendment to allow the addition of a regional name to the category A and category B labels, which the government has foreshadowed in its report to the Senate inquiry. The dissenting report from the coalition members of the Senate committee stressed the need for regional differentiation to be allowed. This amendment will allow the regional distinction to appear on the official label with labels such as `Product of Australia—Tasmania' or `Made in Australia—Margaret River'.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Bendigo?

—Bendigo, I believe, was also mentioned in one of the Senate inquiries, and quite rightly so. The coalition welcomes the minister's acceptance of the House of Representatives committee report, ably put forward by its coalition members, that the phase-in period for this legislation should be extended from the original 12 months to 18 months. Particularly from the perspective of the impact of these new requirements on industry, the coalition will be supporting the government on this amendment.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is also proposing an amendment to proposed section 65VB, the definition of place of origin of marine produce, to overcome the uncertainty presented by the present definition that Australia is to be regarded as the place of origin of all marine produce that was first landed in Australia, regardless of where it was caught or taken. The amendment will ensure that marine produce labelled as `Produce of Australia' or `Made in Australia' will have been caught and processed so as to meet Australian conditions.

The area covered by the Trade Practices Act on origin labelling is complex and faces the difficult task of being the solution of all things to all interests. Australian industry has, in the vast majority of cases, been supportive of bringing certainty to the area by means of specific labels for specific conditions. The Australian public—individually and through consumer bodies—has been very expressive and certain in its commitment to `Made in Australia' being a truthful label and describing goods that are truly Australian.

The Australian work force and union movement, in a most vocal and forceful way, have criticised the government's definition of `Made in Australia' and asked for change, as has much of Australian primary and secondary industry, which will have to bear the cost of adopting and adjusting to the new scheme. The government has committed itself to an education program to explain to the public what the new Australian labelling scheme means. Following the coalition amendments, this should now be a more logical and easier process which reflects the expressed opinions of the Australian consumer, industry and worker.

This is an issue where the widely accepted public perception of terms such as `Produce of Australia' and `Made in Australia' are very important. In this case, any scheme that is designed to prevent false and misleading representation based on country of origin labelling will work only if founded on public perceptions of what is truthful and correct labelling. A large number of organisations have vehemently attacked the government on this legislation. I believe that Martin Ferguson was scurrying around the halls of Parliament House today and having lunch with people. Do you know why he was here?

TALK.START.PARA: —To support our amendments.
—To support the coalition amendments to this bill.
—The integrity of `Made in Australia'.

—As the Leader of the National Party has said, `The integrity of "Made in Australia"'. The most vehement critic of this legislation has been the ACTU. Even with the involvement of Martin Ferguson today, the minister has still not changed her mind. I find that quite extraordinary. Out of interest, I will read a letter sent to the Secretary to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs dated 25 May 1994:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Griffiths,

The ACTU is concerned about the inadequacy of the proposed amendment to the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill 1994 and its major thrust. The ACTU Executive has unanimously endorsed this submission to change two sections of the Bill in order to address our concern.
I will be fascinated to hear what government members say about the ACTU's view on all this. It will be a very interesting 24 hours. Under the heading `Concern', it is stated:

The Bill's focus on representations about Australian origin carried on consumer goods supplied in Australia fails to recognise the widely held public perception that goods marked "Made in Australia" denotes that Australia was the place of origin of each major ingredient or component of the product on offer.

What an extraordinary approach by this government to go against a group that ostensibly holds itself out to represent Australian workers, that publicly funds and supports, mans polling booths, and puts enormous amounts of its members' money into supporting this government. It is extraordinary that the ACTU has come out and so vehemently opposed an anti-Australian piece of legislation, which this is. It is anti-Australian, anti-Australian consumer and anti-Australian industry. That is why the ACTU is so vehemently opposed to this objectionable piece of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Let us see what Australian industry thinks about this piece of legislation and what it thinks about the coalition's amendments. A heading in an SPC media release dated 19 October reads, `Coalition and Democrats Sink Federal Government's "Labelgate" Legislation.' SPC, that great Australian company, has described this legislation as `labelgate'.

TALK.START.PARA: —SPC!
—I fully understand the minister's getting so upset about this. The press release issued by the Chairman of SPC, Mr John Corboy, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Moves by the Federal Coalition and Democrats to amend the Federal Government's controversial MADE IN AUSTRALIA labelling legislation is a victory for commonsense and a positive initiative which would be welcomed by every Australian farmer and consumer,
Australian food manufacturer SPC said today.
Mr Corboy said: "The protection of the Made in Australia trademark because of its national importance is a cornerstone to underpinning future employment in Australia."
Mr Corboy further states:
"Australian consumers have a right to a clearly defined labelling system in which they can use with confidence."

"The Coalition and the Democrats have listened and are in tune with the consumers of Australia, the workers of Australia and the farmers of Australia and we now call on the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Jeanette McHugh to accept the amendments with grace—
as indeed I do—
and get on with the job of protecting the integrity of the Made in Australia labelling trademark."

Indeed, it would be very rare that I or anyone else on this side of the House would join forces with Mr Martin Ferguson. But on behalf of Mr Ferguson and me, the Australian consumers, farmers and industry I ask the minister: please accept the amendments with grace.

PARA.TAB: Golden Circle is another Australian company employing Australian men and women and using Australian products. Like SPC, it is a good Australian. Golden Circle's press release dated 18 October states:

SPEECH.PARA: Golden Circle Limited has called on the Federal Government to ensure that the labelling statement `Made in Australia' means just what it says.
Mr Barry Kelly, the Managing Director of Golden Circle, states:
"I think Australians have an expectation that only goods actually made in Australia, with all-Australian ingredients, should be allowed to carry the endorsement of `Made in Australia'" . . .
"It is clear that consumers feel quite a degree of confusion about the labelling of various products and I am afraid that the proposed changes to the law will only make that confusion worse.
I have another letter dated 1 September addressed to my colleague the shadow minister for consumers affairs, Senator Ron Boswell. It is from Rocklea Spinning Mills Pty Limited and it states:
Dear Senator Boswell

I am writing in support of the campaign being waged by the consumer associations, food producers and trade unionists against watering down of the requirements governing the use of `Made in Australia' labelling.

The media release distributed by the alliance on 19 August pointed up the essential requirement that there be honesty in labelling. While the alliance has made its case in the particular terms appropriate to the food industry the merits of the case are by no means confined to the food industry.

As you may be aware, Rocklea, the company which I represent, is a spinner of yarn from Australian produced cotton and wool. You might also be aware that in recent times we have come under severe pressure from subsidized imported cotton products against which we are seeking countervailing action.

We agree with the alliance in its claim that Australian shoppers prefer to buy goods which are made in Australia and it is the truth in this label which is a major aid in our effort to defend ourselves against subsidized imports.

It is very important for the jobs of our employees and the continued expansion of our industry that our Australian products can be clearly distinguished from the imported products made from cotton which is dumped on our shores.
The letter goes on:
In considering this issue I would ask you to bear in mind that truth in labelling is important not just for food and textile industries. The issue is wider than that.
Indeed it is. It continues:
It is important across the whole range of Australian industry.
After all, the Australian shopper has a right to know that the product they are buying is true to its label.
I turn to the National Farmers Federation's press release dated 19 October, which states:
Opposition right on country of origin labelling.

The National Farmers' Federation has commended the Federal Opposition for its move to change proposed labelling laws to more accurately reflect the origin of a product, including its components and ingredients.
NFF President, Mr Donald McGauchie, said farmers had argued vigorously for the term `Made in Australia' to be used only to describe goods manufactured in Australia from Australian ingredients.
`The Opposition's amendments will ensure that `Made in Australia' means exactly what it says,' he said.
`Goods which contain imported ingredients should be more accurately described by the term `Manufactured in Australia'.
`This is the only way to ensure that consumers have accurate, unambiguous information about the country of origin on all product labels.
`This, after all, was the intention of the legislation in the first place.
`The Government's proposal that `Made in Australia' be applied to `goods which acquired their essential character in Australia' is vague and confusing.'

This legislation has been an extraordinary process. I have deep concerns about the process of withdrawal of the legislation. It almost got to the barrier once. It was withdrawn so that the legitimate concern could be expressed, and I respect the minister for that. But the problem is that she is no further down the track of protecting the rights of Australian consumers and industry than she was when this process started two years ago.

PARA.TAB: All honourable members in this House are fully aware that Australian consumers will have no confidence that, when we come out of this process, they will have any guarantees about truth in labelling. If we listen to any talkback radio show, time after time people are saying, `I want to be guaranteed that when I buy a product that says "Made in Australia" it is wholly made in Australia.' We can talk about all these peripheral issues, but that is the guts of this question and it remains unanswered in this legislation. When we get to further debate about the amendments, I will proceed with that matter even further.

I offer the minister a large olive branch. If she comes on board with these amendments I will publicly go out and praise her for seeing commonsense in relation to this legislation. I might even join forces with Mr Martin Ferguson. We might duly go out together, stand on the same stage and say, `The minister has finally listened to the workers of Australia, the farmers of Australia, the producers of Australia and the consumers of Australia.'

What a coup it would be for this House to realise and accept that the government's legislation is doing no more than condemning the Australian public to a situation where it will come out of this legislation with no clearer view of what `Made in Australia' means. This comes at a time when this country is desperately trying to get itself back on its feet, desperately trying to encourage people to buy Australian, desperately trying to encourage Australian farmers and manufacturers. For us to come out of this process without any clearer view about labelling in this country and about what `Made in Australia' means would be an extraordinary tragedy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a performance by the member for Ballarat!
—I am glad you approve.
—No doubt about it. He rants and raves and carries on in here. It makes you wonder whether he is fair dinkum.
—Aren't you concerned about the Australian consumer?
—After all the claims he makes about it being anti-Australia, all of a sudden he is a great ally of the ACTU.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Rocher)—Order! The honourable member should address his remarks through the chair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was, but the other member was interjecting instead of sticking to what he should have been talking about. He was trying to tell us that he is a friend of the ACTU. We all know in this place that there are no friends of the ACTU on that side. For him to stand up here and be so hypocritical is quite amazing.

PARA.TAB: I would rather talk about the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill 1994 because it is very important. A lot of consideration has been given to the matters before us. I am particularly pleased to rise and support this bill, which amends the Trade Practices Act 1974. It has been a long time coming. It is a relief to finally see this bill before the House. Hopefully, there will be some sensible debate. I am sure there will be from this side, anyway.

It was certainly gratifying to read the majority report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the bill, which recommended the legislation be passed with the amendments already proposed by the government. Perhaps we can finally get some work done on this bill, provided that the opposition sees fit to lend some bipartisan support for this important piece of legislation. Given the comments made earlier today, and the press release that Senator Boswell put out in the last 24 hours, it does not appear that there will be much support. It is certainly a pleasure to support legislation that makes it easier for Australians to buy Australian. There is no doubt about the commitments of members on this side of the House to Australia and Australians.

The purpose of the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill 1994 is to help introduce a scheme that will govern representations about the origin of consumer goods. The bill seeks to do this by amending part 5 of the Trade Practices Act 1974 in order to deal with the method of labelling goods which are claimed to be made, manufactured, packed or designed in Australia. The bill focuses on representations made about Australian origin on consumer goods.

The scheme set out in the bill focuses on representations about Australian origin carried on consumer goods supplied in Australia. This scheme will not be applicable to goods intended for export nor does it make any provision about representations on imported goods. Only where imported goods make some statement that could be construed as representing Australian origin does the bill require that further information be provided regarding the national origin of the product. This is a particularly important aspect of this bill. We are all no doubt aware of stories about souvenir items, such as toy kangaroos, which masquerade as Australian products but which, in reality, come from Taiwan and Korea in most cases. We have all seen them on sale, complete with Australian flags or pictures of kangaroos, when the only thing that happened here was that it was packed in this country. We have even seen members of the opposition displaying Australian flags where the stems on which those flags were sitting were made in Taiwan. We need to be conscious of that. Consumers deserve the right to know when they are buying Australian, and this bill will help them in that endeavour.

The issue of labelling generally has had a long history and covers not only the place of origin of goods. Unfortunately, no thorough and uniform scheme covering those areas has evolved. The lack of any comprehensive uniform scheme governing such conduct has been the subject of criticism from all quarters for a considerable period. This bill seeks to standardise that situation. As early as 1977, the report by the Trade Practices Commission on packaging and labelling laws in Australia was particularly scathing about the lack of uniformity in the area. It commented:

SPEECH.PARA: No system of State legislative implementation will succeed in any long term, reasonably efficient sense. If Australia cannot obtain packaging and labelling, and contents legislation of a uniform nature, it is an admission that Australia is not a common market. The small nature of Australian production runs is not problem enough. To subdivide these runs into runs by each individual state because of varying requirements is the height of folly in any system of rational economic planning.

As far as country of origin labelling is concerned, the issue is regulated by a number of Commonwealth and state acts, supplemented by various voluntary schemes. The major influence on labelling comes from the misleading and deceptive conduct provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. Section 53 of that act specifically deals with false representations concerning the place or origin of goods. Typical descriptions which can be the subject of litigation under the act include `Made in Australia', `Produce of Australia' and `Packaged in Australia'. To date, there has been little litigation concerning the section, and it is clear from the reported cases that what the consumer understands by the phrase `Made in Australia' will vary on a case-by-case basis. It has been held that a good is `made' where it obtains its essential quality and character. Section 53(eb) is one provision which has been mirrored in all states and territories.

PARA.TAB: In addition to the Trade Practices Act 1974 provisions, standards dealing with labelling the country of origin can be made by the National Food Authority, established under the National Food Authority Act 1991. The NFA was established primarily to develop and recommend standards for food, although its objectives also include the provision of information to consumers about food and the promotion of fair trading practices.

There is in force at present the Australian Food Standards Code which is adopted by reference under the food legislation of the states and territories. Clause A1(4) of the code requires all packaged foods to carry a statement of the country in which the food was made or produced. Where food contains ingredients which originate in another country, compliance with the clause occurs if the label identifies both the country where the food was packed and either the country of origin of the ingredients or the fact that the ingredients are imported.

Many of the problems regarding labelling have arisen partly because the states and territories also have a complex network of legislation dealing with labelling requirements, which vary significantly from state to state. Although this lack of uniformity has been alleviated somewhat by the mutual recognition acts in all jurisdictions, the legislative framework applies in a piecemeal way to different types of goods in different states.

For example, in New South Wales, the Fair Trading (Product Information Standards) Regulation 1992 prescribes that leather goods made in Australia must be marked with `Made in Australia', `Manufactured by'—followed by the manufacturer and state—or marked with the country in which the goods were made. In Tasmania, the Goods (Trade Descriptions) Act 1971 prohibits the sale of boots or shoes manufactured outside of Australia, unless they bear a trade description citing the country of manufacture. In Queensland, the Fair Trading Regulations 1989 specifies that shoes manufactured overseas shall include the country of manufacture in figures at least 2.5 millimetres high on the outside sole, inside upper or heel of the sock lining. As you can see, this situation is just ridiculous.

The Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill that we are debating here is an admirable attempt to address this problem by introducing a rationalised scheme. It will rationalise the use of descriptions on labels to identify the `Australianness' of goods sold on the domestic market. The fact that it will not only support individual manufacturers but will also help provide a boost to the national economy by making it easier for Australian consumers to buy Australian products is an added benefit.

As tariff barriers have fallen, country of origin labelling has become an important political issue. Increased imports may lead to local job losses, as local producers are forced to compete with products from countries which can sell their products in Australia at much lower prices. As a result, local producers have increasingly sought to emphasise attributes of locally made goods, other than price. The government has supported this aim.

Since 1986, the federal government has directly funded a campaign to encourage Australian consumers to buy more locally produced goods. The allocation for the Australian made program for the current financial year is just over $1.5 million. But it is important to realise that, without clear guidelines for identifying locally sourced goods and services, any campaign to encourage consumers to buy Australian will be a waste of time, resources and energy and, indeed, will lack credibility in the eyes of Australian consumers.

In particular, producers have sought to increase consumer hostility to imported goods by emphasising `buying Australian' to `preserve jobs' and using sophisticated marketing techniques and logos which suggest strong local ties to the particular product. Importers and others in the industry have been able to tap in on these methods to some extent by generating confusion as to what trade descriptions such as `Made in Australia' mean, thereby taking advantage of any consumer goodwill.

In the second reading speech for the National Food Authority Bill 1991, the then Minister for the Aged, Family and Health Services, Peter Staples, announced that the authority would conduct a wide-ranging review of policy for setting food standards. The terms of reference for the review, issued in July 1992, under section 11 of the National Food Authority Act 1991, included the authority's role in informing and educating consumers. This part of the report covered the country of origin labelling question. The NFA received submissions from numerous interested parties and organisations, and the report was presented in May 1993.
The authority discussed the origin labelling question, stating that it was considering whether to:
require a consistent declaration of ingredient origin across all foods;
clarify the intent and operation of the provisions relating to statements which identify the country in which a food is packed for retail sale;
require a consistent declaration of origin for unpackaged foods; and
define any terms used in country of origin declarations which require definition.

SPEECH.PARA: On the origin labelling issue, the NFA states that it believes that country of origin labelling requirements should be consistent with general consumer goods, but that the Australian Food Standards Code should be the primary means of regulation.

PARA.TAB: At around the same time as the establishment of the NFA inquiry, the minister requested the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to prepare a discussion paper dealing specifically with the origin labelling question. In October 1992, the FBCA established two working groups to study the problem. These groups had been amalgamated to one by the time the report was handed down. Parties to the working groups included a diverse range of federal statutory bodies, including the NFA. The terms of reference of the groups included obtaining consumer and business opinions of the existing legislative regime, establishing the scale of compliance costs with the existing regime, and developing country of origin descriptions and legislative provisions for their enforcement.

After hearing submissions from the states and territories and industry and consumer groups, the working committee report was published in May 1993. The committee's findings included that the current system was confusing and imposed conflicting requirements for labelling across jurisdictions, and that no scheme would be able to satisfy all the interests of consumers, suppliers and governments.

The committee's recommendations included that a new division be inserted into the TPA to deal with origin labelling; that the division contain descriptions to be used, but that labelling be mandatory only for specified classes of goods; and that the states and territories be encouraged to enact legislation mirroring the new division. Also, the preferred scheme for labelling was found to be an essential character test. Goods could be labelled `Made in Australia' only if they acquired their essential character in Australia.

The government's response was this bill, which picks up particular aspects of the report's recommendations. Of most significance was the adoption of the preferred labelling scheme outlined above, which was roundly attacked by a wide cross-section of community groups. In launching the scheme, the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) stated that government research had shown that consumers were primarily interested in who made the product and that the scheme would give consumers `what they really want'—and, of course, that is an Australian product.

In this bill the following changes are proposed. Clause 3 inserts a new division 1B into part 5 of the Trade Practices Act 1974. Proposed section 65VC defines the carrying of a representation as when a representation is applied to goods or their packaging or labelling. Proposed section 65VD limits the application of the division to consumer goods supplied by a corporation in trade and commerce. Consumer goods are defined as goods acquired for ordinary personal, domestic or household use or consumption, or goods costing less than the prescribed amount—currently $40,000. The division does not apply to goods supplied outside of Australia.

Proposed section 65VE prohibits representations as to origin other than those in proposed subsection 65VE(2). The legitimate descriptions are `Produce of Australia', `Product of Australia' and `Made in Australia', and the subsection specifies the criteria for their use. These criteria include the controversial `essential character' test.

Proposed section 65VF excludes from proposed section 65VE goods which carry the representation logo `Australian Made' as part of the Australian made certification mark. Proposed section 65VG prohibits the supply of goods which have representations that a production step took place in Australia, unless an additional representation as to the place of origin is also made.

Proposed section 65VH prohibits the supply of goods with representations about Australian pre-production steps, unless the goods carry at least another representation. The other representations can either be those in proposed section 65VE, a representation that identifies the fact that production steps happened in Australia, or a representation that the place of origin of the goods is outside Australia. Proposed section 65VK deals with goods which have both foreign origin representations and Australian representations. This provision ensures that the representations are of similar prominence and that information as to origin is easily accessible.

The major benefit of this bill is to increase the level of awareness among the public and consumers of the accuracy of the `Australian Made' claim on many products. It is in fact an education campaign. This is necessary because, up until now, the labelling standards have caused difficulty and confusion not only for consumers but also for industry. Once the legislation is passed, the education campaign can begin in earnest.

The new guidelines will set a new standard in simplicity and clarity. Goods claiming to be Australian will carry one of two basic descriptions: `Product of Australia', referring to goods made by Australian workers from Australian materials or components; or `Made in Australia', referring to goods made by Australian workers from materials or components that may have been imported but have gained their essential character here in Australia.

If the products cannot qualify for either of these terms, they will have to describe the Australian stage of their production process—for instance, `Assembled in Australia', `Sewn in Australia' or `Packaged in Australia'. These labels will also have to state that the material or components are imported. These new labelling laws will reflect the widespread desire among consumers to know both the source and production process of the goods. They will also help consumers spend their money in a way that will help create or sustain Australian jobs.

Since the bill first surfaced, there have been several delays in presenting it to the House and, during that time, the Minister for Consumer Affairs undertook to consult widely with consumer and producers' groups, and the bill itself has been referred to two committees for scrutiny. As a result, the government has made some minor amendments which should not only satisfy consumers and producers—and we hope the opposition, but that is very unlikely—but which also, in my opinion, make it an even stronger piece of legislation.

The purpose of the government amendments is to provide for the identification of particular places within Australia or of particular parts of Australia in the label stating the Australian origin. For instance, the delicious dairy products from King Island and Tasmania generally will still be able to use that as a promotional tool on their labels, provided that they are used in conjunction with the other labels proposed in this bill, namely: `Produce of Australia', `Product of Australia' or `Made in Australia'. There is an amendment to add section 65VG so that where goods carry a representation identifying a production step which occurred in Australia, they must identify the place of origin of the goods or the place of origin of the components or ingredients.

Australia's international cost competitiveness is at a record high, so we are faced with wonderful opportunities in the future to create new export markets and expand existing ones. A leading economist, Dr John Marsden, has estimated that producers participating in the past `Australian Made' campaigns generated about $4 billion in sales, or 2.3 per cent of manufacturing turnover. This success seems to indicate that the `Australian Made' symbol could be of enormous benefit in overseas marketing and promotion in the future.

Government research indicates that the scheme we are debating in this bill shows that consumers are happy with this scheme. They do not want to know what is in goods; they want to know where a product comes from and whether or not, by buying it, they will be helping young Australians—even their own children—to get jobs in the future. This is supported by research conducted by Ramis Corporation, which showed how strongly more Australians are feeling about the importance of supporting Australian made goods and services.

I am particularly pleased to have the opportunity to rise to support this legislation today. As I said earlier, it has been a long time coming. I would hope that the bill put before the House by the Minister for Consumer Affairs and the amendments she has proposed here today are supported by the House. Clearly, the opposition needs to come to terms with this matter. I think it is almost a case of just rejecting legislation for the sake of rejecting legislation. The furphies that were put forward by the previous speaker absolutely amazed me. He claimed that he would have the support of the ACTU, which I doubt very much. I am pleased to support this legislation and I commend it to the House. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid The Hon N.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill has taken a long while to again come before the House. The country of origin labelling issue has been the subject of two working groups and the government bill has been the subject of both a House of Representatives and a Senate committee of inquiry.

PARA.TAB: The legislation was referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, of which I am the deputy chairman. I had the honour to present our report to the House on 6 June 1994. At the time of tabling the committee's report, I said that the bill posed more questions than it answered. That situation has not changed. I would have thought that, after that committee's report to the Minister for Consumer Affairs, which raised a whole host of problems and issues that needed resolution, it could have been addressed by the minister and the matter resolved. But it is quite obvious that the minister is not listening to the people in industry, and she certainly has not undertaken the consultation processes that the coalition has undertaken.

The coalition has talked with many people in the food processing industry, the Confectionary Manufacturers of Australia, the Australian Chamber of Manufactures, the Grocery Manufacturers of Australia, the Victorian Farmers Federation, the Food Policy Alliance, the National Farmers Federation, and a whole host of individual industries. The coalition is getting a clear and consistent message from industry and a clear and concise summary of what is required in this legislation. It is certainly not what the government and the minister are putting forward.

The minister obviously would have been approached by all of these organisations. But it is quite clear that either she is not listening to them or she is locked into a mind-set which she refuses to shift from. The requirements and the amendments that have been put forward by the coalition seek to address the issues that have been brought before it by these organisations.

There are no present requirements that prescribe or clearly define the terms to be used to describe products with Australian content. The present meaning of `Made in Australia' is as determined by the courts, which broadly encompasses the `essential character' test. Section 53EB of the Trade Practices Act presently creates a specific offence for a firm which makes a false or misleading representation concerning the place of origin of goods. As well, the Food Standards Code regulates country of origin labelling for food. This bill attempts to define the terms and conditions under which goods claiming varying amounts of Australian content can be described. It does so by a number of methods.

The coalition is suggesting that the bill should be amended so that proposed subsection 65VE(2) relating to `Product/Produce of Australia' and `Made in Australia' form category A, to meet conditions where all the major ingredients or components are Australian and all operations in manufacturing and processing occur in Australia. Category B, `Manufactured in Australia', would be for goods that acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia.

There would be a new table in proposed subsection 65VE(2). Category A would have three representations—`Produce of Australia', `Product of Australia', or `Made in Australia'—all ranking equally. The condition under which goods would be in that category would be that Australia would be the place of origin of each major ingredient or component of the goods and that all operations involved in the manufacture or production of the goods happened in Australia.

Under category B, `Manufactured in Australia', the goods acquired their essential character or qualities in Australia. To me, that clearly identifies what is required in an honest approach to origin labelling. It is very clearly spelt out. This would give Australian consumers a very clear understanding of what is required and what they are purchasing—whether it be food or any other product. They would see an honest appraisal on the label and would know exactly under what conditions those products were manufactured and in which country they were manufactured.

All of the other descriptions in the bill, such as labels describing the production and pre-production process—for example, packed, blended or built in Australia from imported ingredients or components—would be followed, as would the use of the `Australian Made' logo on category A and B goods and the provision regarding symbols, words and pictures on foreign goods.

We have provided the minister with reasons for our putting forward an amendment. The amendment allows the contentious label `Made in Australia' to reflect the understanding and the perceptions of the Australian community. The perception of `Made in Australia' is that Australia is the place of origin of each major ingredient or component of the goods and that all operations involved in the manufacture or production of the goods happen in Australia.

A number of surveys conducted by various organisations support the fact that this is the understanding of the Australian public. The Quadrant survey found that 74 per cent of consumers believe that products labelled `Made in Australia' should not contain imported ingredients. The CSIRO national nutrition survey in January 1994 found that 98 per cent agreed that food should not be labelled `Australian Made' unless it was both grown and processed entirely within Australia. The Coles survey in October 1993 found that 89 per cent—which was up from 86 per cent the previous year—prefer to buy locally manufactured food products.

We also have supporting evidence from organisations that we have consulted with, such as the National Farmers Federation. Its news release of 19 October 1994 headed `Opposition right on country of origin labelling' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Farmers' Federation has commended the Federal Opposition for its move to change proposed labelling laws to more accurately reflect the origin of a product, including its components and ingredients.
The Opposition has proposed important amendments to the Trade Practices (Origin Labelling) Bill to clarify descriptions such as "Made in Australia" or "Product of Australia".
The position taken by the Opposition is in line with changes sought by the NFF.
The President of the National Farmers Federation, Mr Donald McGauchie, said:
. . . farmers had argued vigorously for the term "Made in Australia" to be used only to describe goods manufactured in Australia from Australian ingredients.
The Opposition's amendments will ensure that "Made in Australia" means exactly what it says.

That is really what the public want. The public, particularly Australian consumers, want to know that the labelling is accurate and unambiguous and that the information about the country of origin is consistent on all product labels. That was the view of the National Farmers Federation.

PARA.TAB: The Victorian Farmers Federation had a similar view. It was also consulted and has done a tremendous amount of work in this area. As the honourable member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) said earlier, the Victorian Farmers Federation formed an unusual alliance with the ACTU, and they were united in their views on this matter. That takes quite a bit of achieving, but it can be done. It was done in this instance because it reflected a commonsense and accurate approach to how labelling should appear on products made in Australia.
I also have a copy of a press release put out by SPC. I have had discussions with Mr John Corboy, the Chairman of SPC Ltd, on this important matter. The SPC News of 19 October 1994 indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: Moves by the Federal Coalition and the Democrats to amend the Federal Government's controversial MADE IN AUSTRALIA labelling legislation is a victory for commonsense and a positive initiative which would be welcomed by every Australian farmer and consumer, Australian food manufacturer SPC said today.
Certainly it will be welcomed by farmers and consumers. It will also be welcomed by a whole range of other industries. It continues:

The combined attack on the legislation by the Coalition and the Democrats now means the Federal Government's Made In Australia Labelgate legislation will not be passed in the Senate without appropriate changes.

I know that Mr Corboy performed a minor miracle—maybe a major miracle—in Australia by revitalising the old established SPC company, which is now trading successfully on the international market. He has put his record on the line and understands what the food industry and the manufacturing industry are about. The release continues:
Mr Corboy said: "The protection of the Made in Australia trademark because of its national importance is a cornerstone to underpinning future employment in Australia."

Isn't that what we all want? We want to increase employment opportunities in Australia by manufacturing Australian products and by using Australian produce or products of Australia. We want to have products clearly labelled so that the consumers understand exactly what the labelling system means. If they buy a product in Australia and read on the label that it is made in Australia, their perception is that the product came from Australia and was in fact produced here in Australia.

PARA.TAB: If anyone has any reason to doubt that, they have only to look at the enormous amount of money that the government has spent in promoting the made in Australia campaign. Over the last eight years it has spent well in excess of $15 million on a public education campaign to reinforce the message that `Made in Australia' means that the product or the produce is produced here in Australia, that it is manufactured and developed in Australia and that it is an Australian product, which is the perception and understanding of Australian consumers. The government spent all of that money on an education campaign, and that is now the clear perception of the consumers.

My colleague the member for Ballarat mentioned the firm Rocklea, which spins cotton and wool products in Australia. It just happens to have a very good plant in my electorate of Bendigo which employs a substantial number of people. It is doing some very exciting things in developing Australian technology. It is combining cotton with wool and spinning some very innovative products.

Rocklea also supports the approach that is being taken by the opposition on this issue of country of origin labelling. In its letter it spelt out that this will lead to greater employment opportunities, and it also made reference to cotton from overseas that was being dumped here. Rocklea is strongly in support of these amendments that are being proposed by the opposition as it knows they will lead to further employment opportunities for Australians.

The member for Ballarat also mentioned Golden Circle, a very well-known Australian product. A press release from Golden Circle which was issued on 18 October 1994 was headed `Call for clear "Made in Australia" labelling' and states:

SPEECH.PARA: Golden Circle Limited has called on the Federal Government to ensure that the labelling statement `Made in Australia' means just what it says.
Golden Circle is concerned by proposed legislation which would allow products carrying the Made in Australia label to actually contain up to 25% of imported ingredients.

How could we possibly allow that to happen? We must have some honesty, something that is unambiguous and something that the consumer understands. Mr Barry Kelly, the Managing Director of Golden Circle, said:
I think Australians have an expectation that only goods actually made in Australia, with all-Australian ingredients, should be allowed to carry the endorsement of `Made in Australia'.

I think that is perceived and understood by most consumers. When they walk into a store and look at a product which has `Made in Australia' on it, their understanding and their perception is that the goods were made in Australia with all-Australian ingredients and therefore are allowed to carry the endorsement `Made in Australia'.

PARA.TAB: There have been some major worldwide changes in regional labelling and the identification of regional products. If you look at the wine industry in France, you will see how important regional labelling is. It is important that the amendment we are proposing allows regional labelling to follow categories A and B; that is, Produce/Product of Australia—Tasmania; Made in Australia—Margaret river; or Manufactured in Australia—Bendigo. These regional identifications should be used. They will become very important in the future.

I mentioned the wine industry because some French names which are used for wines in Australia will become illegal as they relate to regions in France. Those regional areas are protected in France and this will mean that Australia will have to concentrate on its regional labelling as a marketing tool worldwide. There is no doubt that Australian wines are becoming more acceptable worldwide and that the wine export markets are building up. The amendment that has been put forward by the coalition also authorises the use of the Tasmanian trademark `Produce of Tasmania' as the only trademark for Tasmanian products, which would have been prohibited by the bill but which should be accepted by the government.

This bill has gone down a long path. I do not know whether the minister has learnt anything from it at all. I think the minister is resisting the changes which everyone in industry accepts as being honest and unambiguous. The amendments being put forward by the coalition will bring that about. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Deahm Ms M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to have the opportunity to speak on this most important piece of legislation, the Trade Practices Amendment (Origin Labelling) Bill. On the face of it, it may seem to be a legalistic change to the Trade Practices Act, but it signifies, to a great extent, another step forward in our recognition of the importance of our identity as Australians.

PARA.TAB: Much work has been carried out over the last few years to promote Australian products to recognise the quality of the goods produced in our own country. However, it was not that long ago that we looked to other countries to produce goods which were considered to be of real quality. If it was imported it must be good; if it was local it was not. It was no doubt part of what was known as the cultural cringe—the inferiority complex which we suffered as a nation to a great extent for so many years. As a student of history perhaps I could trace this back to our origins as a convict settlement, but this is probably not the place to look for reasons.

Some years ago I had the privilege of living in the United Kingdom and in Europe for a considerable number of years. It was interesting for me, having travelled so far, to observe the national spirit and the feeling of identity which was so pronounced in some countries. I lived in that part of the world during the entry of Britain into what was then the European Common Market. I watched the withdrawal of Britain from its traditional markets of Australia and New Zealand from the other side. It was an interesting exercise because it showed me that each country has its right to be proud of what it produces and the commonsense of trading in those products and services which are better produced in other countries.

Australia has a right to be proud of what it produces and what it creates. We have a great store of inventiveness and creativity. Although we do not always recognise the people who create new innovations in technology, I think we have reached the stage of maturity where we can exploit the natural products and the creativity of our own people while allowing those of other nations to produce the things which we are not able to deliver.

There will be cases where Australian is best and cases where imported is best. We need perhaps to look no further than the example of Scotch whisky, some may say an example which is close to my heart. The Australian product will never be quite as good not because we do not have the technical know-how but because we do not have the particular environment or historical expertise of Scotland to produce this unique product.

Having recognised that what we produce is worthy of recognition, this bill sets out how we let the community know that these are our products and that we are proud of them. The requirements of this bill make it very clear that producers of goods can no longer use the words of their choice which, in many cases, have been misleading. With a universal system of labelling with clear definitions, there will be no doubt about the meaning. Consumers will get much more of a fair go when it comes to making decisions about what they buy. The Minister for Consumer Affairs (Ms McHugh) has stated that this will be:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . a simple labelling scheme that would not only help consumers identify Australian goods, but also make it easier for Australian suppliers to promote Australian products and create Australian jobs.

The end result has come after a considerable period of consultation and the examination of public submissions. It would seem from the words we are getting from the other side that that still has not been long enough or that the message has not got through. Various consumer groups as well as individual consumers, industry groups, primary producers and retailers have been involved in this consultation process.

PARA.TAB: The new system of labelling will be simple and direct. There will be basically two labels, no As and Bs. They will be: `Made in Australia' and `Product of Australia' or `Produce of Australia'. Because these are simple and direct, they are designed to overcome the myriad of misleading labels which currently exist. Unfortunately, there are those who want to complicate these simple labels—and I think we have heard that enough from the other side this afternoon.

On the face of it, it is quite understandable that there are those who want a more defined explanation of the meaning of `Made in Australia' or `Product of Australia'. However, the legislation will be accompanied by an education program and a lead-in time for industry compliance of 18 months. During this time, the public should be left in no doubt as to the meaning of these words and what they can expect if they buy a product with these labels attached. The scheme does not apply to goods intended for export.

The scheme proposes to set the terms and conditions for making a claim about the Australian content or nature of goods. It will also control the use of potentially misleading misrepresentation on labels, such as maps and Australian symbols. In addition, it will require that origin labels are clearly legible and visible to consumers. They are there to assist consumers and also to assist manufacturers wanting to make claims of Australian origin or content. These goods which are all Australian—that is, that the major components or ingredients have originated in Australia and any processing has been done in this country—would be labelled `Product or produce of Australia'. This will be viewed as the ultimate Australian label. Unfortunately, it is the label that has the least prominence so far. Naturally, it would apply to fresh produce, such as fruit, which is grown in this country.

The `Made in Australia' label on the other hand will identify goods which have been manufactured, assembled or put together into a finished product in Australia. The ingredients which go into these products may be partly grown or supplied in Australia or may include imported components or ingredients. The key to the character of this particular label is that, to qualify for the `Made in Australia' label, goods must have acquired their essential characteristics or qualities in Australia.

The definition of what would qualify under this particular title has been framed from court judgments in cases brought by the Trade Practices Commission which involve false or misleading representations about the place of origin of goods. To assist industry in making decisions about whether a product qualifies for the `Made in Australia' label, the Trade Practices Act will include a list of principles which have been extracted from these court judgments. These include such issues as where the goods acquired their essential function, shape, dimension or appearance; where the goods underwent major processing; where the goods acquired the qualities the manufacturer is promoting; and the consumer's understanding of the phrase `Made in Australia' in the circumstances.

Naturally, there will be goods which fall under neither the `Product of Australia' nor the `Made in Australia' definition. These goods may have been assembled in Australia, packed, finished or blended in Australia, but do not meet the full requirement of the `Made in the Australia' label. For these goods, labelling must be more specific and refer to the particular step in the production process which is Australian. However, it cannot use the general words `manufactured' or `produced' as they would conflict with the official labels. For example, it would be possible for a product to be labelled `Packed in Australia from imported ingredients'.

For those manufacturers who wish to give a clearer description of their product, it would be possible to add information to the major labels of `Made in Australia' or `Product of Australia'. This will be applicable in the case where an individual state or region wishes to make it known that craftsmen or particular workers in that state had a hand in the production of the product. It would not, as the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) has said, exclude those comments. Goods which have been designed in Australia and are labelled as such also will have to have a label indicating where the goods were made.

During the preparation of this bill a lot of controversy has arisen both in the political arena and among manufacturers and consumers. Much of this has been scaremongering or purely misunderstanding of the meaning of the legislation. When a particular state wishes to promote its product there will be no conflict with this legislation. Much of the concern on this issue has been raised by Tasmanian companies which are, quite rightly, very proud of their produce. However, I hope by now they have been assured that they can still proudly label their products `Tasmanian' or `King Island' while still complying with this legislation. For example, when I visited Hobart recently I consumed considerable amounts of a local brand of mineral water. On the label it was marked in large print to be Tasmanian. However, it also complied with the new legislation, ahead of time, because in the corner of label it was marked `Product of Australia'.

Another concern which has arisen—and I have to say this has been fuelled by other political parties—is the issue of fresh produce brought into Australia which then undergoes a slight change before being packaged and labelled as `Made in Australia'. A classic example of this arose in my electorate, particularly after the Democrats' spokesman wrote a letter to my local paper. This concerned orange juice concentrate which is imported from South America. The contention was that this concentrate will have water added to it and will then be labelled `Made in Australia'. Nothing could be further from the truth.

As I have said earlier, the goods must have gained their essential character as a product in Australia in order to qualify for the `Made in Australia' label. In this case the adding of water and packaging is not the essential character. This lies in the orange juice itself. This product could therefore not be labelled `Made in Australia'. If the manufacturer wishes to label it at all, it would have to state that it was imported.

A good example of the gaining of essential character in a product is that of car tyres. Australia does not grow rubber. However, that should not stop the manufacture of tyres in Australia. The manufacture of tyres of high quality is something of which this country can be proud. It seems incongruous to me that tyres which are made in Australia from raw material which has been imported should not be marked `Made in Australia'. There is no way that the natural product of rubber can be supplied within Australia. There is equally no reason why Australian tyres, which are designed and manufactured in Australia by Australian workers, should be marked anything but `Made in Australia'.

All the arguments I have heard from opponents of the bill have focused on the `Made in Australia' label. They say that goods which are labelled `Made in Australia' should be totally Australian or, if they are not, that the origin of the ingredients should be listed. None of these people has ever mentioned the other vital label which is covered by this bill and that is `Product or produce of Australia'. When the latter is seen on a product, and after the education campaign, we will know that it is made in Australia from Australian ingredients. Therefore, `Made in Australia' has a different definition.

However, it is a similar definition to that which already exists under the Australian-made logo—that is, the familiar green triangle with the yellow kangaroo. The Advance Australia Council makes a decision on the level of Australianness which will qualify for the logo. However, these goods do not have to be manufactured in Australia of all Australian ingredients. Therefore, the new legislation in no way contravenes the Australian-made system with which we are all so familiar.

However, if the opposition amendments go through, they could effectively destroy the Australian-made logo with which we are so familiar. The Advance Australia Council will be operating illegally by marking those goods `Australian made' and putting that logo on them. I hope that the opposition will realise that it will have on its conscience the jobs of many Australians. The legislation deals only with goods and products which claim to be Australian. Goods which are imported may display the country of origin, and for more discerning shoppers most of these products will now give an idea of the origin.

However, the most important reason for introducing the scheme is to eliminate the false and misleading information which has been previously given on labels. One of the most important aims of this scheme is to identify Australian goods made by Australian workers. This is one of the key elements that apply to this legislation. The emphasis is on Australian jobs—jobs for Australians. It is hoped that it will encourage Australians to buy these goods and to support Australian jobs.

Labelling says nothing about who owns the company which has that manufactured the goods and in this context it is not important. The main emphasis is on the production of goods within Australia using Australian workers. An Australian company may manufacture its goods abroad or a foreign company established in Australia will use Australian workers to manufacture its goods here. What we are about is supporting Australian jobs within Australia and encouraging consumers to purchase these goods which will support those jobs. I therefore commend to the House the amendments to the Trade Practices Act which will enable these labels to become standard practice within Australia.

I hope that discerning members in the other place will firmly reject the amendments that have been moved by the opposition. It is obvious that we need a further education campaign to show that the semantics set out in Senator Boswell's press release, which require labels to be of an A type or B type, do not make things clearer. How will that make things clearer and simpler? It will merely complicate them.

All we are doing is substituting the word `made' for `manufactured'. Senator Boswell's proposal is absolutely ridiculous. The member for Bendigo has said that the perception in the community is that `Made in Australia' means made in Australia from all Australian ingredients. It clearly does not indicate that. If he were to talk to the Advance Australia Council and were to look at those goods with the green and gold label on them, he would find that many of those are not manufactured from all Australian ingredients. Those companies would be put out of business and the people that manufacture those products would inevitably have their jobs put in jeopardy.
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being almost 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the House do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a matter which is hurting Cranbourne businesses both large and small—everyone from cleaning contractors to bedding shops. Over the past week there has been a lot of discussion about the ongoing Prices Surveillance Authority's inquiry into the future arrangements that should apply for the 51 companies that must presently seek that authority's permission for any price rises.

PARA.TAB: This sort of intrusion by a government agency can cost a lot of money and often consumers end up no better off. One example of that is the beer market. Even though there are only two major brewers, Fosters and Lyon Nathan, the latter being known as Tooheys, they fight head to head for every slab that is sold. Often at Dan Murphy, Phillip Murphy or similar shops the retail price of a slab will be massively discounted. In these situations it makes little sense to have a government agency cast in the role of approver of price rises.

It is up to the Assistant Treasurer (Mr Gear) to require the Prices Surveillance Authority to monitor a particular industry, product or service. In Cranbourne, small businesses are in an unusual situation. Unlike their competitors in Berwick, Frankston, Dandenong or Mt Eliza, Cranbourne homes and businesses are in the 059 telephone area. Of course, they can use Telecom's community call facility to speak at cheaper than normal STD rates. However, Cranbourne small businesses still face a problem. Many of their potential or actual customers might live in the Melbourne telephone area.
