Most business people would know that business directories such as the Yellow Pages and the Melbourne Big are an effective way to reach people looking for goods and services. So many Cranbourne businesses have to advertise in both the 03 and the 059 Yellow Pages and perhaps Melbourne Big or other directories as well.

Over the past two years, however, the company that publishes the Yellow Pages, Pacific Access Pty Ltd, which is 51 per cent owned by Telstra—or Telecom—with the remainder owned in equal shares by the US companies Volt and South Western Bell, the Dutch company YP Publishing and the Australian company Edward H. O'Brien have treated Cranbourne businesses differently from Melbourne businesses. In the 009 region directory Yellow Pages, advertising rates showed that the cost of an advertisement that covers an eighth of a page has increased by almost 6 per cent between 1993 and 1995 editions. The Australian inflation rate over the same period was only 3.6 per cent.

Yet in Melbourne, for Melbourne Big, a competitor to the Yellow Pages, the price rise between December 1992 and 1994 editions has been adjusted by just under four per cent for the same advertisement. The Yellow Pages may well argue that their rates are low by international standards but the fact is that they can increase their prices under this government without having to run the risk of the Prices Surveillance Authority objecting to the price rises.

My concern is that the Yellow Pages have a huge market power. In Cranbourne they are a monopoly. In Melbourne they have about three quarters of what is understood to be a $100 million cake of advertising in business directories. Bill Scales, the Chairman of the Industry Commission, would probably agree that the Yellow Pages meet the stringent tests for what sort of businesses should be subject to prices surveillance, and he does not believe there are many. Yet incredibly under this Labor government, which preaches compassion, the Assistant Treasurer allows his friends at Telecom to escape any sort of government scrutiny with their joint venture company Pacific Access. Until we know what the new policy will be with the forthcoming establishment of the Australian competition commission the Assistant Treasurer should direct at the very least the Prices Surveillance Authority to monitor, or perhaps hold an inquiry into, the Yellow Pages prices.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I last rose in this House in the adjournment debate I referred to the great provincial manufacturing city of Geelong, which I represent in this parliament. I indicated that recently in Geelong there was some bad news and a lot of good news. The bad news was that we lost to the West Coast Eagles, and some Geelong supporters as well as West Coast supporters missed out on finals tickets. That is an issue that I see the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) has placed before the parliament. Hopefully it will be taken up at some time in the future. The good news related to the level of economic development which was taking place in the city of Geelong. I referred in that past adjournment speech to the recent jobs growth which had occurred and the improvement that had taken place in motor vehicle registrations.

PARA.TAB: I would like to turn to other elements of the Geelong economy that have indicated some real signs of growth in recent times. I refer to an article that appeared on 7 October 1994 in the Geelong Advertiser entitled `Economic Outlook Becoming Brighter'. The city of greater Geelong in its report on the Geelong economy had indicated various sectors that had shown substantial growth in the previous quarter. One of those was the building sector. As I look around this House, I see the honourable member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), who sits opposite me here. He knows very well that the building industry is very important to regional areas and cities such as Geelong and to the city that he represents, Bendigo.

In Geelong, new business approvals over that quarter have increased by 10.8 per cent. We have seen their value increase by 21.2 per cent. That increase has comprised new home constructions. More importantly, we have seen a real surge in factory and shop development of over 40 per cent. The total value of that is some $14 million—$4.6 million on factories, $2.1 million on shops and $1.3 million on other business premises. This in itself is a heartening development, but it is the significance of this statistic that we ought to reflect upon. It means that in the city of greater Geelong at this point in time the private sector is beginning to invest in a very real sense. That is a cause for some optimism for people in that region.

Another area of growth that was mentioned in the economic outlook article was education. I refer to another article in the Geelong Advertiser entitled `Business boom for Deakin'—that is, Deakin University—which indicated that enrolments are expected to skyrocket by some 50 per cent in 1995 and will for the first time exceed 50,000 students. I am pleased to note that Deakin University is extending its activities into South East Asia. Recently on a parliamentary delegation I visited Singapore. At the time I was there the Deakin representative was there sounding out business opportunities as far as the university's educational programs were concerned.

Deakin has 900 fee-paying international students. There is much more to be done in exploiting the presence of these students in our educational institution. I will be making some comments about that in the parliament in due course. We have identified excellent export opportunities in the Geelong region. Automotive component manufacture is one of those, along with vehicle manufacture itself. There is great potential in the export of construction services and products and education, general services and wool.

Now for some more good news. We did go for a short period during the week without a football coach. Malcolm Blight resigned. I thank him for his service to the club and wish him well. We have appointed a new coach, Gary Ayres. He is very young, he is mature, he has a wealth of finals experience, he knows the players and he is going to pursue a youth policy. Look out for the excitement machine at Kardinia Park in 1995.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to draw the attention of the House to the prevailing drought conditions which are extending from Queensland through New South Wales down into Victoria and to the impending drought conditions in north central Victoria. Over the past couple of weeks we have had increased temperatures. Earlier this week we had 32 degrees celsius, one of the warmest October days for many years in central Victoria. The weather pattern in Queensland and New South Wales is extending south down through Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Over the past three years farmers have had to contend with some extremely difficult conditions in north central Victoria. We have had mice plagues, we have had damaged harvests and in recent times we have even had floods in north eastern Victoria. So farmers have had some extremely difficult conditions during that period.

Those difficult climatic conditions have in fact put a tremendous amount of pressure on the farming community. I am seeking a visit by the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee. The Minister for Agriculture in Victoria, Mr Bill McGrath, is aware of the very difficult conditions that are being caused by that weather pattern; however, I am not sure whether the federal minister, Senator Collins, is aware of the exceptional circumstances of the north central Victoria area. I do not know whether he knows about the history of the past three years, about the conditions that have been experienced by the farmers in that area. I take this opportunity to invite both the Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Committee and the minister to the area of north central Victoria to see for themselves just what tough conditions and exceptional circumstances the rural community in that area is facing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, you know that I have previously spoken in this House about my abhorrence of ocean outfall and about sewage and effluent management. I was elected to this House on 13 March 1993. Since then, I have devoted myself to improving the quality of the environment and to developing the potential for the future growth of my electorate and to improving the living conditions of those in my electorate. As a surfer, one of those things has been ensuring that the purity of water along our coast is maintained for a number of reasons—not for my own selfish reason of wanting to surf in good, pristine waters but for the reason that tourism is one of the dominant industries along our coast. There is another reason; that is, the potential for mariculture along our coast.

PARA.TAB: Since being elected, I have put forward the view that not only was this discharge into the ocean an environmental danger but also that it was a waste of a resource. Many people within that area, particularly the one-time mayor of Shoalhaven and others, thought that I was a dreamer, someone who was a sky pilot, whose head was so far up in the clouds that I could not see reality. Well, a lot has happened in that time. In fact, I have been able to attain a feasibility study on employment generated by effluent management and, subsequently, the re-use of water for agricultural purposes and for farm forestry.

In the time of drought that we have now, it is exceedingly important that people realise something. I must admit, the drought is one of the things that has aided me in getting this message across. What has resoundingly come out of that study is that my ideas of using effluent as a resource have been sown amongst a number of groups.

The first group was the Shoalhaven City Council, which was dead against the idea from the start. It said it was unfeasible and not possible. It has changed its view. The second group was that of landowners in the area. Those landowners now are supportive. The third group was that of the corporate sector. I had to go to Melbourne and other places to various sections of the corporate sector and I found that those people are prepared to attend meetings. In fact, on 31 October and 1 November a key group of people will come together to examine the prospects of future development within the scope of that feasibility study.

This is quite exciting because a number of things are coming out of it. I am putting forward the concept of a corporate entity which would comprise the Shoalhaven City Council, the landowners and the corporate sector. The Shoalhaven City Council, which represents the people, will have to put in an effluent management system anyway. Whether it pumps the effluent into the ocean or elsewhere, there is no difference in dollars. The landowners already own the land and therefore have a contribution to make to a corporate entity in terms of tying up dollars and cents or litres that they will be prepared to expend and use on their land. The third section is the corporate sector, which I have taken a great deal of time to interest and involve in this. In fact, a number of projects in other areas have interested them, but they have decided to have a good look at what we are proposing in our area.

The dream I still have is that of this corporate entity. Being a socialist I do not normally run with the capitalist system, but in this case practical reality says that we have to put those three elements together. I am happy that the people of Shoalhaven will in the long term benefit from that. Hopefully in the long term, when the trees and the value of that commodity comes through, they will benefit.

This meeting, which will take place on 31 October and 1 November, will set the ground rules for this corporation. This corporation will then own an intellectual product when it is all together. I am hoping that it will be able to go up and down the coast from Rockhampton to Lorne selling this. The jobs that will come out of it for the young people of my area in terms of skills in the horticultural and construction industries will be such that I will be able to address the 15 per cent unemployment in my area.

I promised that I would do all I could for jobs. I have delivered to a large extent here. I hope that this meeting—which is one of many that I will hold; and I am holding another one on 11 November on tourism—will be the start of something big. We will reintroduce the forestry industry in my area; I do not want greenies putting their lives in jeopardy or people who have capital in the bush having it destroyed by other people. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile Mr M.A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As was the case in the adjournment debate last night, I again would like to bring to the attention of the House the plight of some of our primary producers on the mid-north coast of New South Wales as a result of the current devastating drought. Again, I have been asked to bring this matter to the attention of the parliament. I received a letter from a Mr Ray Burnett of Byabarra, which is just west of Wauchope. He writes:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mark,

The present drought aid to coastal farmers has not received the respect from our politicians that it warrants. The Hastings Valley for example has an average rainfall of 1300 MM. The plants that grow in the area are therefore adapted to this environment. Also the soils are much shallower in depth to the soils of the inland and because of the heavier average rainfall leaching the nutrients, they have less food value for stock.
This means that a drought of 2 months on the coast is equal to 6 to 9 months in the inland as regards food for cattle.
This coastal area is the breeding cradle for cattle to supply feed lots and inland grass fatteners with young cattle for the domestic and overseas markets.

So you can have some conception of the present drought on this coastal area, the lowest rainfall ever recorded in the Hastings Valley, was in 1941 with 653 MM. or 50.2% of the average rainfall over 100 Years.
This year to the end of September we have had 373 MM. or 28.7% of the years average. (we require 280 MM. by the end of December to equal the lowest recorded).
This follows 3 years of below average rainfall:-

I purchased grain and fed some stock to sell at the store sale at Wauchope on Friday 14-10-94 it cost $533 for the grain and the 7 cows and 1 calf brought $730 less $80 costs making a return of $117 for the value of the animals.
Since I purchased the grain prices have now risen from $222 to $350 per ton.
The fodder transport subsidy is also of marginal benefit because to reach the $500s to make a claim valued at $250 a farmer will have to spend $3,500 on feed to gain the $250.

This subsidy I consider a great Joke, because if the trucks were not delivering the fodder they would not be using fuel, tyres or oil which the Federal and State Governments are collecting taxes for. The taxes collected for this additional truck usage is therefore compensating the Government for the transport subsidy.
Stock water on farms will possibly last 2 months, depending on how hot it becomes.

The local Kempsey Rural Lands Board Veterinarian spoke on the ABC Radio last week, he stated that without substantial rain there could be a loss of 80,000 head of cattle in the boards area within 6 weeks because of the lack of stock drinking water on farms.
Some properties are already carting water for stock.

With the low market value of stock at present and the continuous low income from previous years farmers will be unable to purchase re-stockers when normal conditions return. This could have a devastating effect on the future supplies of store cattle from this cattle breeding cradle of Australia.
Yours faithfully,
Ray Burnett.
Member of the N.S.W. Farmers Association.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends various acts relating to the meat and livestock industry. The purpose of the bill is to amend the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 to help identify the types of restrictions imposed by importing countries which enable the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation to establish export quota mechanisms. The bill also amends the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 to provide for the selling agent to be responsible for collecting and forwarding levies imposed under the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1990 whenever that agent is involved in a leviable transaction, and amends the Beef Production Levy Act 1990 to introduce a conversion factor allowing the beef production levy to be calculated where a hot carcase weight is unavailable and only cold carcase weight is available.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act provides the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation, AMLC, with the powers to establish quota schemes on the export of meat and live sheep from Australia where restrictions are imposed, or likely to be imposed, on Australian exports by importing countries or by the Australian government.

The necessity for these amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 has arisen from the successful outcome of the Uruguay Round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a result of which is that many quantitative restriction measures are being converted into tariff quota. The United States's action of introducing a tariff quota mechanism to replace the former quantitative mechanism under the US meat import law is one such example of this. The imposition of such economic restrictions not only disrupts our trade to the United States, which is a major market for beef worth in excess of $1.1 billion, but also creates uncertainty and impacts on the stability of Australia's domestic and other meat exports.

The meat and livestock industry would like to see a degree of orderly marketing by maintaining parallel flows of tariff free products and tariff liable products in those years where exports are likely to exceed the tariff free limit. If left unmanaged there is a likelihood of a rush of product into the US market early in the year which would have the effect of depressing prices for the tariff free component while also disadvantaging northern Australian beef producers. It is envisaged that quota mechanisms set up under these arrangements will manage the trade in a way which avoids these effects.

A delegations clause is also proposed for the Australian Meat and Live-stock (Quotas) Act 1990 to enable the corporation's staff to sign the documents imposing a quota scheme. This will bring it into line with other corporation powers, which can already be delegated to the corporation's staff and its committees.

The Beef Production Levy Act 1990 imposes a levy on the slaughter of cattle on a cents per kilogram basis of the hot carcase weight. The hot carcase weight is the weight of a carcase that is weighed within two hours of slaughter. At present the act provides that if a hot carcase weight is not available the carcase weight is deemed to be 240 kilograms per head of cattle for levy calculation purposes.

It was brought to the attention of the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council that some small domestic abattoirs are not able to determine the hot carcase weight, but are able to determine a cold carcase weight. Representations from these abattoirs indicated that the great majority of the carcases produced by them are under 240 kilograms, and these abattoirs were therefore paying higher levies than they should reasonably have paid.

To address this problem, the government has accepted the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council's recommendations that a conversion factor be incorporated into the act to allow a conversion from cold carcase weight to a hot carcase weight equivalent.

The Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 currently provides that where an abattoir slaughters cattle on which a cattle transaction levy is imposed, the abattoir proprietor is responsible for collecting the levy and forwarding it to the Commonwealth. In other cases, an agent, if involved in the sale of cattle, is responsible for collecting and forwarding the levy.

This has caused some problems where an agent is involved in the sale of cattle to an abattoir proprietor or facilitates the sale of cattle on an `over-the-hooks' basis. The proposed amendment clarifies that the agent rather than the abattoir proprietor will be responsible for collecting and forwarding to the Commonwealth the levy imposed by the Cattle Transaction Levy Act 1990. The abattoir proprietor will only become responsible for collecting and forwarding the levy where an agent is not involved.

Penalties have been imposed in the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 for offences relating to amendments in the Beef Production Levy Act 1990 when either the hot carcase weight or the cold carcase weight is available but not used.

This amendment also corrects an omission in the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Collection Act 1991 regarding abattoir proprietors' ability to refuse to slaughter livestock. This provision permits abattoir proprietors to refuse to slaughter livestock owned by another person unless funds for the payment of the livestock slaughter levy are first made available. The correction brings pigs within the scope of this provision, so that if pigs are to be slaughtered funds for the payment of the pig levy are first to be made available.
I commend the bill to honourable members.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill 1994 will amend the Beef Production Levy Act of 1990 by introducing a conversion factor, as outlined by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport (Mr O'Keefe), which will allow the levy to be calculated where only a cold carcase weight is available. There are also other minor amendments to levy acts.

PARA.TAB: The beef production levy is collected for research and development purposes, promotional efforts, disease eradication programs and the residue survey. It is currently calculated on a hot weight basis. The difficulty arises when the carcase is weighed cold as this always produces a lighter weight. This legislation introduces a conversion factor of 1.03 which allows for a weight reduction of three per cent for the chilled or frozen meat, and provides the hot carcase weight equivalent for levy calculation purposes. Where, for whatever reason, neither the hot nor cold weight is determined, a deemed carcase weight of 240 kilograms will be assumed in order to calculate the levy.

This legislation also clarifies a point of some confusion by stating that an agent, if involved in the sale of cattle, is responsible for collecting and forwarding the levy to the Commonwealth. The abattoir proprietor will only become responsible for collecting and forwarding the levy if an agent is not involved. It is good to see that that point is being clarified in this legislation because I know in my own electorate of Maranoa, which is three times the size of the state of Victoria, with very important beef producing and beef added value industries in the form of feedlots, it does cause confusion and some conflict between the producer and the agent or the abattoir.

Abattoir proprietors are also given the ability to refuse to slaughter livestock—including pigs—which are owned by someone else, unless levy payments are first made. Quite clearly, the abattoir proprietor will have some capacity to get those levies paid prior to the slaughter of those animals. This has also been an area of conflict in many parts of my own electorate where there are some producers who feel that this is a levy that they should not pay and someone else should pay. This legislation clears up that point and gives abattoir proprietors an opportunity, if they feel there is a problem collecting these levies, to get that levy prior to the slaughter of livestock.

It is timely, given the presence of legislation meeting Australia's GATT obligations before the House of Representatives, to recognise the enormous commitment within the beef industry to its future and, indeed, its growth and expansion.

There can be no doubt that the beef industry's commitment to research and development, self-promotion and disease eradication has been crucial to the beef industry's continuing success on the Australian domestic market, and the export markets. It is an industry which has gained a great deal of recognition and market share in the emerging Asian basin. These markets will be crucial to the beef industry in Australia in the future. It is vital that this legislation plays its part in allowing the industry to sort out the way it collects its levies and on what basis it collects those levies.

Meat processing is one of Australia's largest rural based industries. It employs more than 30,000 Australians and generates in the order of $5.6 billion in turnover annually. That turnover is nearly all generated out in regional Australia. It is a great employer of the regional work force and plays a great part in the decentralisation of this nation. Obviously, with $5.6 billion turning over in regional Australia, it has clear implications for the wider community because of the multiplier effect that those dollars generate in those communities where meat processing and the beef industry are based.

More than 75,000 farms and pastoral properties produce livestock for slaughter. Beef and veal combined are Australia's fourth largest export earner, generating $2,949 million annually. They only rank behind coal, gold and wool in terms of total export earnings. It is a very significant industry and one that we need to ensure plays its part in any recovery and any future of this nation. I am quite convinced that we will always have a beef industry in Australia. However, there are aspects of the cost of production on which we must start to focus as a nation, if we want the beef industry to be part of a viable export sector in the future.

To that end, the GATT outcome provides new opportunities for the Australian beef industry to build on. In particular, the opportunities to expand further into the American market are noteworthy. The US Meat Import Law, which has thwarted Australian beef exporters for many years, will be converted to a tariff only protection. There will also be increased access through tariff quotas. Initially there will be an increase of 17 per cent in access in 1995, compared with 1994. That is a significant increase in terms of access on a year-on basis. The new global quota for access to the US beef market will be 656,621 tonnes of beef of which Australia will have a 57.6 per cent market share, that is, 378,214 tonnes of beef.

Japan has similarly agreed to a reduction in tariffs, subject to particular quantity based safeguards. The Korean market is another which shows great promise. Korea has agreed to completely liberalise its beef market at the end of the year 2001. Of course, with the end of 1994 almost upon us, that date is only seven years away. Of course, when it has liberate its beef market in 2001, only a tariff will apply. The Koreans will also be increasing their global quota allowing for a greater proportion of sales to be made direct with end users, reducing the above quota tariff and reducing the government levied mark-up on imports.

Quite clearly, those sorts of arrangements, as they phase out in the year 2001, will have a massive impact on the beef industry on a global basis. For Australia to become part, and to gain part, of that increased access to Korea, we are going to have to compete with other countries which will be seeking a share of that market. Other breakthroughs are likely in Thailand, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Canada and Mexico, and there are clearly enormous opportunities for our beef industry around those markets in the future, as those economies grow and those peoples demand a higher standard of food intake and a better quality of food intake, which is related to their increased standards of living.

Of the $900 million of gains predicted for Australian agricultural industries as a result of GATT, $330 million is expect to flow through to the beef industry. In other words, more than a third of the gains in terms of the GATT outcomes are going to flow through to the Australian beef industries. These gains, of course, will be delivered over a number of years. Those outcomes are yet to be achieved, and they will not all come in the first years of the operation of the new GATT rules. The gains that are available to our primary industries must, however, be kept firmly in perspective.

Whilst we can expect to gain $900 million a year as a result of many years of multilateral negotiations, significant gains could also flow from the reform of the Australian taxation system. Agricultural industries currently pay around $1.3 billion a year in indirect taxes such as fuel tax, sales tax and payroll tax: indirect taxes that producers in the agricultural industries are paying on an annual basis. It is clear that genuine reform in this area would produce gains of the same dimension as GATT would, if not of a bigger dimension.

Tax reform of this nature would also vastly enhance the competitiveness of our agricultural products. We can no longer expect a free ride in the international trade arena on the basis of our historical role as a major exporter. International trade is now a much tougher environment. Whilst our products will always be able to compete on quality, taste and freshness, we must also be able to offer competitive prices. That requires a genuine commitment to reducing the costs of production in this country, and tax reform is the ideal place to start.

We must also consider the urgent need to reform our expensive and inefficient transport system. The road transport industry does its best, considering that it too faces a prohibitive fuel tax and sales tax regime and a substandard road network. Many truck drivers talk to me about the fact that they do not mind paying their fuel tax but that they would like to see more of that money going back into their roads. They believe that they have to contribute to the roads, and they are quite happy to do that by paying the 30-odd cents per litre fuel tax. But they want to see that money going back into roads and not the great crime of it being siphoned off into other programs that the government may use some of that money for.

I refer to an area in the back of my electorate—the Diamantina Shire. Only 250 people live in the Diamantina Shire. It is based around the townships of Birdsville and Bedourie. There are 1,600 kilometres of roads in the Diamantina Shire, but only six kilometres of those roads are sealed. That gives some example to the House of how the people out there are paying their fuel taxes, but are not getting any of the money back in the form of better roads in their part of the world.

Quite often people there tell me that it is not what damage the trucks do to the roads out there, it is what damage the roads do to their trucks. As I said earlier, they would be quite happy to pay their fuel taxes and sales taxes providing the money went back into building better roads. Of course, better roads will reduce the cost of production and, ultimately, make our exports more competitive on the international markets.

Only last week the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, commented on the looming grain shortage crisis caused by the drought. He urged grain feed consumers, lot feeders, pork producers and chicken meat operators to import grain from North America because it would be cheaper than shipping it from Western Australia, despite the fact that ample feed supplies are available there. On the figures that I have received, it would cost approximately $40 a tonne to ship grain halfway around our domestic coastline, and it would cost $27 a tonne to bring it across the Pacific. That is a ludicrous situation.

As a nation, we can no longer afford to have a situation where it is more expensive to bring grain halfway around our domestic coastline than it is to bring it 12,000 kilometres across the Pacific. At the end of the day, if those producers source the grain in Western Australia it means they will be paying a freight penalty which will add to their costs. Reforms are required on the waterfront to ensure genuine competition in terms of the cost of moving grain and products on our coastal shipping routes.

Our railways perform only marginally better. The most efficient rail freight operation in Australia can move grain for 5.5 cents per net tonne per kilometre. The best performance in American rail is 1.54 cents per net tonne per kilometre. In other words, Australia is 3.5 times worse off than America in terms of moving grain. It is little wonder that our struggling farmers are doing it so hard. The harsh reality for them is that, to compete internationally, they have to be competitive in terms of price and quality, and that means absorbing enormous cost disparities such as those to which I have just been referring.

The beef industry is one of our most price competitive industries. This is largely due to the size and climate of Australia which allows us to produce vast quantities of livestock relatively cheaply, but we begin to fall behind the rest of the world when processing costs are taken into consideration. A 1993 study comparing the costs of best-in-class meat processing facilities in Australia, revealed that Australian facilities are far more costly than United States facilities and, to a lesser extent, those facilities in Argentina, Ireland and New Zealand. Given that labour costs are the most significant component of processing costs, that is obviously the area in which gains must be sought. This need was acknowledged by the Industry Commission in its report into meat processing. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Labour is by far the largest single input cost of processing livestock into meat. Features of the industry's award system inhibit innovation and have contributed to industrial unrest. Seniority systems and daily hire provide insufficient incentives for training and skills development. The complexity of the tally system, and its structure of premium rates of remuneration for extra output, reduces incentives for improving working conditions and productivity . . . The Commission has . . . recommended that Labour market reform be pursued as a matter of priority.

It appears that this warning has gone unheeded by the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union. Only two weeks ago Australia's largest beef processor, Australia Meat Holdings, withdrew from saleyard purchasing in Queensland and New South Wales for 24 hours following threats from the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union that it would commence a rolling one day per week stoppage—great timing in the middle of the worst drought since European settlement in this nation.

PARA.TAB: The company clearly anticipated difficulties if it continued to buy cattle and could not slaughter as a result of the threatened work stoppages. This had a major impact on the cattle sales in my own electorate, particularly the Dalgety sales in Toowoomba, Churchill, the Dalby saleyards and Casino in New South Wales. All those selling centres were particularly devastated by the withdrawal of AMH from those sales.

Of course, who paid the ultimate penalty on that day and for the following week? It was those drought affected producers who had no alternative but to sell their stock. The alternative was to take them home and keep them on a drought affected property for another week, and perhaps the following week there might have been sales where the AMH buyers would be operating. We have to remember that AMH is the largest meat processor in this country and therefore a very dominant factor at any auction sale around the eastern states and obviously in Western Australia.

The reason for this strike is that the AMIEU demanded a 14 per cent wage rise. The raise was not linked to either enterprise agreements or workplace restructuring; the union just wanted a pay rise. I guess everyone really would like a pay rise, with Christmas coming on. But it has to be linked, as the Industry Commission says, to productivity gains, to restructuring of work practices, to ensure that there is a sustainable industry there in the future. That is not the approach of the AMIEU.

Perhaps someone from the other side of the House should explain why the AMIEU has taken this action. Clearly, what the AMIEU has to look at is that labour market reform does not translate to wholesale wage increases for everyone. That is something that must be explained to those members and those people who drive the AMIEU.

What it does mean is a cooperative drive for productivity improvements and the consequential rewards for employers and employees, which this can bring. If there is that cooperation, the rewards flow through, as the Industry Commission report clearly identifies, to better work practices, more sustainable employment opportunities and, of course, an ongoing job, which is important. Without this cooperation, the meat industry is going to be confronted with a situation where operating on the export market will become increasingly difficult because of the cost price imposed through those sorts of practices.

What we must understand in this country is that we are part of a global market—a global shopping village. The AMIEU ought to understand that it is part of that global shopping village, and that the products that it is involved in producing and processing are going to go, in most instances, onto our export markets and into these developing Asian markets. Of course, importers are also in a global shopping village, just like we are in Australia. Those importers wanting to consider the purchase of Australian products will also consider other countries' products. If they can buy them at a better price from other countries, they will buy them from those countries.

We have got to understand that, as part of the global shopping village that we live in today, we have all got to be part of the reforms and part of a cooperative approach. The AMIEU ought to consider what damage it is doing, not only to our domestic processing industry—its members' own jobs—but also to drought affected producers, who have been affected in terms of the price that they have received, because of the lower bids being offered by meat processors as a result of the AMIEU's actions.

Whilst the GATT bills before the House of Representatives at the moment are important, we can never lose sight of the fact that there is a great deal more we can do, as a nation, in reforming our tax systems, to ensure that we do become part of the international global shopping village and that we can take our share in international markets, including those that GATT will open up for us.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to support the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill. It is also pleasing to note the bipartisan support for the amendments, particularly the support shown for them by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott). While I wholeheartedly agree with his comments about the demise of railways in many of our rural areas in Australia and the disastrous effect that that is going to have on future generations of rural dwellers, I do not support his comments related to the meat industry union.

PARA.TAB: If you care to go and have a look at the abattoir at Dubbo, which is probably the biggest, most progressive and most modern slaughtering facility for lamb and mutton in Australia, you will see that there is no doubt that the enterprise bargaining that has been entered into there sets the pattern for all Australian slaughtering institutions. If it can be done in one place, it can be done in others. There are two sides to every argument, and I would suggest that management has as much to answer for as any trade union does, in this industry and in any industry.

It is obvious that a process of consultation and participation by all sectors of our meat and livestock industry has given us a set of amendments that has received widespread support from all sectors of the industry, and from the opposition, which we know is very hard to do. Because they are acceptable, it is most likely that they are going to work.

It is important that we look at these levies historically. The proposed amendments to the Beef Levy Act 1990 and the Primary Industries Levies and Charges Act 1991 were put on hold by the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Crean), pending the completion of a review of the cattle industry levy system recommended by the Australian Meat and Livestock Industry Policy Council. It is significant that the review was carried out by the Cattle Council of Australia and the AMLIPC. The review has now been completed, with the outcome being that the Cattle Council of Australia has decided to retain the current system. The Cattle Council's position has been fully endorsed by the AMLIPC.

The Cattle Council of Australia undertook a comprehensive review of the cattle industry levy mechanism, including a detailed examination of several alternative mechanisms, aided throughout by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy through the provision of technical advice and through the preparation of a paper comparing the main options in terms of equity, economic efficiency, administrative efficiency, visibility, and reliability and predicability of income.

The Cattle Council of Australia decided at its November 1993 meeting to support the continuation of the flat rate transaction levy and beef production levy beyond the completion of the trial period. The reductions in the transaction levy from $6.25 to $4 and to $3.60 from 1 July 1994 have taken much of the heat out of the argument. No-one likes to pay a levy and part of the problem has been that all parts of the industry felt that they were the ones making the major contribution.

As a cattle producer myself, I do not like a levy. I have spoken to the minister recently about a levy that is currently being paid on forced sales of drought affected cattle—cattle which would not normally be going to slaughter and for which the levy will not contribute to a better price. I have put forward my point of view that, where it can be shown that breeding cattle are being sold unnecessarily because of the weather circumstances, perhaps there should be a suspension of the levy. The cattle council's conclusion was consistent with the analysis by the Department of Primary Industries and Energy of the options, which showed that the current arrangements are the best compromise to achieve the industries goals of visibility, efficiency and equity.

Having visited Japan, Korea and Taiwan during our winter recess, I was very pleased to note the way that funding through the levy system is being used by the AMLC to promote Australian beef—Aussie beef—in those countries. If we take the case of Japan in particular, we find that Australian beef last year was worth more than $1 1/2 billion to this nation. It has now surpassed iron ore in importance as a commodity exported to Japan. That success is not only due to the fact that trade barriers in Japan have been broken down; it is also due to the fact that the AMLC has mounted an aggressive and successful campaign for selling our beef. That is the levy in practice. All sectors of the industry are reaping benefits from this levy.

I speak to agents from time to time and they complain about the cost to them of collecting the levy, but they do have the advantage of using the funds, of reducing their OD or of simply having the money invested and accumulating interest for the month, because they return the interest monthly only. As a service to their customers it is better that they do it; it is better in the interest of the AMLC that it is returned on a regular basis. It would be a quite horrific exercise if we relied on, say, the growers to fill in that return. As a grower I know how lax growers can be in putting in their returns on time.

I was also pleased to see the honourable member for Maranoa indicate the contribution that the cattle industry, the meat industry, makes to rural Australia. It is a significant contributor as an employer—through meat processing, through cartage, through contracting—and also through the farming community. It is an industry that we in Australia take a great deal of pride in as the industry is a world leader.

The unfortunate thing is that the current drought being experienced is going to require more than a levy to make sure that the industry stays on track. I feel that we will be suffering the consequences of this drought for the next decade because of the loss of breeding stock. Certainly in the immediate future we will not be able to satisfy contracts and there will be sectors in our meat industry where contracts will be lost to other exporters. It is going to be very hard for us to get that export market back, but we have done it in the past and we will do it again.

I would certainly like to support this legislation. I would like to compliment all the sectors of the industry, and particularly the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, for producing these amendments. As I said, they have been supported by everyone and because of that they will work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased in this Main Committee to have the opportunity to speak briefly in support of the legislation. I commend the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Horne) for his contribution and I recognise the authority he brings into the debate as a cattle producer. I was pleased to hear his comments about the AMLC and its role in the Japanese market. I was among the first to acknowledge not only the important role that GATT has played in heightening the opportunities for the beef industry in Australia but also the role it has played in lowering tariff barriers that have existed around Japan as non-tariff barriers are converted to tariff barriers under the GATT.

PARA.TAB: It is good news for the cattle industry and, as I said in the House of Representatives yesterday, good news for horticultural industries as well, though they frequently fail to see it as such because of some of the temporary difficulties that they are experiencing. The opposition joins once again with the government. Certainly government members opposite—if not the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—have been generous in acknowledging that the opposition has long recognised the value of GATT and we have avoided any misrepresentation of GATT for simple short-term political gain.

It is true that out of the GATT arrangements, the beef industry is one of the major winners. That is something about which we are all pleased. It is also true to say that one of the problems that the beef industry faces is, as alluded to by the honourable member for Paterson and expanded on by the honourable member for Maranoa (Mr Bruce Scott), its cost of production, particularly off-farm costs.

The legislation we are currently considering could be considered as part of a processing reform because what the legislation does is make nothing more than an allowance for a conversion factor so that the levy calculation can be made on cold carcases as well as hot carcases. The legislation, as I understand it, provides for a three per cent reduction in the levy calculation where in fact the calculation is being made on the weight of a cold carcase.

Both the honourable member for Maranoa and the honourable member for Paterson have indicated the importance of the meat processing industry, not only for the opportunity that Australia has to get into the export market in Japan with what is reputable product but also for the employment impact that this processing industry has in regional Australia. I would expand on the comments made by the honourable member for Paterson by pointing out that 27,000 people are employed in meat processing in regional Australia and the employment expenditure alone on meat processing generates something like $752 million for what are principally regional economies in Australia.

The member for Paterson is commenting on the whole question of meat processing. He recognises, as the opposition does, the value of this legislation. As he said, while levies are never welcome, at least this legislation does propose a more equitable way in which a levy calculation can be made. The member for Paterson quite fairly said that, while it is easy to be critical of meat processing plants, management has much to answer for. I want to reassure him that he will not find the opposition disagreeing with that. I do not come from the meat processing industry but I have spent some time in meat processing plants. What historically happened in meat processing that has posed such a problem for the Australian industry is that a them-and-us mentality became the norm. In that sense, there were faults on both sides. There is no doubt that the opportunity for enterprise bargaining and for greater cooperation between process workers and management is helping in some ways to break that down.

We need only look at the experience that enterprise bargaining has brought to an unrelated industry—the mining industry in the Pilbara of Western Australia—to see what it can do. There we can see what sort of attitudinal change it can bring about and how much: not only productivity is enhanced, but the whole self-esteem both of employers and employees is enhanced when the them-and-us strategy is broken down. There is an attitudinal change and some real sense of cooperation.

I stand in this Main Committee as a South Australian. While we are in debate now, a major meatworks in South Australia is going through this whole exercise as to whether or not it can survive in the light of the present processing costs for meat anywhere in Australia. The works I refer to are the Tatiara meatworks. It has been very much in the news in South Australian papers because it has been forced to close. Currently the Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Dale Baker, in whose electorate I would suspect the Tatiara meatworks is located, is involved in negotiations to ensure that the Tatiara meatworks can remain there. These negotiations will very much depend on whether or not the employees at Tatiara are prepared to go through this sort of attitudinal change that enterprise bargaining can bring and are prepared to raise their productivity in order to lower the cost of production in the Tatiara meatworks. Frankly, the things that are keeping the Tatiara meatworks from being efficient and are forcing it to the wall, with real implications for the people of the country town of Bordertown, are the cost of production, the lack of throughput and the need for the sort of attitudinal change that has been referred to in this debate.

The tragedy for much of Australia's primary industry is that while on farm efficiencies have already been wrought—sometimes at the expense of employment numbers—it has been so much harder to achieve efficiencies in the processing sector. The meat industry illustrates that clearly. In fact, it is a very sobering truth that in meat processing labour costs alone make up 45 per cent of the total cost of any meat processing plant. It is a no less sobering truth that when we compare our own meat processing costs with those of the Americans we find that we actually load the AMLC with an additional disadvantage of up to $50 a carcase, making it that much more difficult for it to get into the Japanese opportunities that the member for Paterson has referred to.

I often use this illustration: if we were to load the wool industry on farm with the sort of employment arrangements that we have off farm in meat processing, the wool industry would never have survived. One of the reasons the wool industry has managed to remain competitive is that years ago it effectively introduced enterprise bargaining into the shearing shed. One of the reasons my own industry, the citrus industry, has managed to remain on farm competitive is that years ago it effectively introduced enterprise bargaining into the citrus field.

Both shearing and fruit picking are done on a contract basis. In my experience, both employees and employers have been better off. Far from employees being obliged to work for less, there has been opportunity for them to work and earn more as their productivity is recognised. This is what enterprise bargaining brings. This is what enterprise bargaining can do for meat processing and this is one of the opportunities in meat processing that has largely been lost.

I recognise that the legislation before the House makes the levy section of meat processing more equitable, because it allows more flexibility in the way in which a carcase levy is charged and recognises the equity of separating hot and cold carcase levy charging. But the reforms that need to occur in meat processing are much broader than this. They are self-evident and have been documented in a number of inquiries. Frankly, what is needed in meat processing is not necessarily an attack on the workers, but a whole change of attitude, so that the opportunity is there for workers to be rewarded for what they do at rates that reflect a competitive rate with the rewards that are offered around the rest of the world.

The member for Maranoa made a very valid point—which was also taken up by the member for Paterson—when he expressed his concern about the drought that has so much affected his electorate. The concern that we, as legislators, now have in regard to the beef industry is, principally, its capacity to be work productive and efficient in world terms in the processing sector. Secondly, we need to ensure that when this drought ends there is still a breeding stock in place, so that the opportunities that now exist for the beef industry around the world, as GATT has lowered tariff barriers, can be exploited in the best possible way by ensuring that we have the breeding stock to keep our processors happy and to keep the demand for our export product met.

That is a real challenge. It is not part of this legislation. It is something that the government should address with an appropriate drought package, to provide opportunities for farmers to ensure that they keep their breeding stock in place, so that we still have an industry when the drought ends. As far as this legislation is concerned, it allows the processors to more equitably enter into levy charges and, in the spirit of that equity, the opposition is pleased to support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill, and I will make just a few brief comments about the circumstances of primary industry. The issue of road and rail comes up regularly. I would like to put on record that there is one very important debate that this country has not had: that concerns the relationship between road and rail, seen as a transport mode collectively, and not seen as a road in isolation from a rail running alongside it. We have a whole range of policies which inhibit rail, and which unnecessarily load up our roads. Frankly, I am appalled that as a nation we have not put far greater effort into understanding the relationship between both. Rail says constantly that it has to pay for its own track. It is subject to the excise, even though it pays for its own track. There is no diesel fuel rebate available. That is just one small example of a relationship that, as a nation, we should understand far better if we are going to develop a truly competitive and effective national transport component.

PARA.TAB: This legislation deals with levies, the weighing of carcases and fairly straightforward matters. But I was interested to note the references in a Parliamentary Library paper to the GATT round. The GATT round was a very important part of the whole discussion about opening up the market for beef. For me, as a new member in this place, it was an important history lesson concerning the seven GATT rounds, beginning in 1947, and this eighth round, known as the Uruguay Round. We see some great opportunities in front of us, but there are many impediments still to be tackled.

I understand that Japan will allow rice to be imported. The minimum access for imports will rise from four per cent of the average level of rice consumption, to eight per cent after six years. The interesting statistic that is of value to this discussion is that there will have to be reductions of 21 per cent on general volumes of subsidised exports, and reductions of 36 per cent on budget outlays on export subsidies from their 1986 to 1990 averages. That sums up some bottom line numbers concerning the opportunities for Australia as a competitive exporter.

I want to touch briefly on the future of agriculture. Constantly as I move through my electorate I hear great concern about the future of agriculture, and it is not just that mind-set that comes when people are on hard times. The drought does do things with people's minds and it does perhaps distract us from the more positive aspects of life, but there is an underlying concern about the future of agriculture, about the number of people that will be employed, the opportunities that will be there for future generations.

I was at a primary school about a month ago doing the sort of thing that members of parliament are expected to do, and it is a part of my work that I thoroughly enjoy. The deputy principal asked me about my family and I said, `Well, this one is doing that and this one is doing something else,' and so it went on. It turned out, of course, that none of them were on the farm and none were going back on the farm. She said to me, `You are a successful farmer—you have got your children off the land.' And there it was quite starkly in front of me. There is that feeling in regional Australia that there is no future for young people, and that is why we see such a push on Austudy and the assets test in education, because there is an overwhelming belief that we must get our young out of agriculture. That is something that I will not dwell on any longer but it is something that we must address as a nation.

I want to talk a little bit about the drought from a different angle. We have heard the statistics on the lack of production and the effect that we think it will have on our economy, but I want to touch on something that came to me this morning in talking to home, that brief contact with home. I said to my wife, `How is the morale at home?' and she said to me, `I think it is not anything that you would particularly notice just yet, but people are getting more niggly, they are getting that little bit more frustrated as the drought bites and they know that they have to wait another 18 months at least for an income.' So we must remember in this place the personal effects on families and on individuals as they struggle to come to terms with this devastation. It will wipe out many, their businesses and their futures, and they will have to start again. But for those who have the courage to go on perhaps we could just share with them the pressure that is on them currently as individuals.

I just want to go on to the matter of employment in primary industry. This has been quite an issue over the last decade, unemployment and the opportunities for particularly regional Australia. I think it is accepted that the urban centres, the major cities of this country, have a greater range of opportunities but there are many of us who choose to live in the regions and who value what that life in the regions offers to us. I think that we need to see it in a much more holistic sense.

I will try to sum it up this way. I was at a very good seminar that the Parliamentary Library put on last week and a senior Labor backbencher there related this anecdote. He had said to a major employer on talkback radio, `When did you ever support a wage rise for the workers?' Of course, the employer had to say, `Never', and that was seen by this senior Labor backbencher as a great coup, as a great win, that he had made his rhetorical point and he had scored a political point on the day. Of course, it is just as easy to ask when a union ever did not go for a wage rise or refused a wage rise. It is part of our ethic and part of our culture that we tend to lock ourselves into these situations and I think the nation has been a loser because of it.

I want to read into the Hansard this morning something that the Reserve Bank bulletin of September said about the internationalisation of employment and of wages. I think that really is something that as a nation we might look at rather than just get into the cheap political point scoring. It is worth spending some time on it because this is really about the future of our primary industries and its contribution to our nation: the effect of the internationalisation; the employment opportunities and wages; and the coexistence with primary industry. This statement from the Reserve Bank bulletin sums it up for us, gives us much food for thought and is something we really should attack as vigorously as we can as a parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: If trade reform does indeed lead to a more efficient and dynamic economy, real wages and employment opportunities will increase. The concern is that the dispersion of wages will also increase. As tariffs continue to fall, and imports from low-wage countries rise, there may be downward pressure on the employment and the relative wage of workers with few skills. To date, however, the loss of low-skilled jobs in Australia as the result of trade reform appears to be relatively modest. It is only in the clothing and footwear industry that cheaper input prices, associated with lower tariffs, have caused significant job losses.

PARA.TAB: An alternative, but related view is that changes in technology, rather than direct effects of trade, are driving developments in the labour market. The suggestion is that there is some world-wide technological change that is reducing the demand for unskilled labour. This technological change is mainly driven by general scientific advance. In the United States it is leading to lower wages for unskilled workers. In Australia, and in other countries with relatively inflexible relative wages, it is raising the possibility of chronic unemployment of unskilled workers.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge that the government is trying to address this with its case management and with its Working Nation document, but we still have, by international standards, a very rigid job market. The statement also says:

Both increasing wage dispersion and high unemployment are leading to pressure in many countries to limit or reverse trade liberalisation. These pressures seem generally inappropriate, and particularly so, if the real force is technological change. A more appropriate response is to ask what type of policies might be used to limit, and to deal with, increasing inequality and unemployment.

PARA.TAB: One response is to give up on the notion that the wages system is an appropriate tool to achieve income distribution goals. Perhaps an economy adjusts more easily to various types of shocks if relative wages are free to move. In the end, a more flexible labour market may deliver lower unemployment and a more dynamic economy. If this is the case, the tax and transfer system is probably the appropriate policy tool to achieve distributional goals. The difficult issue is how to do this. If the market-clearing wage for unskilled workers falls too close to the level of unemployment benefits, is the incentive to work affected?

SPEECH.PARA: The great criticism of my side of politics is that we do not care enough about the low income people and do not place enough store in supporting social security. I feel that I can bring some credibility to this debate because as a farmer for many years I have really not made much more than social welfare wages. So it is presumptuous to think that my side of politics is always the silvertails. The statement from the Reserve Bank bulletin continues:
If highly-skilled labour that is internationally mobile is taxed heavily, the incentive to require skills may be reduced and the high taxes may lead to a `brain-drain'.

That is already occurring. I know from my work with the long term strategies committee that the people who measure these things within our immigration department were very surprised at last year's statistics, and there is already a brain drain out of Australia. The statement goes on:
Understanding these interactions between the tax and transfer system and people's incentives is critical to developing successful policies concerning income distribution.
A second response is to upgrade the skills of relatively unskilled workers through increased training.
But here again, training for what? The statement continues:
By reducing the relative supply of unskilled workers, it may be possible to increase their relative wage.
We understand that. The statement goes on:

This idea is attractive. If the training is of the right type, the new growth theory suggests that it might also increase the economy's rate of growth. The fact that training holds the promise of increased growth and less dispersion of income has seen many governments embrace the idea in recent years. The real problem is what type of training is required. Should it be vocational or general? Should training be conducted by government or in the private sector? How should training be paid for? These are questions with no simple answers. However, the twin processes of technological change and internationalisation significantly increase the returns to finding the right answers.

I come back to my comments about GATT and about the opportunities for Australia and for the primary industry sector to provide, firstly, I suppose, a survival mode; and then to go on and provide employment opportunities for the whole nation. We are going to have to do quite a lot better over the rest of this decade if we really are committed to the philosophy of full employment.
