SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lindsay The Hon E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Mr LINDSAY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill incorporates Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 of 1993 into the Excise Tariff Act 1921 and Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 of 1994 into the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993.

PARA.TAB: Excise Tariff Proposal No. 4 of 1993 proposed to remove an anomaly that exists in the treatment of crude oil production for crude oil excise purposes under the Excise Tariff Act 1921.

Duties of excise are payable under the Excise Tariff Act 1921 on crude petroleum oil produced in Australia. As a result of the operation of other Commonwealth legislation, such as the Petroleum Resource Rent Tax Assessment Act 1987, excise is in effect only payable on crude petroleum oil produced from the North West Shelf project area and in most onshore production areas.

In 1987, the government introduced changes to the petroleum taxation arrangements to encourage petroleum exploration and development in Australia. A key factor in these changes was the exemption of the first 4,767.3 megalitres of crude petroleum oil produced from onshore fields and offshore projects from the payment of excise. This exempt crude oil is defined as `exempt onshore oil' and `exempt offshore oil'. The granting of the exemption in respect of exempt offshore oil is dependent upon whether the oil is produced from a `project'. As the term `project' is not defined and there is no other relevant statutory or industry definition, uncertainty exists as to the scope of the exemption from the payment of excise on crude oil produced from offshore projects.

To eliminate this uncertainty and to provide for the consistent treatment of exempt offshore oil and exempt onshore oil, it is proposed to change the basis for the granting of the exemption from the payment of excise on offshore oil while still fulfilling the intention of the original 1987 policy. The exemption is proposed to be granted in respect of crude oil produced from an offshore field, where `field' is a term that is readily understood in the petroleum industry. It is also proposed to insert provisions that will enable the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to make guidelines that are to be taken into account when prescribing a field for the purposes of granting this exemption.
The proposed amendments have the support of the North West Shelf joint venture participants.

Excise Tariff Proposal No. 1 of 1994 proposes to correct cross references in the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993 to the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act (the CELA Act). A number of sections in the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993 referred to provisions in the CELA Act for their commencement. When the CELA Act was renumbered as a result of amendments by the Senate, the cross references in the Excise Tariff Amendment Act (No. 2) 1993 were not altered to take account of these amendments. The proposed amendments correct this error.
The proposed amendments in this bill have no direct financial impact. I commend the bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Excise Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill before the Committee, which will clarify the excise status of the Cossack and Wanaea petroleum fields on the North West Shelf. This legislation will remove any doubt that the Cossack and Wanaea fields are separate for the purpose of excise. As a result, the first 30 million barrels of oil from each field will be exempt from excise. Without this legislation the excise status of the fields is less clear, and it could possibly be argued that the excise exemption should apply to the first 30 million barrels from the combination of the fields rather than each singly.

PARA.TAB: I understand the government has always considered Cossack and Wanaea to be separate developments, even though they are close enough that the production will occur from the same platform. Woodside Petroleum, the operator of the project, requested that legislation be amended to clarify its position beyond doubt. Although this clarification may seem unnecessary to the casual observer, there are sound reasons in this case for making the letter of the law reflect the spirit of the law.

`Sovereign risk' is a term commonly used in the resources debate in Australia now, where, a few years ago, the term was confined to academic textbooks. I would venture that it is one of the greatest problems facing the resource sector today in its dealings with the Labor government. Sovereign risk is simply defined as the risk that governments would change the operating rules after the commencement of a project. Security of investment is a critical issue for resources projects as they are typified by high capital costs, long lead times between discovery and production, and finely judged financial margins. Thus, once the decision to invest has been made, resources projects are sensitive to changes and factors such as taxation arrangements.

The impact of such changes can continue to cause uncertainty for many years, as in the Labor government's decision in 1990 to impose a resource rent tax on oil and gas recovered from Bass Strait. Four years later, the financial consequences of this decision are still subject to action in the courts, and there is still the possibility of considerable increases in the price of gas to Victorians as a result of this change.

The entrenchment of sovereign risk as a disturbing new factor in Australia's resources debate occurred in 1991 with the Labor government's decision to reserve Coronation Hill from mining without allowing negotiations to proceed between the prospective miners and the traditional owners of the land. Although Australia lost the opportunity of 630 new jobs and at least $500 million in export income as a result, the event took on a much wider significance and was widely seen as a turning point for domestic and international investors considering resource projects in Australia.

The decision confirmed the growing suspicion that this Labor government could not take the tough decisions on multiple land use and was not committed to the sustainable development of our nation. Since then, the Native Title Act has further entrenched sovereign risk in the resources debate, particularly since the question of the status of pastoral leases with respect to native title remains inconclusive, even though the legislation purported to exempt pastoral leases from native title claims.

For a development the size of the North West Shelf project, it is crucial that the operating rules for the project not be changed in the middle of the project without full consideration of the consequences. Even though the present legislation seems to involve only a routine clarification of excise status, there is a recent precedent, in addition to the resource rent tax on Bass Strait, which reinforces the eagerness of this government to indulge in sovereign risk in the petroleum sector.

In October 1990, in a very similar situation, the government introduced legislation with the opposite intention of the legislation now before the Committee. On that occasion, the government was seeking to clarify the excise status of two separate oil fields in a way very much to its own revenue advantage.

Geologically, the Tuna L field in Bass Strait was entirely discrete from the surrounding fields and yet the government claimed it should be considered identically to the adjacent field for excise purposes. Not only did the government claim that Tuna L was not a separate oil field; it also introduced into parliament legislation to retrospectively establish its claim. Since this same dispute between the government and the Bass Strait joint venturers was currently being heard by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the government's legislation at the time was a blatant abuse of its responsibility to govern fairly.

The government was unashamedly trying to correct its past errors by retrospectively legislating away the existing rights of the Bass Strait partners, BHP and Esso. Not content with that, the government also used its legislative powers to interfere with the course of hearings then before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The AAT was the relevant body empowered to consider and determine this dispute, and it was a shabby move to legislate to prevent a decision adverse to the government from taking effect.

The Bass Strait joint venturers were entitled to fair treatment under the laws of the land, as is any corporate citizen, small or large. At the time the coalition sought an amendment to ensure the legislation was not retrospective. I would like to think that the arguments of the coalition at that time, during the debate, have persuaded the government not to attempt to override the rights of Woodside Petroleum in the current matter.

Of course, I do not expect the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Mr Lindsay) to make such a public concession but I can assure the Committee that, at the time of the imbroglio surrounding Bass Strait, we properly expressed the outrage of many Australians. It is pleasing to see the government now bring the legislation before the Committee. In any case, I want to welcome the government's more enlightened approach on these issues.

The North West Shelf project is too important to be meddled with by opportunistic interventions from governments. It is the largest natural resource development in Australia's history and is, surprisingly to most Australians, in the league of the Snowy Mountains scheme. However, unlike the Snowy, it has been undertaken entirely by the private sector. Honourable members should not be surprised to hear that the company operating the North West Shelf project, Woodside Petroleum, began life in my electorate of Gippsland and is, in fact, named after a town there.

In 1954, Australia imported nearly all its crude oil, but the wildcatting spirit which has led directly to our present near self-sufficiency in oil was well under way. Thus it was that the float for Woodside was a tremendous success and, although many lean years followed, the astute backers of the company were able to continue to fund the vital search for oil. In 1959, Woodside went all out to gain 2,600 square kilometres of exploration acreage off the Ninety Mile Beach near Lakes Entrance in Gippsland. However, misfortune dogged the company as its unsuccessful permits were immediately adjacent to the enormous oil reserves later discovered in Bass Strait.

In the early 1960s, Woodside was able to secure the entire North West Shelf area, thus establishing its present-day security. Faced with the prospect of exploring this vast region, Woodside took on partners. But the cost was still so huge that in 1967 the company relinquished all other exploration permits to concentrate on the North West Shelf. At this time, a non-commercial discovery was made in the region, but it was not until 1971 that a significant discovery of gas was made. The enormous gas and condensate reserves were then revealed. However, the Whitlam Labor government caused activity to cease on the North West Shelf by withdrawing essential tax incentives. But Woodside managed to keep its staff through this difficult period by contracting drilling work overseas.

Then in 1975, with a coalition government returned in federal parliament and strong support from the Western Australian government, the joint venturers set about developing the gas reserves. It was clear from the start that the project would not be viable without exports. There was simply too much gas for the domestic market alone, and the costs of extraction and transport from this remote area were not justified by the small domestic demand.

In the early 1980s, a 20-year contract to supply gas to the State Energy Commission of Western Australia was signed, and Woodside assumed responsibility for operating the North West Shelf project. The Western Australian contract required a $2.5 billion investment, including a 135-kilometre submarine pipeline which was completed in 1984. Expensive and challenging as this first phase was, the development of the export phase was an extraordinary achievement and has been tremendously successful. Focusing on the enormous Japanese market, Woodside signed a contract in 1985 to supply six million tonnes a year of liquefied natural gas for the next 20 years. With investment costs of around $5 billion, the export phase has surpassed expectations—so much so that in July the Japanese buyers contracted to purchase in the future seven million tonnes a year of LNG.

Since oil prices dropped soon after the 20-year agreement with Japan was signed, management of this project has required strict attention to costs. This focus on costs has been necessary throughout the project, owing to persistently low oil prices, and it is to the credit of Woodside that it has weathered this so well. With the first shipment of LNG in August 1989, the project was entering its mature production phase and earning much needed export revenue. It is worth noting that it took 14 years for the domestic gas to come on stream and 18 years for the export revenues to commence. That length of time is no reflection on Woodside's ability to develop this reserve; rather, it indicates the patience which investors in petroleum and gas must have before seeing a return. It also underscores the need for the operating rules not to be changed by governments.

The seven million tonnes of LNG which should be exported each year from April 1995 will have a value of around $1.5 billion. The project now has the flexibility to meet the demand from its primary Japanese customers, as well as to sell on the spot market and to negotiate contracts with other countries, including Korea and Spain. Further flexibility was added with the discovery of the Cossack and Wanaea oil deposits in 1990.

To develop these deposits, the North West Shelf project will once again be using cutting edge technology to produce significant quantities of oil and gas from the two fields. Instead of the familiar oil platforms used in Bass Strait, production will occur from sub-sea wellheads through a flexible flow line to a converted oil carrier, known as a floating production storage and off-loading facility. Gas will be piped to the existing North Rankin A platform, 33 kilometres away. It is forecast that crude oil production of some 115,000 barrels a day will begin in 1995, providing a very welcome addition to Australia's oil requirements. There will also be production of liquefied petroleum gas starting late next year.

Today, the North West Shelf is a significant driver in the Australian economy. The Clements and Grieg report of September 1993 on the economic impact of the North West Shelf project indicates that the production phase of the project is crucial to our economic wellbeing. The report concluded that in a typical year the project will increase Australian exports by 3.5 per cent, gross domestic product by 1.24 per cent, and national employment by 80,000 jobs. This is a staggering contribution for any one project to make to the health of our national economy. Total royalties to governments were estimated to be $240 million per annum in 1995.

This project has also given a substantial technological boost to Australian industry with the introduction of new technologies with significant local input. For instance, the construction of the Goodwin A platform is a significant milestone in Australia's gas and oil industry. Technically, the development of this platform involved considerable risk and made use of innovative technology not previously used in Australia. In the second phase of the project, which involves the export of LNG, Western Australian companies accounted for 66 per cent of the total value of contracts awarded, with an additional 7 per cent from the rest of Australia.

In addition, the report emphasises that the economic impacts of resource projects extend far beyond the simple direct boosts to exports, output and employment. The North West Shelf project is a sophisticated undertaking which has had to be built and operated on a large scale in a harsh and remote environment. The resulting challenges for the design and supply of equipment required the transfer and integration of new technologies from overseas for Australian equipment.

Local firms have developed expertise applicable to the unique conditions applying to the project, and more rigorous performance standards for equipment performance and supply have been implemented in Australia as a result. New expertise and abilities have been introduced into the domestic market and are flowing through into wider Australian industry. These new capabilities are enhancing Australia's ability to compete internationally.

In another sphere, the North West Shelf project has resulted in $33 million in infrastructure improvements in the Pilbara region, including roads, hospital facilities, power and water supplies, airport works and housing. Woodside has contributed another $10 million in community and social infrastructure, encompassing social, sporting and cultural facilities.

This expenditure reflects a consistent feature of the Australian resources industry. Long before regional development became a trendy label, mining companies in remote areas were building roads and ports for their primary task of developing resources but also houses, hospitals and community centres for the benefit of their employees.

Woodside's commitment to the community is also shown through the visitors centre constructed at Karratha. Given that public access to the facilities on the Burrup Peninsula is not possible, Woodside has provided visitors with an opportunity to understand the project indirectly but comprehensively in the visitors centre. The visitors centre at Karratha overlooks the shore facilities and includes a theatrette showing a video on the project as well as having numerous displays and informative staff. The fact that some 20,000 people visit the centre each year shows that a significant educational resource provided by Woodside is being used.

With a resource project the size of the North West Shelf, it is crucial that governments set in place an appropriate operating framework which provides mutual benefits to the company, government and community. In this regard, it is pleasing to see the Western Australian government reforming the gas market, including removing the state government as a `middleman' between the producer and gas consumer.

So often governments cling ruthlessly to their right to extract large sums of money for a very small service, as the Queensland Labor government does in charging exorbitant coal freights. The freight charges are way out of proportion to the simple rail transport service rendered and are actually so large that they figure in the Commonwealth Grants Commission's deliberations on funding allocations between states. But from 1 January 1995, the State Energy Commission of Western Australia will cut itself out of the supply line, allowing the North West Shelf to sell directly to major industrial customers and compete for new market opportunities, particularly in the Pilbara.

Another significant reform is the removal of SECWA's monopoly on the Dampier to Bunbury gas pipeline. Importantly, Woodside recently publicly expressed confidence that the spirit in which the negotiations of these new arrangements were carried out would achieve the objectives of all parties.

There is a clear example for the Commonwealth government in the manner these reforms have been carried out. Not only have the reforms been swift and decisive but they have been built on genuine trust with the industry, and this must be the keystone of such reform processes.

The Commonwealth Labor government could also take a major step forward in building trust with industry by abolishing export controls on commodities such as LNG from the North West Shelf. Though it is not often publicised, many commodities are subject to export approval by the Commonwealth government. In theory, this allows the Labor government to control the price that Australian commodity producers receive for their exports. However, in practice, export controls have long outlived their usefulness and are largely ineffectual and difficult to enforce.

Australia must respond to the realities of the international marketplace or be left behind. The government must acknowledge that Australian companies selling in these markets have appropriate bargaining power with customers. Thus there is no justification for the government to be able to veto exports on the basis that a fair price has not been received. Even though these powers are rarely used, the existence of even residual powers causes increased uncertainty in decision making and may inhibit the development of the spot market for LNG.

In 1993, the government's independent advisory body, the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics—ABARE—looked at export controls in the coal industry. The report argued `the costs of export controls appear to outweigh any possible benefits'. It is apparent this conclusion applies equally to the export of LNG from the North West Shelf as it does to coal. The assumption that governments understand the operation of markets better than the companies that have to survive and prosper in those markets is outdated and frankly ludicrous. By abolishing export controls, the government would show it has faith in the ability of Australian industry to compete in the international marketplace. With no financial cost to the government, this action would be of material benefit to industry in removing any impediment to free negotiation with buyers.

In conclusion, I must emphasise the enormous benefits that accrue to Australia from the North West Shelf project. It is also crucially important that the government sends the correct signals of support to the operators and investors. As a consequence, the coalition supports the legislation before the Committee to clarify the excise status of the Cossack and Wanaea petroleum fields.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Mr Lindsay) agreed to:
That the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

DEBATE.TITLE: EVIDENCE (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 24 March.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill is consequential upon the Evidence Bill 1993, which was introduced on 15 December 1993. It sets out transitional arrangements for that bill, repeals the State and Territorial Laws and Records Act 1901 and most of the Evidence Act 1905 and amends several acts consequent upon the Evidence Bill 1993, or upon the repeals of most of the Evidence Act 1905. The bill is expected to have no impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue. I commend the bill to the House.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Mr Reith) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: EVIDENCE BILL 1993Cognate bill:EVIDENCE (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 15 December, on motion by Mr Kerr:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith Mr P.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition does not oppose the legislation before the Committee but on behalf of my colleague Senator Vanstone, the shadow Attorney-General, I wish to have the opportunity to make some general remarks about the proposal which will be fairly brief. I also wish to join issue with the government in respect of one aspect of the bill which goes to the question of legal professional privilege.

PARA.TAB: I should also say, on that matter, that there are three amendments encapsulated in this one issue of bona fide contest or discussion between the parties. Whilst I am advancing that amendment, I do not propose that we should employ the procedures to require a vote in the House of Representatives on that issue; I simply seek at this stage to see the issues more thoroughly exposed. When the issue is debated again in another place then that might be the appropriate time for there to be a more vigorous contest by way of vote in that place; but hopefully the issue, by being talked out, can be resolved in a satisfactory way.

The Evidence Bill 1993 and the Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1994 have as their principal purpose the codifying of the laws of evidence as they relate to matters before federal courts, and are also intended as a model for similar enactments within the states. The legislation is therefore a restatement of the law of evidence for application in federal and ACT courts.

Evidence law is largely a product of the decisions of the courts, otherwise known as common law, although each state and territory has an evidence act. Together with the pronouncements of the courts over time, these acts form the basis of the laws of evidence in Australia in the various jurisdictions.

As a result of sections 79 and 80 of the Commonwealth Judiciary Act, the evidence laws applicable in a Federal Court depend upon the state in which the court is sitting. Generally, state laws apply, whether they be of a statutory kind or whether they have originated at common law. In some cases—though in more limited cases—the Commonwealth Evidence Act 1905 may apply. If a Federal Court proceeding is transferred for hearing in another state, the evidence laws applicable may be substantially different as a result of the fact that, as previously stated, under the current arrangements, the applicable evidence laws depend upon the place in which the matter is heard by the Federal Court. This bill will provide uniformity across federal court proceedings.

Very briefly, the history of this area is that in 1977 the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs proposed that a reference be given to the Australian Law Reform Commission on the question of laws of evidence. That reference was provided to the Australian Law Reform Commission by the then Senator Peter Durack, the federal Attorney-General—a very good Attorney-General, I might say—and in due course the Australian Law Reform Commission produced both an interim report and a final report. In the meantime, the New South Wales government provided a reference to the New South Wales Law Reform Commission, and in 1988 the New South Wales Law Reform Commission recommended the adoption of reforms to the laws of evidence as applicable in New South Wales so as to conform with the recommendations of the Australian Law Reform Commission. So it was that we came to a situation where in 1991 we had a Commonwealth evidence bill and an evidence bill from New South Wales introduced into the parliament to seek comment.

I say, as an aside, that this matter has been the subject of most extensive consultations between the interested parties. Such process obviously is welcome in achieving a sensible outcome and establishing a model for the others to follow. There is no doubt that the more work that is put into achieving a uniform arrangement between the Commonwealth and New South Wales the more will the argument be strengthened for the others to pick up the model being proposed.

The bill before us was introduced in 1993. It was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which, after receiving further submissions and conducting hearings, produced an interim report in June 1994. The committee supported the bill in principle, so that has advanced the prospect of producing an outcome which will be acceptable to all parties and which will advance the objectives of those who have been promoting this reform for many years.

As I say, the coalition generally is supportive of the proposals before the House and, clearly, there are advantages in having a uniform set of laws of evidence around Australia. One of those advantages is that, as uniformity simplifies the law, there is a reasonable chance that costs in the delivery of justice can be—

EMPHASIS.TAB: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 11.47 a.m. to 12.l5 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension I indicated that the coalition does not oppose this bill. We are generally supportive of the initiative to introduce a codified system for the laws of evidence for the Commonwealth and thereby for federal courts and, furthermore, to establish a model designed for the laws of evidence. Also I noted that this effort by the Commonwealth to reform the laws of evidence had been undertaken in conjunction with the New South Wales Parliament, which has likewise introduced an evidence bill. By and large the two bills reflect similar provisions.

PARA.TAB: I come now to the one aspect of the bill on which agreement between the Commonwealth and New South Wales was not able to be reached. The coalition's view, very simply, is that the Commonwealth ought to adopt the New South Wales approach to the issue and the Commonwealth bill should be brought into line. For that reason, I foreshadow three amendments: one to clause 118, one to clause 119 and one to clause 120. In each case the amendment would be to omit the word `sole' and substitute the word `dominant'.

I will amplify this one aspect of discord between the reformers. The substance of the issue relates to the question of legal professional privilege. You would be aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, that in some circumstances evidence will not be accepted by courts, where that evidence pertains to the professional communications between a solicitor and his or her client. The test that is proposed in order to determine whether legal professional privilege attaches to a communication or document made or prepared for the purpose of legal advice or for the provision of legal advice is whether that purpose, that is, the obtaining or provision of legal advice, is the sole purpose or the dominant purpose of the communication or document. That is the nub of the issue—whether this test should be the sole purpose test or the dominant purpose test.

I am sure you can appreciate, Mr Deputy Speaker, that if the sole purpose test is adopted in this Commonwealth legislation which is proposed by the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) it is a more restrictive definition. A more generous definition for the benefit of the party seeking to claim the privilege would be the dominant purpose test.

The New South Wales Government, and, therefore, its proposal as embodied in the New South Wales bill, is that the dominant purpose test should be adopted. This matter has been the subject of correspondence between the Attorney-General for New South Wales and the federal Minister for Justice. In a letter dated 16 September 1994, the Honourable John Hannaford, MLC, Attorney-General for New South Wales, says:

Finally, I have also given consideration to your comments in your letter of 26 August 1994 concerning client legal privilege. I remain of the view that the adoption of a "dominant purpose" test in clauses 118 and 119 of the Bill would be preferable to avoid the possibility, no matter how remote, of strict judicial interpretation of the existing "sole purpose" test.
In view of the fact that the adoption of a "dominant purpose" test was a key recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission, I regard this approach as a matter of some importance.

SPEECH.PARA: He completes the letter by saying:

PARA.TAB: Although any divergence between the State and Commonwealth Bills would of course detract from the goal of uniformity, I am strongly of the view that a "dominant purpose" test would be more appropriate for New South Wales.

SPEECH.PARA: From that, it can be discerned that a significant aspect of this is that the Australian Law Reform Commission itself proposed the dominant purpose test and yet this minister insists on a stricter test of the sole purpose. I would be keen to encourage the minister to amplify his views on this. As I understand, his reasoning is based on the argument that the sole purpose test is a more accurate definition of the law today. I presume he argues that the government is attempting to codify the existing law. If the existing law is the sole purpose test, that is what ought to determine the Commonwealth's policy.

PARA.TAB: This matter has also been carefully considered in the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of June 1994 entitled `Evidence Bill 1993: Interim report'. I have not been closely associated with the matter but I have had the benefit of reading parts of that report and it seems that the Senate committee has done a thorough job on the issue and has taken expert advice on the matter. In particular, the Senate committee had the benefit of advice from Mr Justice Smith, who expressed his concerns about the sole purpose test. At the bottom of page 38, the Senate committee's report says:

SPEECH.PARA: He suggested that this test could not be applied literally without destroying the client's privilege. For example, a solicitor's file comes into existence not solely for the purpose of giving legal advice and assistance; it is also used by the solicitor as a record of work done in part for the purpose of charging the client.
The committee's report continues in paragraph 1.138:

His Honour noted that the High Court decision in Waterford v Commonwealth (1987) 163 CLR 54 demonstrates that the sole purpose does not work. He endorsed the ALRC suggestion of a `dominant purpose' test. This view was supported before the Committee by the Law Society of NSW. It was also an alternative suggested by Sir Garfield Barwick in one of the minority judgments in Grant v Downs, the case which laid down the `sole purpose' test.
The committee refers to a view of the minister in paragraph 1.140:

Responding to this view, Mr Justice Smith noted that the High Court itself had had great difficulty with the sole purpose test—only two members had purported to express support for it and had, in his Honour's view, even then converted it to what he called `a Clayton's' sole purpose test. In His Honour's view, the most significant point demonstrated during the ALRC's extensive consultation was that `the sole purpose test was not workable. There was universal acceptance of the dominant purpose test as a test that struck appropriate balance'.

This reveals another point that is worth making, perhaps as an aside, and that is that we have another authoritative voice—in this case the Law Society of New South Wales—that has also examined this matter in great detail and come down in favour of the dominant purpose test in distinction to the sole purpose test.

PARA.TAB: It is true that the Senate committee did not resolve the matter but it certainly quoted at length the arguments in favour of the dominant purpose test. We have got the Australian Law Reform Commission lining up on that side; we have got the Law Society of New South Wales lining up on that side; we have got Mr Justice Smith lining up on that side. In fact, everybody seems to be lining up on that side except the minister. Given the nature of the opinions expressed, and given the fact that the purpose of this proposal is to provide a uniform law and

SPEECH.PARA: a model, I look forward with great interest to what the minister has got to say. He has got a lot stacked up against him. As I say, we do not intend to be churlish and seek a division at this stage in this discussion. We put this forward to the minister, genuinely interested in his response. This is not a party political matter. We are simply keen to explore—

TALK.START.PARA: —I accept that. I genuinely accept the opposition has been very constructive throughout this whole process.

—That is my maiden interjection, Mr Deputy Speaker. I am not quite sure how to handle it. I can assure you that I certainly know how to handle the minister—I can promise him that. That is really the sum total of this particular matter. Needless to say, as I have said earlier, the coalition does not oppose the bill. We think there are some benefits in uniformity and in establishing a model but, if we do so, let us try to make it as uniform as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to support the passage of the Evidence Bill 1993 and the Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1994. In the second reading speech on the Evidence Bill the Minister for Justice (Mr Kerr) detailed the origins of the Evidence Bill from the original recommendation in November 1977 of the then Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when he referred to `a review of the whole of the evidence law . . . be undertaken by the Law Reform Commission.' The review would work through to the work of the Law Reform Commission and the development with New South Wales of the text for the new evidence bills. The result of that work is now before the committee.

PARA.TAB: Of course, there have been further developments. The provisions of the Evidence Bill were referred earlier in the year to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In June the committee published an interim report in which the committee stated it was keen to see the bill passed, and made recommendations relating to some further work by the government on some of its provisions, its time of commencement and post-enactment monitoring. Further, the Minister for Justice has responded to the Senate committee, advising the committee of the government's intention to move the amendments to the Evidence Bill we are to consider in detail today.
In supporting another evidence reform of this government, the Foreign Evidence Bill 1993 and the Foreign Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendment) Bill 1993 I said the following:

SPEECH.PARA: [As] a non-lawyer . . . I think it is very important to make it clear that, from the community's perspective, the law as it is presently understood and practised in this country is seen to be in the province of the very rich and the very powerful, in the hands of and available to large corporations and, to a very limited extent, the poor and dispossessed through legal aid assistance.

I believe that is still the case. These bills will make a significant contribution towards correcting the community's perception of the way the law is practised in Australia. This is very important because it is clearly a right in a democratic society that if we are to be ruled by the rule of law then people must be able to clearly and easily make use of the legal system to seek to attain their rights.

PARA.TAB: The bills will attempt to right this misperception in a number of ways. First, they will for the first time in this country's legal history make evidence law much more accessible to those who need to use it. Instead of being found as part of the common law in the decisions of the superior and appellate courts across Australia, much of the law of evidence that applies generally in all proceedings will, for those who appear before the federal courts and the courts of the Australian Capital Territory, be found in an act of the Commonwealth statute books. Having evidentiary rules in statutory rather than in case law form will make it much easier for litigants and practitioners not versed in the arcane mysteries of the law of evidence to find and apply the law.

Secondly, the bills will make a contribution towards lowering the cost of obtaining justice in the courts in which they also apply, which can only improve the community's perception of the practice of law in this country. The Evidence Bill in particular will lower the costs of justice: firstly, by providing rules where there is no uncertainty about the current law, for example, in the rules relating to hearsay evidence; and, secondly, by making the admissibility of evidence more predictable and hence litigation itself more predictable. Thirdly, the bills will make it much simpler to prove many facts.

On this last point there are provisions throughout the bill that will reduce the time and cost of proving facts. Amongst its hearsay exceptions, the bill includes exceptions for: use of tags and labels attached to an object in the course of a business to prove the identity, nature, ownership, destination, origin or weight of the object and the contents, if any, of the object and, for statements about the identity of a sender or recipient, the time of transmission of a message transmitted by E-mail, fax, telegram, lettergram or telex.

I turn now to documentary evidence. The bill abolishes the original document rule and in its place provides straightforward procedures for proof of the contents of a document, which will enable a party, as an alternative to tendering the original document, to prove its contents by tendering a readily available photocopy, microfilm copy or, in the case of computer records, a computer print-out of such records. In part 4.3, which is titled `Facilitation of proof', there are provisions that will remove the need for witnesses to attend court to give evidence of formal matters—for example, proof of signatures and proof of acts in official documents—or of the proper functioning of devices and processes used by businesses that have provided evidence. The same part also includes presumptions relating to the postage, transmission and delivery of postal articles and documents transmitted through telecommunications systems.

The third way in which the bill will make a contribution towards correcting the community's perception of legal practice is by removing unnecessary restrictions on the admission of evidence in proceedings. Examples of such provisions are the exception for first-hand hearsay evidence in civil proceedings where it would cause undue expense or undue delay or where it would not be reasonably practicable to call a witness to give evidence, and the abolition of the exceptions to the opinion rule for matters of common knowledge and ultimate issues in proceedings.

Obviously, there are many other issues in the bill, but I will not address them in my contribution this morning. However, I believe it is part of a major commitment by our government to significant legal reform in this country, going to the very heart of social justice matters. We are, as a government, doing great things on many fronts—and I include the cultural statement yesterday as a profound achievement of this government. But if we are not able to provide individuals and citizens in this country with their right to present their case and to believe and have confidence that the law will provide an effective arbitration of their circumstances and their rights as citizens, then we fail to achieve our social justice objectives. The Evidence Bill will effect considerable improvements to the way in which the federal courts and the courts of the Australian Capital Territory determine proceedings before them, and demonstrates the commitment of the government to real reforms of our legal system.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak on the Evidence Bill and the related bill, the Evidence (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill. The Evidence Bill is to be judged against its objective of providing uniform evidence legislation across Australia. The bill is to operate in federal courts and in the ACT. A complementary New South Wales bill is a model for other states and is in terms substantially similar to those of the Commonwealth bill.

PARA.TAB: Whether to support the principle of the bill has, for me, been a real issue. There are undoubtedly unsatisfactory features of the present rules of evidence. Each state has for its rules a combination of common law and statute. Each state has an evidence act. For the most part, the evidence acts are outdated. They contain provisions in some cases designed to overcome what were even medieval common law principles which had survived for far too long. An example is the old rule that an accused cannot give evidence in his own defence—something that is outrageous by modern standards.

At the federal level, the Judiciary Act provides for federal courts to apply the rules of evidence of the jurisdiction in which the court is sitting. That usually means that state rules of evidence will apply. There are, however, some federal statutes—the Commonwealth Evidence Act being one—which deal with some evidentiary issues which affect federal courts.

Against that background, it is relevant to ask whether the rules of evidence achieve the objective of having substantially the same result for the conclusion of litigation wherever it is heard in Australia. The answer in most cases is yes, but the answer in all cases is probably not yes. It is also relevant to ask whether any additional costs are imposed on the public generally because of the existence of different evidentiary rules in different jurisdictions. The answer is certainly yes, but how significant that is is very difficult to determine or even to comment on. The impact of the existence of different rules in different jurisdictions in an individual case in court is probably quite insignificant.

In some situations the present rules of evidence can cause confusion or they are unnecessarily complex or they draw unnecessary distinctions. An example, of which I have experience, is the overlapping statutory rules relating to the admissibility of business records. The provisions of the Commonwealth and state acts can apply together in some situations. The rules are quite important because they allow the admission of documents which constitute records of business transactions, which would otherwise be inadmissible because of the hearsay rule. The difference between the different models of business records legislation between the different jurisdictions is, in itself, unjustifiable and quite inconvenient.

The case for reform with a view to achieving some uniformities, in my opinion, is well made out and has been made out for quite some time. However, the question is whether this bill goes about achieving uniformity in the right manner. The Evidence Bill has the appearance of a code. It seeks to restate some basic laws of evidence and to effect, by restatement, reforms in some areas where reform is undoubtedly required.

There has been significant debate both within the legal profession and among the judiciary as to whether it is appropriate to reform the law of evidence by a bill in this present form. One view, strongly held and voiced by some lawyers, is one for which I have considerable sympathy. That view is to the effect that large parts of the rules of evidence—particularly those governed by common law principles—are well known, well understood and applied on a daily basis without any difficulty in courts across the country. Those rules are in no need of reform and they are in no need of statutory restatement.

On the other hand, it is accepted by proponents of this view that other parts of the rules of evidence are in need of reform and that reform should be uniform. In support of that, the argument goes that that reform should relate to those areas in need of reform only. In support of that view, it is argued that a statutory restatement is inflexible and incapable of adaption to changing circumstances in the same way that the common law is. There is a need for adaptability to deal with, for example—taking a modern situation—proof of communications using modern technology.

Another argument in support of this view is that whenever laws which are the subject of daily focus or which govern daily activity are changed, there is an enormous economic cost to the community. The cost is often unseen and unidentified, but it is substantial nevertheless.

Against that view is put the response by the architect of the bill. It has perhaps already been said, but the bill is substantially the result of a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission in 1987. That report was preceded by a number of events which commenced with a report of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs as long ago as 1977. The committee called for a reference to be given to the Australian Law Reform Commission to review the laws of evidence. That was done by the then Attorney-General, Senator Peter Durack QC, in 1979.

The commissioner in charge of the reference at the Australian Law Reform Commission for most, if not all, of the years that the commission studied the subject was Mr Tim Smith of the Victorian Bar. He is now Mr Justice Smith of the Supreme Court of Victoria. His study found that, in order to coalesce the evidence acts of the different states, it was necessary to incorporate rules in one statute. He found, however, that the evidentiary rules dealt with in the state acts covered virtually all areas of the rules of evidence. So to coalesce the state acts you would have to study, in effect, the whole field.

The second point Mr Justice Smith made was that there were in fact serious problems in virtually all areas of the law of evidence. In some of them, the common law not only had failed, but would almost certainly continue to fail to provide appropriate reforms, or an avenue for reform. He also argued that the case for ossification of the law by statute is not convincing in the light of the fact that the common law itself had shown a capacity to do the same. A particular example he cited was the hearsay rule and its exceptions, its exceptions being a list which was closed approximately a century ago.

Mr Justice Smith also mentioned the difficulty of getting court-generated reform. Court-generated reform is likely only to come from the hearings in appellate courts or the ultimate court of appeal, the High Court. But only infrequently will an issue of evidence be significant in a case such that it can be taken on appeal as the principal issue and dealt with as a principal ground of appeal, either in an intermediate appeal or in an appeal to the High Court.

For my part, I am not entirely convinced by Mr Justice Smith's response. However, there is experience in other jurisdictions which suggests that a restatement can achieve the practical ends for which this particular restatement is designed. I use the expression `restatement' rather than the expression `code' because the bill does not represent a true codification of evidentiary rules. In some respects it builds on unstated basic principles of the common law. The saga of successive governments endeavouring to bring in legislation capable of being adopted as uniform legislation has gone on for approximately seven years and, in my view, that is long enough. I am prepared on that basis to support the bill, but not without some doubts that it will not have some of the advantages suggested for it, and not without some doubts that it will have some of the disadvantages suggested by the critics.

I do have one apprehension in relation to a statutory restatement of the rules of evidence. The bill, on enactment, will result in the virtual transfer of responsibility for the principles of evidence to parliaments, this parliament in particular. What had previously been the province of courts and was capable, to some extent, of incremental development over time will now only be capable of change by statutory amendment. That is a perfectly ordinary consequence of the enactment of a bill, but we are dealing here with a bill which would be the subject of focus in every court, in every jurisdiction, across the country on every day that the courts sit.

One can say similar things of other legislation, like the corporations and securities legislation, but the concern I have is generated by the fact that this bill has not generated any interest whatever within this parliament on its passage through, and it is in fact a significant moment in the history of the administration of justice in this country that the bill appears likely to be passed in the near future. I seriously doubt whether, if significant defects are identified in the future in the bill, it will be possible to generate sufficient political interest and parliamentary interest for amendments to be dealt with with the expedition and the priority that, for my part, I believe they deserve.

This bill has taken 17 years from the sowing of the seed or the germination of the seed to this point. It took eight years for the Australian Law Reform Commission to present its report and it has taken nearly 15 years from the time the Attorney-General's reference to the Australian Law Reform Commission was given to reach this point. It is a significant event, and I only regret that more people did not recognise it for what it is.

I do not propose to say anything about the contents of the bill. It would be impossible to do justice to its contents in any significant way, but I do make the point which has been made by the honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith). He referred to the difference between the Commonwealth and New South Wales in relation to the admissibility of legal professional privilege. The difference appears to be that the New South Wales Attorney-General, with considerable support, favours the admissibility of evidence on the basis that documents came into existence for the dominant purpose of the obtaining of legal advice. The position of the Minister for Justice is different and the bill itself is different; it applies the sole purpose test rather than the dominant purpose test.

For my part, I must say that when I first read the case of Grant v. Downs, which was the first statement of the sole purpose test—I read it many years ago, so long ago I am not quite sure when it was, but the decision was in 1976—I thought the High Court had got it wrong and I thought that the dissent of Chief Justice Barwick was right. I have not changed in that view since I first read the case. I note that in Waterford v. the Commonwealth in 1987 the High Court, at least a majority, referred to Grant v. Downs in terms which suggested an approval of it. I do not think that Grant v. Downs was directly in issue before the High Court in Waterford v. the Commonwealth; it was more a question of whether the legal professional privilege rule would be extended to the seeking of legal advice within government, so the exact extent or application of the rule in relation to sole or dominant purpose was not an issue. But I would urge the minister to pay heed to those who have urged before me the New South Wales view, because I think the New South Wales view is right. I commend the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I firstly say that we have reached this point in relation to this legislation largely because of the good cooperation of all members and senators in progressing a matter which has required a considerable amount of coordination between the Commonwealth and the states. We now have a piece of legislation which has, with one exception—which has been noted and commented on in this debate—been agreed between the Commonwealth and the state of New South Wales. New South Wales was selected by the other states to be their frontrunner, as it were, in determining a common position that might then be the basis of common legislation, and that is a mark of the great maturity of those involved in the legal profession and those who have involved themselves in the debate thus far.

PARA.TAB: Because of the time, and the fact the opposition has indicated that we will be able to progress this matter through fairly promptly today without difficulty, I will make some quick comments about the sole purpose test, which has been the main issue raised today. We understand that there will be further debate in due course in the Senate.

The government opposes the amendments that will be moved in relation to dominant purpose for the following reasons. The first reason is that the sole purpose test is, in my opinion, all that is necessary to protect the public interest involved when a person consults a lawyer. That person should be able to make a full and frank admission to the lawyer of all relevant facts and circumstances in which he or she seeks legal advice or professional legal assistance in relation to litigation. Any broader test for privilege for communications or documents involving a lawyer has a potential to erode a balancing of other significant public interest, that is, the public interest in courts having available to them all relevant factual material in proceedings.

The amendments are also opposed for cost of justice reasons. The sole purpose test is relatively easy to apply, particularly compared with how a court might be expected to apply a dominant purpose test. This point was accepted in the interim report on evidence by the Australian Law Reform Commission which stated that a dominant purpose test may be more difficult to apply than a sole purpose test. There is perhaps more room for argument and false claims about the appropriate purpose. An examination of the document will often be sufficient for the sole purpose test, but not for the dominant purpose test.

The sole purpose test has been working well for several years. I confidently expect that the test will be interpreted in the same way as the High Court has interpreted the common law sole purpose test, that is, as explained in Waterford v. the Commonwealth. In Waterford the High Court looked at the purpose for which the document was created in applying the sole purpose test expounded in 1975 by the court in Grant v. Downs.

It is hard to believe that courts would set out to create a difference between the test applying under the bill, the test applying at common law, and the sole purpose test, by deciding that the same language should be treated differently. The comments made by Mr Justice Smith to the Senate committee were that a solicitor's file containing notes of instructions from an advice given to a client might not, on a strict application of this test, be privileged under the bill. It was argued that because a document on the solicitor's file came into existence for a variety of purposes, including a record of work done for the purpose of charging the client, privilege would not attached to it.

That analysis is not correct. Clauses 118 and 119 afford privilege where evidence would disclose a confidential communication made or the contents of the document prepared for a relevant sole purpose. Even if, for the sake of the argument—and I certainly do not concede it, I think it is wrong—a particular document on a solicitor's file is not privileged in its character as a document, it would be privileged if evidence of the document would result in disclosure of a confidential communication made between the client and the lawyer.

I do not want to address this matter at length here. There will be occasions in other places for the debate to be extended. I do believe that this is a matter in which the Commonwealth is perfectly justified in adhering to the position it took. I note, simply for the record, that originally it was also the position of the New South Wales government as part of an agreed process. It is disappointing that on this issue we are not ad idem, but each government, for its own reasons, thinks that this is an issue of principle. It will be ultimately for the parliament to decide which of those approaches is the correct approach to take. I have no hesitation in advocating the basis and propriety of the view that we are adopting as a government.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 23 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: What procedures are available for a future Commonwealth Government to withdraw from any international treaty, convention, protocol or other agreement signed and ratified by the current Government if the instrument is not supported by or consistent with the values of the future Government, Commonwealth or State Parliaments or the Australian people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: There are various procedures for withdrawing from treaties, and the procedure generally depends on the terms of the relevant treaty. Most treaties provide that withdrawal will take effect at the end of a specified period following notice of withdrawal by the withdrawing party. Were the Australian Government to decide that it was no longer in Australia's interests to be bound by a particular international agreement, it would need to observe the conditions for withdrawal provided for in that agreement. All countries enter into international agreements on this understanding.

Under the Constitution, the treaty making power is vested in the Federal Executive. Accordingly, only the Federal government is authorised to enter into or withdraw from an international agreement on behalf of Australia. Withdrawal from an international agreement is a treaty action of similar significance to becoming party to an international agreement, and similar domestic procedures apply. For example, in deciding whether to withdraw from a particular agreement, the Government would usually consult interested sections of the community.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a declaration made under the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978 on 28 July 1989 by the then Attorney-General, Mr Lionel Bowen, which appeared in the Commonwealth Gazette of 24 July 1989 and permitted the recruitment in Australia by the Papua New Guinea (PNG) Government of persons, not being members of the Australian Defence Force, to serve with the PNG Defence Force (PNGDF) in any capacity to facilitate the use of four Iroquois helicopters supplied to the PNG Government by the Australian Government.

(2) Are any Australian nationals in Bougainville, or have they been, associated with, acting in support of, or taking part in military or military-style operations in Bougainville; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) have any been injured, wounded or killed as a result of those activities; if so, what are the details in each case.

(3) Have any Australian citizens taken part in a blockade of Bougainville by (a) alerting PNGDF units or vessels travelling between the Solomon Islands and Bougainville to assist their interception or (b) by any other means.

(4) Is the Minister able to say how the PNGDF deals with crews of unarmed vessels believed to have breached, or attempted to breach, a blockade of Bougainville; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) have crews been killed; if so, what are the details.

(5) Have PNGDF practices in Bougainville been the subject of Australian diplomatic protests, investigations, intelligence gathering or any other procedure potentially leading to these measures; if so, what are the details in each case.

(6) Is Australia a signatory to any international treaty or agreement concerning matters dealt with in the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) is the declaration referred to in part (1) consistent with Australia's obligations under each instrument.

(7) Is Australia a signatory to any international treaty or agreement concerning actions of the types referred to in previous parts of this question; if so, (a) what are the details and (b) has the Government fulfilled Australia's obligations under each instrument.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, although the declaration to which Mr Mack refers was made on 20 July 1989, not 28 July 1989.

(2) A number of Australian nationals employed by the aviation company under contract to the PNG Government have served as pilots for Papua New Guinea Defence Force (PNGDF) UH-1H helicopters. The PNG Government has repeatedly assured the Australian Government that the aircraft are used in accordance with the guidelines set down and agreed between both governments in July 1989. These provide that the aircraft are to be used for purposes that are limited to such activities as transporting troops and supplies around Bougainville, patrolling and surveillance activities and evacuating military and civilian casualties.

The Government is aware of only one Australian national being wounded while operating a PNGDF UH-1H. He was shot in the leg while flying in central Bougainville in 1992. The Government is not in the possession of any evidence to suggest that at the time of sustaining the wound he was engaged in any offensive military activity.

Australian nationals are also employed as helicopter pilots on Bougainville by other civil aviation companies contracted by the PNG Government. The Government regards the details of their employment and activities as matters for the PNG Government and the contractors and individuals concerned.

Members of the Australian Defence Force (ADF) serving as loan personnel with the PNGDF under the Defence Cooperation program have from time to time visited North Solomons Province. Their visits have been at the request of the PNG Government under the terms of the letters signed in 1977 by the Papua New Guinea and Australian Ministers for Defence on the use of ADF personnel in politically sensitive areas. Such visits are approved on a case by case basis by the Australian Minister for Defence. They have been limited to providing technical advice for the PNGDF and Royal Papua New Guinea Constabulary (RPNGC). There has been no ADF direct involvement in mounting or participating in PNGDF operations on Bougainville.

The Government is aware that there may be other Australians living in Bougainville. One Australian has been reported to be living in BRA controlled territory in central Bougainville and there may be an Australian teacher in the Talena district. In addition there are several business people (mostly in the construction industry) present in Bougainville at any one time. As many of these people do not inform the Australian High Commission in Port Moresby of their movements, it is impossible to provide further details. The Government has no reason to believe however that any of these people are engaged in "military or military-style operations" in Bougainville.

(3) Some of the Australian nationals employed as UH-1H pilots by the PNG firm contracted by the PNG Government, may have been involved in conducting surveillance of the PNG/Solomon Islands border. The Government is unaware of any further activity that would be relevant to this question.

(4) The Government understands that the PNGDF carries out the internationally accepted process of calling on vessels suspected of illegally crossing the PNG/Solomon Islands border to halt and be searched.

The Government is aware of incidents where vessels crossing the border have been fired upon by the PNGDF on occasions when those vessels have refused to allow a search or have fired at the PNGDF. The Amnesty International report for 1993 contains allegations of unarmed vessels being fired at by the PNGDF. The Government is not able to confirm the accuracy of those reports.

(5) The Australian Government has a keen interest in the human rights situation on Bougainville and has regularly engaged the PNG Government, including at ministerial level, on reported incidents of human rights abuses. During regular visits to Bougainville since mid-1991, Australian High Commission officials have investigated PNGDF practices on Bougainville and its relationship with local communities. Human rights issues were given particular emphasis during the visit to Bougainville in April 1994 by an Australian parliamentary delegation which was funded by the Australian Government. Some of the issues raised have included the alleged execution of Ken Savia (a former minister in the Bougainville Interim Government), treatment of BRA captured by the PNGDF and the detention without trial of BRA members. The Australian Government has also strongly supported the proposal that Papua New Guinea establish a Human Rights Commission and has offered both financial and technical assistance.
The frequency with which the Australian Government has engaged the PNG Government on human rights issues makes it impracticable to give comprehensive detail.

(6) There are no international agreements to which Australia is a party concerning matters dealt with in the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978. The International Convention against the Recruitment, Use, Financing and Training of Mercenaries has not yet entered force (and is unlikely to do so for some years). Furthermore the Australian Government has not yet finalised its position on signing the Convention, although the issue is under active consideration.
(7) (a) Australia is a party to a number of international agreements concerning armed conflicts, notably the four Geneva Conventions of 1949 and the two protocols of 1977.
(b) Yes.
